Author: demetri3524
Content: @Walker Reynolds, so if we are running an edge driven OEM product (operated by PLC), would you put a CPU (advantech uno, OnLogics) at the edge with each system?  Assuming that this system has mission critical data that needs to be buffered should you have a network issue between an operator CPU that has Canary Historian.  Our products typically live in a pretty segmented world, meaning one system is tied to one test cell and one operator is typically testing a piece of equipment in that specific test cell.  I‚Äôm open for other topology that may reduce licensing costs but still provide a robust system that doesn‚Äôt drop data from the edge!

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> @Walker Reynolds, so if we are running an edge driven OEM product (operated by PLC), would you put a CPU (advantech uno, OnLogics) at the edge with each system?  Assuming that this system has mission critical data that needs to be buffered should you have a network issue between an operator CPU that has Canary Historian.  Our products typically live in a pretty segmented world, meaning one system is tied to one test cell and one operator is typically testing a piece of equipment in that specific test cell.  I‚Äôm open for other topology that may reduce licensing costs but still provide a robust system that doesn‚Äôt drop data from the edge!
@demetri3524 yes sir, I would -- unless the PLC supports store and forward over MQTT or DNP3 out of the box (think Opto 22 or Wago, for example).  The final architecture would depend on several variables but for any mission critical data, buffering and S&F is required in the architecture.  The beauty of edge driven and report by exception with S&F is that we  have a lot of options available.

Content:
> Question of the day: Have you worked with edge gateways that turn Automation data into IIoT data?  If so, which is your preferred gateway?  Have you worked with PLCs or controllers that support IIoT protocols like DNP3 or MQTT?  If so, which is your preferred hardware?
@Walker Reynolds 

We have started with Linux based  ARM single board computers like Raspberry Pi, Balena Fin, and a few others.

Also experimented with microcontroller based alternatives like Audrino, Particle Mesh Networking boards. 

Our primary interfacing was HTTP + OPC-UA, with Saia Burgers PLC line. 

Once our product recieves traction we will implement Machine protocols.

Author: zackscriven
benveenema
Content: Looking for PLC (or other controller) recommendations. We are building out a new manufacturing line and part of my duty in that is to bring in the current state of the art in industrial controls. My background is in C++ on baremetal/RTOS micros but I have worked on a few PLC Ladder based projects as well. I've been looking into PLCNext, Groov EPIC, UniStream, Turck and other brands but it's hard to tell how well something is going to work until you've actually tried to build something with it.  Any input is appreciated. Thanks!

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> Looking for PLC (or other controller) recommendations. We are building out a new manufacturing line and part of my duty in that is to bring in the current state of the art in industrial controls. My background is in C++ on baremetal/RTOS micros but I have worked on a few PLC Ladder based projects as well. I've been looking into PLCNext, Groov EPIC, UniStream, Turck and other brands but it's hard to tell how well something is going to work until you've actually tried to build something with it.  Any input is appreciated. Thanks!
@Ben Veenema Opto22 Groov Epic is really hard to beat for IIoT.  Depending on the complexity of your needs, EZAutomation EZRack is a great low cost option that has native MQTT integration but lacks the bells and whistles (which is why its low cost), Siemens also supports MQTT out of the box now (we are using a lot of S7 1200 with their MQTT blocks).  My personal opinion, Opto22 is the leader in I4.0 process control and its not even close, really.  @Benson Hougland can provide more info you need it but damn... they got the goods.

Author: mdowdell
Content:
Adding to edge discussion... Opto 22¬¥s products look, and are, fantastic.

I can also vouch for Red Lion¬¥s products. I have used their HMI (Graphite and CR series) and gateways (DA series and FlexEdge) in production environments.  What I love about Red Lion products are: free software, multiple protocol conversion, OPC UA capabilities, web server and viewer, good tech support, and MQTT connectors - including Sparkplug B.  I should also, note that defining UDTs or data structure is easy within the Crimson software. Also, their cellular offering makes it very easy to demo for customer.

For example, grab a DA o Flexedge, add cellular, then install Ignition with MQTT Distributor & Engine  (with 2 hour demo) in a Vultr Linux-based server, mock up some responsive displays in Perspective, and you have a relatively inexpensive (< $1200USD) way of demoing solutions to customers. Cellular is a great way to do an end-run on IT and build the business case for our OT friends in maintenance and operations. 

I do not understand why I do not hear/see more about their products in the I4.0 space.

Maybe we need to invite Mike Granby (former Red Lion President and Crimson development) to this forum.

Never mind... just did!

Author: paulwright3831
Content: I've just had a global PLC maker state that by embedding an OPC-UA server into all their controllers, they circumvent the drawback of the poll/response nature of the communication (cited by Walker and others). To me, it sounds like a lot of overhead having every device run a server, and I'm still not sure you can call that  "stateful, report-by-exception technology" from the edge. What do you make of their argument?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: @Paul Wright  Adds overhead to the edge device, which we can live with if HP is sufficient.  If it leverages pub/sub part of OPC-UA standard, it is report by exception and will use MQTT, it is not stateful because state of the connection is not part of the OPC-UA standard (including pub/sub part of the standard).  It does not jump the hurdle on the size of the OPC-UA headers, eg. payload is exponentially larger than flat MQTT or Sparkplug MQTT as well as DNP3 or LWM2M.  OPC-UA also is not 'OPEN' in the traditional sense because so many parts of the standard are optional.  All that being said, this is a step in the right direction for hardware manufacturers and I would not deter them from taking this step.  Unfortunately, there is no doubt they will charge for this OPC Server because it will require far more work to develop than just adding in MQTT client support (which hardware manufacturers are able to include at no additional cost).  When its all said and done -- adding on board OPC servers is a good thing for process control and does little to add value for enterprise IIoT solutions.

Content: It depends on your definition of edge.  But -- in most cases, you need drivers to unlock data from PLCs and Controllers -- and those cost money.  Now, if you are going to connect directly to the sensor and monitor the rising and falling edge of transitions with your own intelligence, there are plenty.  In most cases, you are using a driver to pull the data natively and then converting to MQTT -- using cMT-SVR, Kepserver, Ignition Edge, Litmus Automation, etc.

Author: mdowdell
Content: I got a question regarding Ignition. Any experience with using it as a multitenant app in the cloud. I have done something similiar using roles, but as you guys probably know the tags/data are grouped in the same space. Any ideas or comments with respect to best practices?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: We do it a lot, actually.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
1. Use a separate tag provider for each tenant
2. Use a separate db connection and schema
3. Use 1 parent project with all of your base templates and windows
4. Create a new child project for each tenant from the parent
5. Use separate user sources for each tenant

Author: mdowdell
Content:

Content:

Author: andyott33
Content:
Hello all,
I have a few questions in regards to shield termination, I have some experience with shield termination but still have lots to learn. So, any help would be appreciated.

Background information:
We are helping commission a dairy barn that has many VFDs connected to a controller with multiple 0-10Vdc outputs. Each 0-10Vdc output is going to approximately 10 VFDs. See the attached schematic for a simple illustration of the set up.

I was wondering what the best practice is for terminating the shield of the control wires going to VFDs, specifically when going through junction boxes. I have read that it is best to keep continuity and that the shield should be terminated on one end (signal source end). I have also read that it is best to terminate the shield on both ends. What is best?

Also, what is best practice for shield termination when branching off from the junction box to the VFD?

If you have any other feedback or recommendations, I am happy to hear.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Terminate on both ends (you will hear both answers) -- the goal is to remove any current and eliminate induction on the supply line -- which will create noise on the control signal.

Author: andyott33
Content:
> Terminate on both ends (you will hear both answers) -- the goal is to remove any current and eliminate induction on the supply line -- which will create noise on the control signal.
@Walker Reynolds  So, terminate at the source and then at each VFD? Thanks for help!

Author: dewayne_warden
Content: @Walker Reynolds I‚Äôm curious, why not use signal splitters that will isolate each signal? If one VFD goes down, it could pull others down. Isolators help prevent that.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Ideally, yes @dewayne_warden we would isolate control signals to each.  I was just answering his ground loop question.  You are correct on the control design.

Author: dewayne_warden
Content: @Walker Reynolds Thanks boss.

Author: andyott33
Content:

@dewayne_warden  thanks for the tip! Do you have any recommendations for signal splitters?

Author: dewayne_warden
Content: @Andy There are many to choose from.  I use Acromag, they have a few different types.  Some can be done with bluetooth setup or USB cable with laptop.  There is also AGM, more old-fashioned but they have a 7 year warranty.  Not bad on price.  You need to use an active isolator/splitter, not passive.  Active Isolators can be AC or DC powered.  Another good isolator is made by PR Electronics, look up model 5104, which I believe can do either Volt or mA isolation.  Your j-box may need to become a panel box to house and power your isolators.

Author: benveenema
Content:
Object Oriented PLC/IEC-61131

Who is using OOP/OOIP?

I am transitioning from writing control systems using C/C++ and extensive OOP techniques to writing Control Systems using Industrial Controls IDE's (in this case Codesys) and finding it very frustrating. The things I am used to doing aren't working like encapsulating functionality in objects and sharing that functionality with controlled interfaces. 

I am looking for books, video, training and other resources for using well structured OOP techniques in PLCs.  I have found this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wv1eGzBT5mQ&feature=emb_title&ab_channel=garyhartland and the corresponding project here: https://ooip-foundation.proboards.com/ and have signed up for this course: https://www.udemy.com/course/plc-object-oriented-programming-advanced-infastrucutre/

Should I even be bothering with OOP? My gut tells me hell yes and that OOP is a natural fit with IIoT but I'm open to the idea that it's not appropriate or too much trouble.

Author: jasperlouage
Content:
Hi all, I have question on Edge devices. I've heard of devices like opto22, onlogic, Moxa, Advantech, but I never really understand the use of these devices in the real world.
I mean, In the projects that I have been doing we're able to connect the plc's to KepWare, and then from there we can connect to anything. 
Why do these devices exist and what problem do they solve? I know this is a very basic question probably, but I can't seem to get a good answer.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: @Jasperlg I'd say their main difference is that they are cloud ready. Modbus is not suitable for LAN to Cloud connection. The protocol is not efficient and not secure. MQTT can use encryption, is lightweight and projected for these cases when the connectivity might be breaking any time. You can also program these devices for a internal buffer, in case they are not connected to the cloud. And also, they usually allow you to install Linux and that potentially expands the horizon for you to do things like ML on the controller. Think of an Arduino, that is good for control but is shy and computing power. And a Raspberry Pi that is the opposite. Edge devices basically are both in a single box.

Author: jasperlouage
Content: @Mario Ishikawa thanks for your answer! Can't you do all these things allot cheaper by just having 1 kepware server for your whole plant, which from there you can also use MQTT to the cloud or do ML?

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Yes, you can! So every project is a new situation and different architectures can be used. What you mentioned makes a lot of sense, at least for now. These Edge devices are good if you have a different scenario like, one device per plant in one or several plants. And I mean for now because many people mention that 5G will change everything and will make it viable for every device in a plant connect directly to the cloud. But time will tell if this will be really used as the main way.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: And BTW, by ML I mean running an already trained model for fast response to interact with the controlled process. To train the model, you would typically use the cloud. Ex: you want to train a model to count and inspect parts for quality, using vision. You can train the model on the Cloud and once it is trained, to detect the pattern you no longer need a lot of processing power, but you do need minimal latency and cannot rely on the cloud. So if you have a PLC that can run TensorFlow, for example, it is the perfect scenario as there is no latency. And for this case you will need a PLC that also has a "computer" processor, typically ARM, so you can run Linux.

Author: jasperlouage
Content: Thank you for you insights @Mario Ishikawa!

Author: autom8ion
Content: Really though isn't it the beginning of a paradigm shift to where there is no PLC?  I can see that you can quickly hit a tipping point where all of the edge devices installed as IO collectively have more computing power than the PLC they are connected to.  I think people will start to ask what is the real purpose of a PLC in a distributed smart sensor network and we will move to more of a distributed control system with sophisticated control planes for orchestration and maintenance of your control system cluster.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: In my opinion, there is still a need nowadays to keep things simple on the PLC side due to availability. So the PLC CPU is certainly very limited, but once it is started it is already running the control program in 100ms. Basically there is no software fault on the firmware to halt it. For critical mission, this is very important. When you go to Edge processing, you will need more things, and an Operating system such as Ubuntu will open a lot of doors. But if it crashes, it might stop your machine/process and take like one minute to go live again. But PC PLC is a topic since the 90s. Beckhoff is now working with PLCs that run over Windows, and they even made a partnership with Microsoft to have the Kernel modified (so they said in a conference I was attending). It certainly might be a move, but on the other hand, computers evolve so fast that there is no time for a technology to get mature to the point it will really be bug free and 100% availability. In 5 years they will have to repeat their hard work for new lines of processors and SOs, while if you want just to count pulses a $200 Siemens Logo will do the job pretty well just as it was already doing 15 years ago. I'm not against to the change though, just saying my opinion why things don't seem to move faster in the market.

Author: autom8ion
Content: @Mario Ishikawa I agree.  Industrial automation will always be a trailing edge market, its not big enough to really drive the market when it comes to hardware and software.  We end up being in a position of identifying how to implement the commodity hardware and software driven by some other market like the smart phone industry.

Author: autom8ion
Content: https://cumulusnetworks.com/products/cumulus-linux/ This got me thinking ... It would be interesting to play around with.

Author: paulwright3831
Content: https://opcfoundation.org/news/press-releases/new-international-initiative-to-define-opc-ua-cloud-library/ - So if I am a well-established manufacturer with a fleet of legacy controllers humming along with OPC-UA, while planning the integration of newer IIoT systems to better understand operations (OEE, supply chain, etc), how valuable will these machine profiles be? I am trying to better understand the value, not criticizing their goal. Will it drive faster adoption of OPC-UA for some? Possibly. Will that help companies realize the promise of Industry 4.0? What are your thoughts?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
For a variety of reasons, it appears that "edge" has assumed the meaning of necessarily "field" or "on-machine".  There exists a lot of hardware that is designed to be deployed in the field (e.g., rugged, hardened, din rail, 24vdc), but marketed as "edge".  The word "edge" has become somewhat synonymous with "field".  The name edge comes from edge-of-network.  A rack full of blade servers at a large manufacturing site is just as edge-of-network as an industrial PC in an asset's electrical panel.  The role of the edge here is to connect nodes into the broader digital ecosystem and, optionally, provide some local services (e.g., HMI, analytics).

You're definitely right.  It's often much more practical (and cost-effective) to leverage centralized software gateways rather than deploying tens, hundreds, or even thousands of industrial PCs on assets.  When a manufacturing site is sufficiently large and "Industrie 3.0" enough, it will have the infrastructure in place that makes this favorable.  However, not all industrial environments are like this.  Some are remote oil fields with bare bones infrastructure.  Some are plants with infrastructure but without a culture or useful IT personnel to make use of it.  These environments are where a low-cost edge device can make a ton of sense.  It's also a lot easier to sell an edge device than piece of software that requires an entire infrastructure (e.g., server, networking, maintenance).

I believe overtime we will likely see more intelligence on the asset level.  Either we will see more advanced PLCs or we will see some sort of industrial PC playing a supervisory role.  In addition to IIoT connectivity, they might be providing edge services (e.g., HMI, buffering, information models, remote access) that make the node itself more useful.  At the end of the day, the vast majority of transformation programs will involve brownfield sites.  This will pose constraints and will help mold the solution.

Author: jasperlouage
Content: Thanks for the insights all!

Author: abram7918
Content: Within my organisation we use the term 'thin edge' for devices  next to the machine, & 'thick edge' for plant or site level gateways. This resolves the ambiguity of the term 'edge'. IT departments getting their info from cloud & SaaS providers understand the 'thick edge'.

Author: abram7918
Content: The discussion has identified thin edge devices & centralized  software based solutions for integrating machines  (as a minimum meaning protocol conversion). Using a central server approach means that communication with the machine over the plant network occurs via PLC native or modbus protocols which are unsecured leaving a large security vulnerability on the shop floor network. Thin edge devices provide the opportunity to secure shop floor level communication. Centralized server solutions must also be made high availability, increasing complexity.

Author: dewayne_warden
Content: Wouldn‚Äôt the overall strategy dictate your hardware needs?  The goal is real-time data centralized in the UNS. To me, Edge devices should help access legacy data and participate in processing it into a useful form. As technology progresses, the ‚ÄúEdge‚Äù will become a part of the equipment or the PLC.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: This is a great convo ‚Äî I will circle back to this tomorrow... movie night with the fam (watching IT).  Happy Halloween, y‚Äôall!

Author: abram7918
Content:
@dewayne_warden  The role of the thin edge is potentially;
* southbound connectivity (protocol conversion, communication management)
* processing of data into useful form
* build the equipment data model  'at the source' as low down the hierarchy as possible, then everything above is more interchangeable
* execute logic
* run ML models
* a way to connect peripheral devices such as scanners, local displays (MES interface for example)
* northbound communication : M2M or higher level systems
* northbound communication security : part of an overall plant level security solution 

Using / distributing that data via a UNS is a second step & certainly not the only goal.

Author: dewayne_warden
Content: @Abram I smell a great tutorial for class! Thanks for the clarification.

Author: abram7918
Content: @Paul Wright  Global library of OPC-UA data models is also in progress with Microsoft . An interesting part of this video is the combination of pub-sub and OPC Methods  in parallel. https://youtu.be/XsOx1T8Q1z4

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
> The discussion has identified thin edge devices & centralized  software based solutions for integrating machines  (as a minimum meaning protocol conversion). Using a central server approach means that communication with the machine over the plant network occurs via PLC native or modbus protocols which are unsecured leaving a large security vulnerability on the shop floor network. Thin edge devices provide the opportunity to secure shop floor level communication. Centralized server solutions must also be made high availability, increasing complexity.
@Abram  Is this your company‚Äôs I 4.0 architecture?  What is your stated digital strategy and upon which architecture are you scaling out?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: The best way to secure shop level data is: prohibit multi-cast traffic on the plant floor LAN (in nearly all cases) and leverage edge driven architecture (outbound connections only).

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Your term ‚Äòthin edge‚Äô == edge gateway in I 4.0 and IIoT speak.  This is a solid solution for converting legacy systems into the IIoT protocol you‚Äôve selected.  RE: your architecture and digital strategy ‚Äî what is the plan for non-legacy solutions, how do they integrate as they are added to the plant floor?

Author: benveenema
Content:
> @Mario Ishikawa I agree.  Industrial automation will always be a trailing edge market, its not big enough to really drive the market when it comes to hardware and software.  We end up being in a position of identifying how to implement the commodity hardware and software driven by some other market like the smart phone industry.
@Densparker I think Industrial Automation can keep up with edge of the market if we start leveraging open source software and hardware and move closer to an "embedded" software/hardware approach. Industrial Automation software and electrical circles seem to want to live separate from the mainstream but I don't see a lot of reason for this. Instead of asking chip vendors to cater to us, we can conform to them, build really reliable, easy to use IDEs on top of their platforms and processes. But I think this will require an open source approach as there isn't much incentive for a company like Rockwell to do this.

Author: abram7918
Content: @Walker Reynolds No, that's not our architecture, but it adresses an issue of using OPC-UA methods in parallel to a message bus.  The corporate folks are sold on OPC-UA as the standard for shop floor communication with thin edge for legacy machines, & integrated OPC-UA for new equipment.  There are some positives: the machine data model can be built at source of data, METHODS are convenient for complex data exchange, security on the shop floor network can be managed, overall plant OPC node structure is browsable namespace. But its NOT a UNS with S95 overall structure, and therein lies the crunch. I note your comment that ERP transactions also pass through the UNS. I assume that means there is no direct ERP to MES connection else it would bypass the UNS which acts as the central message bus. I'm chewing on what our architecture should be, given large legacy installed base with / without MES. I have posed a query earlier regarding using kafka as the cental message bus allowing to 'replay' events when necessary to sync an application or on- board a new application.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: @Abram UNS does not eliminate all discrete, point to point, connections between applications but it does reduce them drastically.  There may be ERP to MES connection, there may not be -- that depends on the solution.  What we do say is, there WILL be an ERP to UNS connection and there WILL be a UNS to MES connection.

Author: benveenema
Content:
I'm working on a Machine Status Class that will contain a Machine State register DUT(Enumeration). I'm referencing this video for Intellic: https://youtu.be/iIXnWX1aUV4?t=300 to try to incorporate as many states from the get-go as I can.

This class will be used on most if not all of our machine builds going forward, so I'd like it to contain as many states as any machine could need, without it getting too out of control.  Here is the DUT I have so far:

TYPE MachineState :
(
    Stopped, // Machine is stopped
    Running, // Machine is running
    DT_Standby, // Machine is in run mode and ready to run (waiting for operator)
    DT_Setup, // Machine is in setup mode
    DT_Faulted, // Machine is broken/errored
    DT_Blocked, // Waiting for downstream part to clear
    DT_Starved, // Waiting for upstream part
    PDT_PreventativeMainteneance, // Planned or scheduled maintenance
    PDT_ScheduledDownTime // Other schedule down time
);
END_TYPE

Looking for input on what should be in this DUT.

Also, I'm not sure about the Stopped state. Walker says they always reserve 0 for Stopped, but wouldn't any of the downtime states (DT) be stopped as well? It seems redundant.

Thanks!

Author: marioishikawa
Content: @Ben Veenema have you seen PackML? It might give you some ideas to add to your model.

Author: benveenema
Content: I haven't. Looking into it now.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: It put modes and states in different dimensions. It can be applied to any discrete model.

Author: benveenema
Content:
Looking at this: http://omac.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/PackML_Unit_Machine_Implementation_Guide-V1-00.pdf

PackML seems to define major states of:
Held,
Execute,
Suspended,
Idle,
Stopped,
Aborted

The rest of the states are transitioning states.  This does give me a good sense of what Stopped would be vs other downtime conditions. "The purpose of the STOPPING state is to stop the production of a production order from a
Supervisory control system or when the operator wants to stop the production order at a
unit/machine" but it doesn't include states for Setup or Maintenance, at least on my 5 minute fly-over I didn't find any

Author: marioishikawa
Content: on page 64 you can see the modes. So different modes have different possible states. A Setup is not a state, it is a mode, and during this mode, some states are possible. This can be useful for example to avoid tracking downtime during setup (other than the setup itself). But with most people I talk about, they see it as hard to accept that operators will apply the machine in the correct modes.

Author: benveenema
Content:
Thank you! Missed this first time around.

I like the distinction between modes and states. I think that's pretty important. I guess what I'm building is actually a "Machine Mode" register as PackML defines Mode vs State. Most every machine is going to have multiple state machines within that could be running at different times. For instance, the current machine I'm working on has a "Left Hand Ram Out" State, this state could be active in Production or Setup modes (or more)

Author: lmtx
Content:
Which MQ solution do you prefer as a MQTT broker for IoT edge deployment - RabbitMQ or ActiveMQ? I find RMQ more developer friendly but it does not support QoS 2; configuration of AMQ is a pain but it can handle QoS2.

Which one are you using and why?

Author: andyott33

Author: bogaczykn
Content: Has anyone used the IOLink stuff from IFM? I recently spoke to their sales guy about a device and he started discussing all the IOLink masters in which also has an IOT port built in. Looking for some feedback if you have used any of this stuff in a system. Any concerns with IOLink in general?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: I tested IOLink for a high speed data capture solution for an oil rig --and I think @zackscriven might be familiar with it @BogaczykN .  Its very similar to the profibus hubs you can get from PF et al.  Upsides are speed and reliability, downsides are they use a JSON payload structure which has to be parsed on the broker side.  In terms of IIoT ready, they are similar to Kepware's IoT Gateway (which we don't use anymore and will replace with our gateway or highbyte).  I basically describe IO Link as profibus devices with rudimentary MQTT JSON support built in.  Overall, its a step in the right direction but sorely lacking in some very key areas.

Author: zackscriven
Content: Great question @BogaczykN

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
We use IFM's IO-Link products extensively.  We put it on every new project.  It's all but replaced analog input cards for us.  Those 8-port IP67 IO-Link masters work wonders in both brown- and green-field scenarios.  They save on cabinet space.  Flexible topology (e.g., daisy chain, ring).   Analog transducer for non-IOL devices.  IFM has a slick IOL LED stacklight with a buzzer.  Each port can be used for conventional DI/DO and can be expanded with hub devices.  Sensors can be whitelisted to specific port(s) and the configs are stored in the PLC.   I could go on and on.

Many assets in my industry vertical tend to be useless from a preventative maintenance standpoint.  When an asset does have sensors, they're typically digital/discrete.  That is, there are alarm levels programmed into the sensor and only an on/off signal is passed onto the PLC.  The problem with this approach is that it does not convey how good or bad whatever is being sensed is.  It, instead, merely indicates something is good or bad.  This makes any sort of analytics or process improvements impossible.  IO-Link has been a powerful tool in helping us solve these problems.

We have not used the IFM IO-Link masters with the additional MQTT JSON feature.  We have only deployed the versions with just EtherNet/IP or PROFINET.  I've been very curious about them though.  We have scenarios where we do not have fieldbus connectivity and deploying a standalone IOL master in parallel could potentially work.

@Walker Reynolds brings up a great point about parsing.  One of the reasons that we've had such great experiences with IFM's IOL products is that IFM maintains a library of AOIs and FBs for all their products.  These libraries decode each sensor's payload into useful tags on the PLC.  Without these, it's probably a nightmare.  It's like programming on an old fieldbus.

Perhaps IFM should partner up with HighByte.  Imagine some sort of plugin that decodes the IFM IODD payloads into one's UNS models.

Author: bogaczykn
Content: @is thanks for the detailed response.  It really looks like IFM has covered this technology well. I can see these products being great for last minute expansions.

Author: zackscriven
Content: Thank you for the knowledge @js  üôè

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
"In terms of IIoT ready, they are similar to Kepware's IoT Gateway (which we don't use anymore and will replace with our gateway or highbyte)."

Could you provide a little more context on this statement about Kepware's IoT Gateway?

The reason I ask is that we're looking at using it as a bridge between the native PLC protocols and something like HighByte.  We don't really have practical infrastructure constraints between our PLCs and on-prem servers.  The field networks are logically segmented, small, and have dedicated uplinks.  In this environment, "polling on the edge" (e.g., centralized servers, in-panel hardware gateways) is more of a physical distinction than a network one.  What's your recommended approach to gateways for this type of environment?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: The IoT Gateway in Kepserver is really just a stop gap and doesn't contain any of the modeling (UDT) or logic (triggers, events, filters) needed to effectively scale.  HighByte is a much better solution for this.  We only use the IoT Gateway in Kepserver as a last resort because it is little more than grabbing a bunch of tags and packaging them in a JSON for a single topic publish to the broker.  This means that topics are buffered together at n interval.  Highbyte allows us to do all of the abstraction, modeling and logic management and break the events apart.  So -- we could have topics that publish no faster than x interval and other topics that publish at y interval.  More and more, we need flexibility on the edge.  IoT Gateway from Kepserver is a nice add-on, but they've done nothing with it since the original release (nothing of substance anyway).

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I really appreciate the insight.

So, let's assume no embedded MQTT or OPC-UA within the PLC.  We're stuck using the native protocol (e.g., E/IP CIP, PCCC, S7, FOCAS, GE-SRTP).  What's your preferred way to get this into HighByte?

[PLC]   <-native protocol->   [Kepware                   ]   <-OPC-UA->   [HighByte]
[PLC]   <-native protocol->   [Kepware + IoT GW]   <-MQTT->   [HighByte]
[PLC]   <-native protocol->   [???                             ]   <-MQTT->   [HighByte]

With regard to the "feeding" the model, how much heavy lifting do you on the PLC?  Do you spend a lot of time building out logic here?  Or, are you taking a minimal approach by working with what's there and deriving anything else within HighByte?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
If we are using a gateway on the edge, then this is the ideal architecture:

[PLC]   <-native protocol->   [Kepware                   ]   <-OPC-UA->   [HighByte]

We do as much heavy lifting in the PLC as we can, keeping a close eye on the resources we are using for abstraction and packaging.  That being said, most of the time we are doing nothing in the PLC for brownfield implementations and nearly everything in the PLC for greenfield implementations.  We have a toolbox full of solutions that all get us to our desired IIoT infrastructure (edge driven, report by exception, lightweight, open architecture built on a technology stack), which tool we use is dependent on several factors.  The solution fits the problem but all solutions meet our minimum technical requirements.  There isn't one tried and true way -- this is where 'architecting' the solution comes in.  

In general, for existing brownfield PLCs, we are doing next to nothing in the PLC.

In general, for future PLCs, we are doing as much as we possibly can in the PLC.

Your toolbox has to have both solutions and everything in between -- which tool to use is a function of the problem.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: I hope that helps -- I know its 10k view, but the 1k view is dependent on your specific implementation.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Interesting. So, for the heavy weight and feeding the model (not the control logic) on the PLC I'm thinking about things like line calculations derived from cell tags, and things like that, meaning things you could do on Pi Asset Framework. Is that the case? My question is, for new implementations, having all the calculation on the PLC, does it make harder to change calculations later? Changes seem to be so frequent and having them on HighByte for example seems more flexible as you do not need to worry about PLC downtime or PLC remote access.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: correct -- I wouldn't do any calculations in the PLC, that should be a method or engine called centrally.  What we do in the PLC, line state abstraction (from alarms and conditions to a single status register), alarm arrays, event arrays, count arrays, machine information (manufacturer, install date, sensor definitions).  Any modeling above the machine level gets done outside of the PLC.  However, for existing PLCs, it makes little sense to add all of this in, so we abstract it outside of the PLC so we can scale quickly.

Author: benveenema
Content:
> Any concerns with IOLink in general?

I recently used IO-Link in a small machine for a valve bank and touch indicator.  My impressions were mixed. I think IO-Link has potential but is a long ways from being the "USB of Industrial Machines" as I have heard it touted. 

In the case of the products I was using, SMC valve bank, Banner K50 Touch Indicator and Turck TBEN-L4-8IOL the IOL documentation  was mediocre to bad. Almost no PLCs have IO-Link built-in so you end up using a fieldbus to talk to an IOL master and it ultimately just adds another layer between the PLC and the device.

When we started down the path of IOL, we mistakenly thought we could use the IOD files that are associated with most devices as a driver that would do a lot of the heavy lifting for us, such as creating an easy path for reading and writing registers on the devices. Turns out that wasn't the case and I ended up needing to write a lot of custom code and bit-shifting to get all the "bonus data" that IOL devices offer.  Without the bonus data, an IOL device is just a regular old device that is more difficult to connect to your PLC.

If device manufacturers start offering drivers/function blocks for mainstream IDEs, and/or documentation improves dramatically, I think IOL could be massively beneficial. It would likely still pale in comparison to more general "smart device" protocols like I2C or SPI. These protocols are popular in the embedded controls space and benefit massively from economies of scale. With a little hardening, I think they could be used in the Industrial Controls space. Most Arduino and RPi PLCs have it baked in as well.

One thing I did like was the defacto standardization on the M12 cables. This is not actually part of the IOL spec but a lot of manufacturers seem to be organizing around them and they're great! We have a mantra, of "Never make a cable" and M12, M8, etc really help here.

Author: abram7918
Content:
"If we are using a gateway on the edge, then this is the ideal architecture:

[PLC]   <-native protocol->   [Kepware]   <-OPC-UA->   [HighByte] "

... & from HighByte you publish topics (individual tags or data bytes)  into an MQTT broker?

Author: abram7918
Content: In the brownfield case you mentioned using OPC-UA via Kepware to get data out of PLC's. Do you use OPC-UA METHODS at all?

Author: .dhess
Content: @Andy Include "What will happen if we don't do this." in your key points. Sometimes that is the deciding factor for management. Fear of loss is an effective arguing point.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Kepware's UA Server has implemented profiles for just the core, data access, and security facets.  Nothing for methods.  In speaking with product management a few years ago, adding support for methods was under consideration.

Kepware statement on OPC-UA Method support:
https://www.kepware.com/en-us/support/knowledge-base/2015/opc-ua-method-support/

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I kind of don't blame them.  I have not seen much adoption of the more advanced features of OPC-UA such as information modeling and, in this case, method calls.  There is still a mindset in our industry that we‚Äôre trying to move I/O rather than move information and execute commands.

Client-side, there aren't many apps that support invoking method calls.  And, when they do, discoverability is an issue.  It‚Äôs like trying to calling an API without knowing what it is and how it works.  Most UA client implementations are relics of classic DA.  They interface with the rest of the app with a limited data structure (e.g., ‚Äúflat‚Äù name & value pairs).  It will feel ‚Äúbolted-on‚Äù rather than ‚Äúembedded-within‚Äù.

Server-side, most PLCs are still programmed like it's the dark ages.  Tags are frequently thought of as aliased I/O, ‚Äúhelping‚Äù logic, and alarms/conditions.  They‚Äôre made use within monolithic logic.  Rarely are programs constructed with abstracted interfaces to provide services in a way that a method call would make use of.  To receive commands or serve up requested information, it‚Äôs something much more informal like ‚Äúwatch these signals‚Äù or ‚Äúwrite to these bits on a certain way‚Äù.  It‚Äôs a bit more like interrupting a Rube Goldberg machine rather than starting one.

Author: abram7918
Content: @js This is where intelligent edge devices are useful. Smart edge devices will pre-process data, run logic, run ML algorithms, and provide the OPC interface capable of using OPC Methods & doing the S-bound comms management / handshakes with the PLC. This results in a 'microservices' architecture, rather than all data exchange happening through a UNS and broker. We are thinking about how to leverage the best of both worlds.

Author: paulwright3831
Content: @Walker Reynolds , @js , @Abram , @EgoNoBueno , @Mario Ishikawa, @Ben Veenema  - just stopped by to express my appreciation for all the industry knowledge shared in this thread around Kepware, HighByte, OPC-UA and PLC evolving best practices. Actually beginning to feel like I could understand most of this one day. Great questions asked and solid information provided. Much appreciated.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: thanks! I'm loving this discussion too, and also improving and learning a lot. Glad to be part of this community!

Author: abram7918
Content: Regarding the discoverability of an OPC Method : it's a function call with a discoverable set of parameters to be passed. Like any API, a description is certainly useful, but its not correct to say its not discoverable. The alternative is doing bit / byte level data exchange & control flags / handshakes to manage the exchange. All of those bits & bytes are discoverable individually, but their combination as a function is not : that needs to be described. Furthermore, the other party / system participating in the exchange needs to understand & be configured to mirror that bit level logic. Which is easier? A Method call that passes a few parameters. The fact that legacy PLC's are 'in the dark ages' can be remedied with thin edge devices or server based data flow model applications. The point that few legacy PLC's apply OPC data modelling is not a reason not to do it. The best place to build the data model of a device is as close as possible to the source. Ideally the device is self describing. The OPC foundation, Microsoft, Google, CESMII, VDMA and many industry bodies are all working towards that goal of having libraries of standard data models. The question is : how will we use them ?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: I'm going to touch on this in our mentorship call today and I'll shoot a video to comment on this discussion.  The answer is yes on methods but they are problematic at an enterprise level -- mostly because you don't have wide adoption of methods by vendors, when they are adopted they are less reliable, there are far too many optional elements of the OPC Standard which makes leveraging these elements problematic.  OPC is not the future of IIoT... I've spent 10 years researching it and discussing this.  I need to do a better job of communicating it.  That's on me.

Author: abram7918
Content:
A detailed technical discussion  would be much appreciated. In defining an overall architecture, we consider; 
* heterogeneous comms protocols of equipment / devices & the desire to standardize an interface to each 'type of machine' at some level
* security of comms as soon as anything gets connected to a network
* simultaneous operational & maintenance access (backup / restore) to plc's & configurable devices
* machine to machine comms, use of TSN in future
* field (i/o level) device data / maintenance access
* in the discrete manufacturing environment in particular, consideration of the Event Driven Architecture at shop floor level, and at SCADA / MES / ERP / System levels
* OPC-UA in the continuous process industries (where it seems a more natural fit) vs (? SpB) in discrete manufacturing ... pros & cons
* The global momentum behind OPC-UA, particularly by industry & national bodies. (Swimming against the tide is hard work ... in going with the flow "you might not be right, but you can't be wrong")

These are the elephants in my room.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I don't dispute that the technology is there and it's all possible.  There are tons of research and working groups establishing standards.  The asset administration shell in the RAMI 4.0 spec seems to touch upon what you described.

Theoretically, discoverability is not a problem with OPC-UA methods.  But, in practice, it is.  If one is building their own servers and client apps, there are no limits to OPC-UA.  If one is to leverage third-party products with OPC-UA, there are many limitations.  There are so many optional components of the UA spec that rarely get implemented.  This shapes the way applications are built around UA clients.  Even Ignition, a leading platform built on a modern tech stack, struggles with methods.  Their developers even publicly concede this.  They have a client that supports it, but the rest of their application suite can't really make use of it.  To intelligently interact with a 'UA server with methods, one would basically have to build their own module.

My comment referencing the "dark ages" is not one about technology per se, but rather its practical adoption.  Even with capable technology available, industrial assets are not being designed for open exchange of information.  That is, it doesn't matter how smart the edge is because there is not much useful to abstract from in the first place.  Assets are often programmed as a standalone, turn-key solution rather than something that must interface with other machines or factory.  "M2M" is a good example.  Many machine builders, even in 2020, build automated machines for discrete manufacturing without any sort of interfacing logic for basic material handling (e.g., robot tending).  They're still struggling to even do I3.0 properly.  This is not to say smart edge devices aren't worth it (because they totally are), but rather what they're connected to will pose many challenges.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
The most recent greenfield project I worked on involved 17 major assets, 32 controllers, 7 control platforms, and 17 partners from 4 countries (across 3 continents).  At the field level alone, excluding vision and sensors, there were 9 native protocols in use.  And this was all using brand-new stuff.  Reflecting on this project, I can't imagine being able to mandate that everything come pre-installed with an edge gateway with full-featured OPC-UA servers.  The machine builders wouldn't have a clue what to do.  It would be cost prohibitive and would never meet the program's deadlines.

This shouldn't be viewed as a condemnation of any particular technology or architecture.  It should viewed as the realities manufacturers face and how it hurdles adoption.  There exist very real limitations in what manufacturers can mandate their machine builders do.  There are only so many of them in world.  Assets are acquired based on their core productivity and not necessarily their connectivity.  If an asset can crank out higher quality widgets faster at a lower cost, no investor or buyer will care what the communications are.  They'll figure a way around this on their way to the bank.

Technology is not always adopted because it's the "best" technology.  At the end of the day, we're talking about people.  And people are motivated by much more than just technology.

I don't think any of the issue was with them, more that I am knew to Industrial Controls (I have 8+ years of embedded controls experience) and don't know the landscape forwards and backwards yet. I still find a lot of PLC/Industrial Controls development challenging in that it's difficult to get reliable, unbiased information about devices including pricing. It seems to be getting better and I hope to be able to send my business to manufacturers that are open about their products capabilities and costs.

Author: .dhess
Content:
Choosing Edge Computing Framework and Architecture
https://youtu.be/hGZpJBnGhjM

Takeaways: A "spectrum" of edge definitions. A commonality of wanting to extract the data as close to its point of origin as possible due to latency concerns. I liked how the decision to keep the data on site is due to keeping expenses down. The argument for On-Prem servers: Why should I spend money on expensive data pipelines, to expensive servers, so I can crunch my data far away, and pay to bring it back again.

Author: .dhess
Content:
5 Edge Computing Open Source Platforms - Date: Feb 26, 2020
https://youtu.be/TrZc9FVq8f8
My takeaways in my words: 00:29 Edge computing is a game changer for IOT.
01:10 EdgeX Foundry
01:40 Akraino Edge Stack. A Linux foundation project backed by Intel and AT&T: https://wiki.akraino.org/
development of Edge API, middle ware, and SDK's. Cross Cloud platform interoperability. Fullly integrated Edge blueprints. Strives to offer plug and play modular architecture, and low latency. Hide hardware differences behind software (sounds cool).

05:08 Arkranio deployment diagram.
05:25  EdgeX Foundry https://docs.edgexfoundry.org/1.2/getting-started/Ch-GettingStartedSDK/. Back by Linux foundation, vendor neutral. Promotes interoperable plug and play components. Devices services SDK download. Helps you avoid proprietary lock-in vendor strategies. 
08:26 Awesomely provides production ready DevKits
08:30 Home Edge Devices - backed by Samsung Electronics. https://opensource.samsung.com/projects.
09:13 Home Edge Architecture explained with diagram.
09:30 Encryption / decryption of the messaging protocol.
10:26 Project EVE (Edge Virtualization Engine)  Hardware assisted virtualization. https://www.lfedge.org/projects/eve/
10:50 EVE Architecture Diagram explained.
11:13 StarlingX A complete cloud infrastructure. https://www.starlingx.io/
11:38 StarlingX Architecture Diagram

Content:
What does "report by exception" mean for analog measurements?

For discreet (integer) values defining state of alarm (0 or 1) or state of valve (for example) {0, 1, 2, ...} (closed, moving, opened, ...) it is clear, publish data only after change.

Analog data (measurements) usually have jitter so that would mean sending data all the time even if the change is very small.

Should one implement a deadband (on smart sensor or in PLC if "dumb" sensors are used) to filter out the jitter and transmit only meaningfull data?

Content: @henning we wrote a standalone transmitter and use the exact same architecture David speaks of above.  S7-1200 --> Ignition (on the edge, not edge version) with Siemens driver --> Our Transmitter SPb to Broker in the Cloud (we wrote our own for optimization and to reduce costs over using CL module) The only cost for us was the Siemens driver on the edge with Ignition (which I think was $250 at the time).

Author: henning8936
Content: @Walker Reynolds I have no idea how the Ignition licensing works. Do I understand that correctly, that Ignition itself is free, if I run it on the edge device? Only the drivers and additional modules need to be licensed?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Correct -- Ignition is modular.  You can buy any module at all and when you license that module, it unlocks the 'Ignition Platform' which is the tag engine, scripting, etc.  So -- if you buy the Siemens Driver, you will get an Ignition license key that licenses just one module, the Siemens driver, but unlocks the 'Ignition Platform' which is tags, scripting, etc.  'Ignition Platform' is all of the base elements of Ignition -- you get those included with any module purchase.

Author: benveenema
Content:
There has been some discussion about IO-Link in this thread. You can find it by using the search in the upper right for "IO-link".

My thoughts are mixed. I think it's a step in the right direction towards smart sensors/devices and lends towards a more "distributed computing" model at the PLC/Edge level. However, the industry is not completely standardized in how they implement IO-Link so it isn't as "plug and play" as it could be. It is NOT yet, the USB of Industrial controls.

Having used other non-ethernet, sensor busses, like I2C, 1-wire and SPI, I don't see any major advantages that IO-Link has over them other than there are industrial blocks you can buy that implement it. IO-Link is slower and costs more.

That said, I continue to to use it as it is the best industrial, smart device, bus that I have found yet. I'm hoping that it gets better over time or someone brings I2C to the industrial world.

Author: dundo6741
Content:
How concerned should one be about time-synchronization of process data?

Is it good enough to rely on assumption that the time-stamp of when the data came in to UNS or time-series DB is approx. the time-stamp of when the data was sent from the edge?

Another approach would be to send time-stamp with every piece of data but then one has a problem of syncing RTCs of all those devices/PLCs.

The time diff between when the data was sent to when it was received/stored in the system should not be great but perhaps could be significant for ML?

Author: benveenema
Content:
I've never used CAN so I can't comment too much. My understanding is it essentially serial (RS232 or similar) with added features for reliability.

I've used SPI and I2C in embedded designs extensively. They are dead simple (simple != easy) protocols, SPI especially. SPI is essentially a shift register and fairly easily bit-banged (implemented in SW instead of HW) when needed. The simplicity of I2C and SPI make them blazing fast and cheap. Where they lack is reliability/redundancy.  You'll need to implement check-sums, timeouts, recalls yourself if you need.

I've yet to use either SPI or I2C in the industrial setting. I believe it could be done, and using an Industrial Arduino or RPi from someone like https://www.industrialshields.com/ is probably the way to go.  

That said, neither SPI or I2C is particularly Industrial hardened. They are typically low voltage protocols and thus could be susceptible to noise. There are some existing ICs that could bring I2C into the industrial world such as P82B96 (https://www.ti.com/lit/ds/symlink/p82b96.pdf) and PCA9615 (https://www.nxp.com/docs/en/data-sheet/PCA9615.pdf)

Hackaday has a great article about taking I2C over longer wires: https://hackaday.com/2017/02/08/taking-the-leap-off-board-an-introduction-to-i2c-over-long-wires/

I haven't done as much research on SPI over long distances.

The biggest advantage of I2C is its proliferation in smart phone and other consumer electronics. The extremely high volumes in this space have driven down sensor and chip costs to rock bottom.  For example, you can purchase a 9DOF IMU (3 axis Gryo, 3 axis Accelerometer, 3 axis magnetometer sensor) chip on a board and with source code for $17 https://www.sparkfun.com/products/15335. These aren't quite ready for industrial use, but a few bucks worth of plastic and some reliability circuits and you'd have an industrial ready product. Only problem, is almost no PLCs support I2C.

Author: benveenema
Content: I think I2C/SPI and maybe CAN could absolutely be used in an industrial setting and are perfect for the edge of the edge. They should be used in a device to PLC connection.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
As mentioned, IFM has IO-Link Masters with MQTT JSON.  Comtrol has IO-Link Masters with OPC-UA.

You can configure these with their standalone configuration software.  Unfortunately, you will need to parse the payloads to make use of the data.  You'll have to pull out the manual to follow the IODD.

You will most likely have a better experience interfacing the IO-Link Masters directly to a PLC over a fieldbus.  The sensor companies maintain PLC code libraries (e.g., AOIs, FBs) that decode the payloads into usable tags.  These are essentially like IO-Link drivers.  From here, you can publish into your software systems up the stack.  Even if you don't necessarily need a PLC for control, it might be worthwhile deploying one as a gateway.

Content: ISA-100 and WiHART are too heavy for an edge protocol. The technology is certainly mature enough, but would use it somewhere between control and edge. LoRa and BLE tend to be the most common. I have seen some Z-Wave and Zigbee, but these tend not to be used in manufacturing as they are better suited for home and building automation.

Author: jon.forbord
Content:
Regarding making a PLC ready for implementation to a UNS. Are there any benefits to switching from OPC DA to OPC UA? (MQTT is not available for these controllers, so it would have to be through the UNS gateway or similar to get MQTT). 
And are there benefits to restructuring the PLC data in a more organized way (top-down structure (e.g. Subsystem.SubSubsystem.Sensor.Actual ))? I have a PLC full of spaghetti data with a mix of flat/top-down/down-top/separated, and I'm wondering if I should take the time to restructure the data in the PLC before moving forward.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: There are benefits -- yes... but the value depends on the level of effort you have to put in.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Yes, OPC-DA should be avoided.  OPC-DA requires legacy Windows technology (i.e., DCOM) with security vulnerabilities and is all around more challenging to support.  It's not really routable and requires Windows dependencies.  OPC Classic (e.g., DA, HDA, AE) was created at a time before the world coalesced around the networking technologies (e.g., TCP/IP, UDP/IP) that make up the internet and today's networks.  OPC-UA has encryption and TCP for transport.  OPC-UA, for these reasons, is an unequivocal improvement on OPC Classic.

If you have OPC-DA today, take a moment to research whether the server is embedded into the controller and what other communications options are available.  Why are you using it?  You might be able to bypass OPC-DA all together.  And if you have legacy DA client apps, don't worry.  You can still use them with UA tunneling.

Most controllers will not have embedded support for "vertical" protocols such as OPC-DA, OPC-UA or MQTT.  If they do, there is a good chance it's a "bolted-on" gateway module anyway.  Even when controllers support it, adoption is a completely different story.  The machine builders and system integrators are recycling old designs.  And end users, in many cases, could care less.  I digress.

Most controllers will have their own native ethernet-based protocol.  These are often adopted from the "horizontal" fieldbus technology they support.  Examples:  Allen-Bradley (EtherNet/IP), Siemens (S7 Messaging), Fanuc Robot (GE-SRTP), Fanuc CNC (FOCAS), Mitsubishi (MELSEC), Schneider (Modbus TCP), Omron (FINS or EtherNet/IP).  Most of these protocols are client/server (aka poll-and-response), but some do have implementations for unsolicited messaging (aka "fire-and-forget" or "report-by-exception").

From here, you would leverage a gateway to convert from the native protocol to OPC-UA or even directly to MQTT.  Kepware is a popular option.  Leveraging a native driver in Ignition or Factory Studio is also an option.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
If I understand the UNS Gateway correctly, it's purpose is to adapt existing OPC-UA servers into MQTT for modeling a UNS.  Many organizations already have OPC-UA servers and clients in place.  Also, there exist OPC-UA server gateways with a wide-selection of native drivers.  The UNS Gateway greatly reduces the engineering effort getting these tags into the UNS.  Gleaning from conversations here, it's basically the Kepware IoT Gateway / MQTT Client that @Walker Reynolds would have built.

But, if there is not an existing OPC-UA infrastructure to leverage, the UNS Gateway may not necessarily optimal.  It might be beneficial to look beyond OPC (classic or UA) and investigate a gateway/driver that works with the native protocols.  It all depends on the PLCs and native protocols you have.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: The effort would be quite substantial, but the benefits would also be for programming/development and SCADA implementation, so if there are benefits with respect to UNS, it would add even more value to the effort.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: We already have a full opc-da infrastructure, with plc->hmi->local server->central server, with opc da at all connections. Not sure why DA was the design choice to begin with. I think your digress is exactly on point here. All our PLCs come with UA server embedded, although one of them had apparently a suboptimal adoption of it until a firmware release last year.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Ah, interesting.  What PLCs and HMIs are you using?

One option could be a hybrid approach of standing up a new infrastructure in parallel to the legacy one.  The new infrastructure would leverage the embedded OPC-UA or the PLC's native protocol with a gateway.  This infrastructure would connect your PLCs to the UNS.  Over time, you could let the legacy OPC-DA infrastructure die off by slowing migrating your clients (e.g., HMI, apps) off of it.

You mentioned OPC-DA is being used with the HMIs.  I'm assuming your using some sort of PC-based HMIs.  Ignition Edge might be a perfect fit.  This could serve as your PLC connection, HMI, and MQTT gateway all-in-one.

Author: jon.forbord
Content:
We‚Äôre using S7-1515 and Bosch Rexroth NC-controller. Interesting option to leave the legacy stuff in parallel to the new infrastructure with mqtt/opc UA for UNS. It is actually a very good idea, as it would keep the ‚Äúlet‚Äôs not change what works‚Äù-people happy. Would have to check network load with both active though. 

Using a HMI that is more or less tied to the NC controller, not really considering changing it out. Would rather develop the Scada as an HMI for machine control and keep the existing one for the NC stuff and service controls.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
If the machine has a well-designed HMI program, it's possible to interface with the PLC as-is.  But, most HMI programs are not all that informative.  Garbage in, garbage out.

I highly recommend building out an interface in your PLC program.  What I've found is that when one tries co-exist with existing programs, it does not scale well.   Most PLC programmers take a "MVP" approach.  They build a minimally viable product and make assumptions how the data will be consumed.  It's not fun "shoe horning" objects designed for the field (by a short-sighted programmer) into upper-level systems.  You will invariably be deriving things and running into limitations.  When you're building apps and infrastructure, you don't want to be bogged down by data quality issues.

The best practice I've seen is to create a separate sub routine and map everything into a clean structure (e.g., UDT).  First and foremost, there are performance benefits to this.  Second, it's organized and easier to consume.  Third, it makes the PLC program and its programmer(s) "aware" of what it's connected to.  As logic is maintained over time, there will be a mindset of maintaining the interface as well.

One interesting side-effect of this is that the initially skeptical/weary OT personnel come around to appreciating these interfaces.  The very same short-sighted programmers start to want to use this interface in their machine-level HMI.  They become more object-oriented and start intelligently abstracting and re-using logic.  They break bad habits without feeling like they're being pushed.

I recognize that this is not always possible or practical.  Sometimes you have to model outside the PLC.  Some PLCs, even newer ones, still have register / fixed addressing based memory tables.  They don't have namable tags or structures.  Or, the machine's logic might be locked out by the OEM.  In this instance, try to follow the same principles of organizing and making the data ready for consumption.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I had a feeling there was some Siemens involved.  It sounds like the Bosch-Rexroth NCs are "married" to their HMIs.  Despite using standard protocol (OPC-DA), it's not really replaceable implementation.

I totally get it.  I'm used to these environments.  Despite my fondness for Ignition Edge as a concept, it's not really practical for HMIs on advanced machinery like CNCs.  The applications are too complex and tailored to re-engineer.  Ignition Edge is really limited to supervisory-level HMI in these environments.  It's a great platform, but it's too different from the platform that machines are built on to replace anything.  The HMIs are staying.

I have not used the native OPC-UA servers embedded on the S7 PLCs.  I've only used the native S7 messaging protocol with Kepware.  I like the automatic tag generation and ability to add into an existing OPC-UA server's name space.  It might be worth doing a shoot-out on which is easier to deploy/maintain and their performance.  I have seen some embedded OPC-UA servers that require you to "select" which tags to host rather than browse remotely.  Sometimes there are limitations on tag counts.  Additionally, OPC-UA's security is another consideration.

(
Side-bar:
It's interesting that your org ended up with S7s and Bosch-Rexroth NC.  If S7 was the preferred platform, why not use SINUMERIK?  Is the Rexroth used for some sort of hydraulic control?

S7s + Bosch-Rexroth CNC?  Sounds like Ford?
)

Author: benveenema
Content: My gut feeling is that IIoT is going to push more sophisticated software and hardware to the industrial edge (it's been on the embedded edge for decades). The IEC61131-3 (Ladder, FBD, ST) languages will need to be adapted or abandoned in favor of more powerful languages like C/C++, Rust or maybe even something like CircuitPython.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Agreed.  Automation is still in the dark ages compared to the embedded world.

It will be interesting to see how the labor market and employers adopt to this.  Right now, at least in the US, manufacturers struggle to find and train personnel to program even basic ladder.  Most could not handle structured text or more advanced IEC61131-3 concepts.  Unfortunately, I suspect most business owners will close their doors before they confront this.  There is a storm coming.

Author: benveenema
Content:
Yes. There will need to be some give and take. 

1. There's a whole lot of young professionals and kids who's first introduction to automation is Arduino. They don't know it, but they're writing C++! When they come into the Industrial Automation space they're going to be turned off by the restrictive IEC61131-3 languages.

2. We need to forget/adjust the concept that manufacturers *should* be accessing the programs of industrial controllers. Programs should be fully tested, including edge cases right from the Machine Builder. Maintenance should *never* need to see the program itself to diagnose faults in the machine. We *can* build this into the program itself and using good OOP practices, it won't be much overhead by the Machine Builders to do. Manufacturers who want to re-program or develop their own machines will need to learn the more powerful languages if they want to leverage the full potential of IIoT

3. Sensor/Device manufacturers will need to start providing good, working, open-source libraries for all their equipment. This will aid towards #2 and build a standard toolset that Machine Builders can leverage and emulate.

Manufacturers will always deal with legacy (last week I was debugging a Visual Basic coded HMI that was last programmed pre Y2K!), it's the nature of the capital intensive business. But we need to push the new machines to use the new tech.

Author: benveenema
Content: 4. We need to make manufacturing sexy to software engineers. Some of the most exciting opportunities in ML and AI are in manufacturing. Manufacturers need to advertise this start to recruit the software engineers. There's a boatload of them graduating every year, and not all of them need to work in Silicon Valley creating the next lame web app.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Interesting views Ben. I was writing a long reply here, but I think I was able to boil it down to: IEC61131-3 languages might still have a place in the future, but I think PLCs and industrial controls will (continue) to expand the toolbelt of programming languages that are supported by industrial controllers. By OOP you mean Object Oriented Programming? There exist PLCs that are OOP. We have those.

Author: benveenema
Content: Yes, Object Oriented Programming. I have used ST within Codesys to do OOP. It works pretty well, but is still lacking a few features, like the ability to pass an object to a function, to be full blown OOP. I also think there's a lack of general acceptance/use of OOP practices. There seems to be some doubt that they are actually beneficial in a lot of minds. To be fair, embedded firmware suffers from some of the same throughts. There's still a lot of people who don't want to adopt C++ over C  because it's "dangerous" in that it allows a programmer to create programs that are bloated and can lead to difficult to diagnose issues like memory fragmentation.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Sigmatek have full blown OOP PLCs to my knowledge, not the IEC-61131-3 semi-OOP. I've heard many talks on the problems with OOP, like how inheritance leads eventually to problems, so you should use composition over inheritance. I'm not sure it applies to the comparatively small programs most PLCs are.

Author: MEE6#4876

Author: dundo6741
Content:
I don't have much experience with PLCs but I do with MCUs and general programming. I guess problems with higher level languages and OOP in PLCs and MCUs are limitations and demands of those platforms.
They typically have much less RAM than PCs and have demand that cycle time is both short and predictable, no much jitter.
When you talk about OOP you typically assume dynamic memory allocation and, nowadays, garbage collection like in Java, Python, .NET, ...
Both of that goes against the limitations mentioned above.

Author: benveenema
Content:
OOP doesn't have to use dynamic memory. But processing and memory is cheap these days.

When we're building an embedded system and we need a chip BOM cost in the $1-$5 dollar range, it makes sense to optimize, avoid languages with garbage collectors and dynamic memory.

When we're building an industrial machine and a "cheap" PLC is $200+ dollars, I think we can afford to throw a bit more processor and RAM at it.

I agree with @Jon Forbord JonF as well that the more advanced OOP features like inheritence, and dynamic memory are problematic and I tend to avoid them altogether or use them sparingly in embedded or industrial automation programs. What OOP offers is code re-usability. It's amazing how quickly one can build a solid, reliable machine program when they can utilize OOP libraries for there sensor, devices and systems and only worry about the glue code and unique logic. It's DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) on steriods.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: And inheritance is like the main OOP aspect we got with IEC 61131-3 üòÖ

Author: zackscriven
Content: Hey John! It has yet to be fully released. We are working on it.

Author: benveenema
Content: Lol. Inheritance can be useful. You just have to be really careful about how much of it you use when we're talking about machines that a high reliability factor. I think OOP features can become a recipe for spaghetti code with greener coders. But that doesn't mean we shouldn't use it at all.

Author: dundo6741
Content:
I remember reading about Bjarne Stroustrup and the challenges he and his team faced when developing software for JSF (Joint Strike Fighter).
It was decided to use C++ but with no "smart pointers", no memory allocation after initialization of objects etc.
There apparently is a standard for C++ in automotive and airplane industry and guidelines for Embedded C++.

https://www.electronicdesign.com/technologies/dev-tools/article/21800991/guidelines-take-the-garbage-out-of-embedded-c

Content: Does anyone know a vision sensor/camera that could count pieces? It could send a 24V signal for every part or have this counter available on a protocol.

Content: How fast?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
How big are the pieces?
  
Are you trying to count them in a single-piece-flow?  Or, are there multiple pieces that need to be counted within a field of view?

Is there specific criteria required to count a piece (e.g., feature detection, shape matching)?  Or, is it simply any object that moves through a to a designated space (e.g., conveyor, fixture, assembly line)?

Here are some potential options that might help frame the discussion.  All of these could transmit your count to a controller via 24VDC, IO-Link, or an Ethernet-based fieldbus protocol.

Ring Sensors
https://www.ifm.com/us/en/category/010/010_010/010_010_080#!/S/BD/DM/1/D/0/F/0/T/24

Inductive Sensors
https://www.ifm.com/us/en/category/010/010_010/010_010_025#!/S/BD/DM/1/D/0/F/0/T/24

Photoelectric Sensors
https://www.ifm.com/us/en/category/010/010_050/010_050_160#!/S/BD/DM/1/D/0/F/0/T/24

Vision Sensors (with embedded processing)
https://www.ifm.com/us/en/category/020/020_010
https://www.teledynedalsa.com/en/products/imaging/smart-cameras/
https://www.keyence.com/products/vision/vision-sys/cv-x100/
https://www.cognex.com/products/deep-learning/in-sight-d900

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
My earlier post was based on a "vision-in-a-box" approach that can be easily dropped into an automation environment.  These are cameras with an accompanied controller that can be deployed similar to the way an industrial sensor is.  These work fairly well for basic pattern detection applications.  If you need to embed this into a product and you have the engineering resources, this approach can be more costly at scale.  If you're looking to go PC-based open architecture as other have mentioned, here's what I've seen work.

OpenCV is the most popular open source vision library by far.  It's very powerful and is constantly innovated.  It's used on everything from autonomous motion to surveillance to automation.  I've even seen it in safety applications for robotics.

SimpleCV is an open source vision library.  Because of the popularity of Ignition and Factory Studio in this community, Python is somewhat well-known here.  SimpleCV is a simplified python-based OpenCV wrapper.  It works pretty well for pattern detection in automation applications.

MVTec Halcon is a commercial vision package.  It's designed for industry.  It has its own IDE, massive vision library, extensive driver support, supports industrial protocols, and works with multiple languages (e.g., C, C++, .NET).  Support for Python was recently introduced.

Cognex VisionPro is another commercial package.  While not as full featured and economical, it's easier to learn than Halcon and much more popular in the US.  It has a .NET interface.

Vision Packages
http://simplecv.org/
https://www.mvtec.com/products/halcon
https://www.mvtec.com/products/merlic
https://www.cognex.com/products/machine-vision/vision-software/visionpro-software

General Purpose GigE Cameras
https://www.baslerweb.com/en/products/cameras/area-scan-cameras/ace2/a2a1920-160umbas/
https://www.teledynedalsa.com/en/products/imaging/cameras/genie-nano-1gige/

Author: mparris
Content:
What is everyone's thoughts on options (brand and models) for general purpose edge devices?

I know there are specialized devices that do Edge Gateway functions or Edge Machine Learning Runtime or data modeling.

I'm thinking the approach should be a general purpose device with a docker interface as the edge platform. This would keep the hardware agnostic to specific IIoT platforms or functions. For example, start with a gateway container to excuse the data, then when ready, deploy a Machine Learning container next to your gateway container.

Thinking that machine builders would include one of these devices in equipment, allowing for future growth.

Is anyone going this route and what devices are you finding useful? Of course, any industrial PC running Ubuntu Server would do the trick, but am curious if there are similar devices that give you a docker interface out of the box?

Author: richard44160
Content: I think that Siemens IOT2050 is a perfect candidate for that purpose. Using it's Debian github image or your own customised, it can handle docker apps. You have also all edge appliance running Ubuntu or other linux like Dell Edge gateway 3100. And you're right, it's definitively an option that should be proposed by any OEM vendor with at least a local UNS ready to publish to any MQTT broker via Sparkblug B !

Author: benveenema
Content: What about Raspberry Pi or any other SBC for that matter? This sure has a list of affordable SBCs with both ARM and x86 architectures https://m.all3dp.com/2/single-board-computer-x86-sbc/

Author: mparris
Content:
Thanks Ben. I'm thinking more of an out of the box solution to abstract the hardware device to simply an interface for docker containers. It would allow visibility of the health of the devices from a single location and allow deployment of docker containers however is needed.

Once this is in place, you can apply any IIoT platform on top of it, mix-and-match, etc.

the minimum tech requiremeby for any IIoT Edge Application would be ability to run within a docker container. Fortunately, this isn't that big of a hurdle as demonstrated by Ignition and HighByte.

The closest I've been able to find is Balena OS https://www.balena.io/ which can be deployed to any number of SBC or even generic x64 PCs.

Next I've found is Hilscher netField platform https://netfield.io/os   and Cisco iOx (=iOS + Linux) platform . The downside of each of these is that you're are locked into whatever hardware devices they can offer.

Author: richard44160
Content: Raspbery Pi or other SBC are very attractive but they don't comply with industrial requirements.
