Author: mparris
Content:
I spoke to the Hilscher USA netIoT team today. Their gateways includes a chipset that talk profinet and Ethernet IP naitively.

Their gateways are basically docker platforms and containers are available to publish fieldbus to MQTT SparkplugB using NodeRed interface.  They have a netfield platform to help manage all the edge gateways and containers from a single webpage.

The interesting tidbit was that Mr. Hanz Hilscher was introduced to Nipper and Clark co-creators of MQTT. Hilscher is now using MQTT to manage their internal communications bus on these gateways!

Author: luisn8316
Content: Hello everybody, I'm just jumping into this conversation - but it seems like there seems to be some confusion between "Edge computer" and "Edge gateway" - can we please set the record straight as to what the differences are? I often see people refer to "edge" when all the device is doing is converting from one protocol to something commonly found in IIOT architectures, like MQTT..

Author: richard44160
Content: @Andy I did not recommend specifically devices based on Pi Compute module but industrial grade devices(you can now boot to a SSD on USB3  instead of the SDcard on the Raspberry Pi 4). @dundo The life of the SDcard depends also on the application(low or high demand on the SDcard). @LuisN "edge computer" will be more high demand than "edge gateways".

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Edge gateway transforms data

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Edge computer runs software

Author: richard44160
Content: For me, it is one of @Walker Reynolds rule. For IIOT hardware, you should be technology driven and not solution driven :  fanless, low power, high availibility industrial grade mini-computers are technologies; Raspberry Pi4, Arduino, ESP32 are solutions !

Author: mparris
Content:
Based on what I have gathered, "edge" is where devices begin to merge into the industrial internet of things (IIoT) architecture. The IIoT space should be a fabric (Network infrastructure and application layer) to seamlessly get you from one place to another. All the non-native applications could be thought of being on the edge, but traditionally it's only been thought of at the levels closest to manufacturing.

So an edge device is something that can directly communicate in the IIoT ecosystem. As @Walker Reynolds#8594 stated, a gateway typically does data pass-through (translation from I've protocol to another). Edge Compute is ingesting data and providing new data at that level, which saves bandwidth and allows processes to react quicker with the reduced latency. Think Machine Learning inference algorithms here.

Author: mparris
Content:
My goal for the edge is to have a software platform that can live on any hardware device (ARM, x64, massive 40-core server with 3 nvidia tesla cards) and they all can receive docker containers, each of which would do a gateway function, data modeling function, machine learning inference, or even machine learning training). The application would drive the selection power of the hardware device and it would be added as another edge node to be managed from a single dashboard.

All these edge devices are a dime-a-dozen, but no one had created a platform to unify the management of them and be agnostic to the hardware. Why a company wants to complete in both the hardware AND software edge space doesn't make any sense. Hardware will come and go and the market already exists. We need a good software platform.

Author: mparris

Author: luisn8316
Content: I agree 100%. That is what I envision "edge computing" to be. So when you have multiple "edge computers" on the factory floor (for example on several machines), how is this "software" centrally managed across all edge computers? For example, if you have an edge device that is doing machine learning and optimization for a specific equipment, x50 lines of this equipment - how do you update the software that is running on each of those edge devices from a central point? Are there any examples of this happening in the field today?

Author: mparris
Content:
The best I have been able to locate is Balena (hardware agnostic) and Hilscher netField (specific hardware).

These are platforms to manage the devices themselves (health monitor, loading applications, etc). Then whatever applications are running on the edge devices are managed through those individual platforms, for example Ignition Edge, HighByte, Sorba IoT, etc.

Author: mparris
Content: To clarify, I have not used either of these edge platforms, but from the face of it look to fulfill what I'm looking for

Author: youri.regnaud
Content: Has anyone ever had the opportunity to connect CNC machines equipped with CNC control from Heidenhaim?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
No, but I have with many Fanuc and Siemens-based CNCs. This is typically accomplished with Kepware‚Äôs driver suite.

Unfortunately, Kepware does not have a driver with documented support explicitly for Heidenhain. Depending on the protocol of your machine(s), there might be a driver with unofficial support.

Reach out to your distributor or Heidenhain about connectivity options. Figure out what native communication protocol Heidenhain speaks. It might be proprietary to them. If the asset is really old, it even be some sort of serial connection typically used for Direct Numerical Control (DNC). Inform them that you‚Äôre looking for a communication module (or gateway) that will enable the asset to interface with MQTT, OPC-UA, or possibly MTConnect.

If they tell you they have their own data collection software they‚Äôd like to sell you, politely ask them your original question again. This software may have some quick value, but it likely won‚Äôt work with everything else in your business that you may want to connect. I‚Äôm sure you have more that just Heidenhain products.  Proceed with caution.  Try to avoid creating new data silos.

After a quick google search, there appears to be third party products dedicated to Heidenhain connectivity. This one appears to have MQTT, OPC, and SQL connection options.
https://www.opc-router.com/7_1-heidenhain_en/

It looks Heidenhain offers their own OPC-UA server. I would investigate if this is compatible with your machine(s).
https://www.heidenhain.de/de_EN/products/cnc-controls/connected-machining/

Author: mparris
Content: I wanted to share a product I've been using over the past year:Matrikon Dispatch Data Broker. https://www.matrikonopc.com/opc-ua/matrikon-data-broker.aspx

Author: mparris
Content:
It has the following features, which could be of interest to those in the OPC-UA universe:
*federates OPC-UA data from servers, so multiple clients getting the same data don't create multiple connections to the original server(saves connections on low-power OPC-UA servers)
*allows method pass-through: you can connect to dispatch and call a method on the server as if you were directly connected
*allows reverse connection, which can transverse firewalls

They are working on the MQTT side and I'm fairly confident they will be moving the SparkplugB route.  I discussed with the product manager that their product could be a great product to bridge the traditional OPC-UA users to interfacing with IIoT ecosystems.

Author: mparris
Content: I've been working with the team over the past year providing use cases and testing. It's not lost on me (or them!) how big the elephant they are trying to eat is, but if anyone can operationalize the theory of OPC-UA, I'm sure Matrikon will do it.

Author: matthijsprent
Content: Some small practical issue, I am looking how to connect a few Siemens S7-300 PLC's to an UNS. The CP343 module looks like the obvious choice for connecting the PLC to industrial ethernet but are there better options that I should consider?

Author: y_u_no_python
Content:
@MatthijsPrent, 

What is the goal of the connection?

The CP343 provides an Industrial Ethernet endpoint to allow programming and communication, or a Profinet IO Communication Master for use with Profinet Devices. 

Normally I have used an OPC server of some kind to pull data over IE. (Kepware, WW SP, Ignition, etc)

I have used Ignition to get data from the S73xx-PN with embedded Profinet port (No CP343 needed)

Author: luisn8316
Content:
S7-300 is at the end of lifecycle. So connecting to UNS via OPC or MQTT was not considered at the time of development 15+ years ago. Depending on the desired protocol, you could use the method @Y_U_NO_Python? mentioned by using the SCADA as a gateway to the UNS, or if you choose to add a module to the backplane the CP343 "COULD" work, but would need some programming/setup in Step 7 (engineering software for the S7-300 PLC). This type of changes would cause the processor to stop and therefore be careful that this does not have any negative effects to your production. 

If you still want a Siemens-based solution without the need to modify your S7-300 configuration and plan downtime, you could use the "SIMATIC CloudConnect" CC712 or CC716 (depending on how many S7 devices and protocol) device as an IoT gateway. This uses an integrated web server that can be used to configure the device, so you don't have to go into Step 7 ot modify the project.

Author: luisn8316
Content: http://www.siemens.com/cloudconnect

Author: luisn8316
Content: Or you could use a low-cost S7-1200 PLC as a "IoT gateway", but that would also require configuring the S7-1200 in Step7 (TIA Portal)...

Author: zackscriven
Content: Pinned a message.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I typically use Kepware's drivers to pull data out of S7-300 and similar SINUMERIK controllers.  Fortunately, I've never encountered one without ethernet.  This must be an older controller.

CP343 seems like a sensible option.  If you can get the native S7 messaging protocol ("RFC1006") coming off the PLC as this does, you will have a ton of connectivity options.  There exist many gateways and platforms that natively support this protocol.  Keep in mind that S7 is a "polling" protocol.  If you need publish/subscribe architecture, you'll want an MQTT gateway to reside at or near the edge.

As Taylor mentioned, it would be helpful to learn more about your goals.  There are a lot of ways to connect to an S7.  Here are a few potential options:

[S7-300] < S7 protocol > [KepServerEx] < OPC-UA > [HighByte] <MQTT SpB> [MQTT Broker]
[S7-300] < S7 protocol > [KepServerEx] < MQTT > [MQTT Broker]
[S7-300] < S7 protocol -or- PROFIBUS > [CloudConnect7] < MQTT > [MQTT Broker]
[S7-300] < S7 protocol > [Ignition]
[S7-300] < S7 protocol > [FactoryStudio]

These options mostly assume you will be using the S7 protocol.  It's also possible to get access to the controller's data via the fieldbus (e.g., PROFIBUS, PROFINET).  Similar to the S7 protocol, there exist gateways for this.  Depending on your environment and the data you're looking move, this can work quite well.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @js, you just advanced to level 5!

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Here's a nice Siemens article about connecting legacy and current generation S7 controllers to MQTT infrastructure:
https://cache.industry.siemens.com/dl/files/282/109772282/att_1010991/v2/109772282_CloudConnect_MQTT_DOC_V10_en.pdf

Author: matthijsprent
bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
The Siemens S7 drivers in Ignition and Factory Studio are TCP/IP based.  They'll require the S7-300 to have an Ethernet module on the backplane (e.g., CP343) or gateway on the fieldbus (Helmholz NETLink Pro, IBH Link S7++, CloudConnect 7).

[S7-300] < backplane > [CP343] < S7 protocol > [...]
[S7-300] < backplane > [CP343] < S7 protocol > [CloudConnect 7] < MQTT or OPC-UA > [...]
[S7-300] < backplane > [CP343] < S7 protocol > [KepServerEx] < MQTT or OPC-UA > [...]
[S7-300] < backplane > [CP343] < S7 protocol > [Ignition -or- Factory Studio]
[S7-300] < PROFIBUS> [Helmholz NETLink Pro] < S7 protocol > [...]
[S7-300] < PROFIBUS> [IBH Link S7++] < S7 protocol > [...]
[S7-300] < PROFIBUS> [CloudConnect 7] < MQTT or OPC-UA > [...]
[S7-300] < PROFIBUS> [HMS Anybus Edge Gateway] < MQTT or OPC-UA > [...]

I would say the best bet is probably a CP343.  This gets you direct on the backplane and enables you interact with the processor in the most "pure" way.  It also opens up the broadest set of driver and gateway options available.

The profibus gateways (e.g., Helmholz, IBH, HMS) can be cost-effective and viable alternatives.  Some have IoT protocol support (e.g., MQTT, OPC-UA) which would enable you to bypass S7 protocol all together.

Here are some useful questions to ask internally:

Could anything else make use of the CP343?  Do you need to program the S7 over the LAN?

Is the PROFIBUS interface currently in use?  Would it be an issue adding a gateway onto the existing network?

What kind of asset is it and where is it?  Is it in a factory with ample network resources or is it somewhere remote?

Where do you plan to host the software communicating with this asset?

Do you have space on the backplane of the S7-300 for a CP343?

Author: marioishikawa

We plan to host the software on the company servers that are in the same building but on a different floor. (I would guess at most 200m distance). Hosting it in the cloud could also be an option that I consider. This is unclear at the moment but I have the freedom to choose what I think is best.

Yes, we have space for a CP343 at the backplane.

Thanks!

Content:
I have a question about the Wago PFC100/PFC200 series and PLCnext from Phoenix Contact: 
As I understand it, both PLC platforms offer the integration of external code through libraries written in high-level languages.

Author: rhuisken
Content: I can only speak to my experience with PLCnext. There are many ways to use C#/C++ code with PLCnext so I will only mention use cases for when used inside the IEC61131 real-time environment. PLCnext Engineer enables you to use C++ code as a complete program. Data is exchanged with the IEC61131 environment through IN/OUT ports. C# is handled a little differently as it cannot be used as a complete program but rather as a Function called by IEC61131 program. On the C# side, in the real-time environment, know that you are limited by what is included in the ECLR runtime.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Nice.  There is nothing wrong with having options.  I had a feeling Siemens would not make those legacy ethernet modules economical.  It's almost to a level where you could justify upgrading the processor.  

A few years ago, my colleagues were in a similar situation with AB SLC processors.  They were able to find a bunch of second-hand, higher-end processors with Ethernet.  It ended up being more economical and performant than using a serial gateway.  This enabled connectivity and bought time for the assets to be modernized.

While the acquisition cost of those third-party gateways is appealing, there may be some hidden engineering or performance costs.  In my experience, not all gateways support native memory addressing over the serial connection (e.g., poll bit with address M36.1).  Generally, with fieldbuses, the relevant tags must by "mapped" into a contiguous block within the memory.  The gateway will not see this as a natively addressed tag, but a mere sequence of bytes on the fieldbus.  The gateway will need the payload defined.  Additionally, depending on how much data is being moved, there might be performance constraints.

If you know exactly what memory in the PLC you're after, it's not a big deal.  If you're less sure and need to be agile, this can add some friction getting access to data and adapting to changes.

Different scenarios:
1)  Controller has embedded support of an IIoT protocol (e.g., MQTT, OPC-UA).  No gateway required.
2)  Controller supports addressing, browsing, and auto tag generation over its native protocol.  Gateway required, but easy setup.
3)  Controller supports addressing over its native protocol.  Requires gateway and knowledge of PLC's "namespace".
4)  Controller supports moving data over a field protocol.  Requires gateway, knowledge of PLC's "namespace", and new logic for all data consumed.

Order of preference:  1 > 2 > 3 > 4.  In practice, all will benefit from new logic.  But, the later scenarios will be more work.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
For everyone currently exploring the PLCNext and others edge devices (e.g., Groov, EPIC, EZRack), could you share your experiences on their automation capabilities?  How is the development environment?  Beyond I/O, what else in the field can interface with?  Can they handle safety and motion?

It appears that the next-gen controllers have great connectivity and economics but don't necessarily handle all automation disciplines.  Even with connectivity tradeoffs, there are significant benefits of leveraging multi-discipline controllers (e.g., i/o, safety, motion, field communications, alarms, CNC, robotics).  All around, it's a much more flexible architecture.  It can accommodate changes.  It keeps the data in one place.  It's easy to integrate "vertically" (machine-to-software) as well as "horizontally" (machine-to-machine).

After standardizing on multi-discipline controllers, I can't really imagine going back.  It's not ideal to consume data from assets with disparate controllers exchanging discrete i/o that are barely aware of each other.  It's a nightmare to construct IIoT architecture around this.  It's so much easier to have one "clean" control scheme orchestrating everything.  For these reasons and others, we've standardized around offerings from the traditional players (e.g., Rockwell, Siemens, Fanuc).  Fortunately, with Kepware's drivers, connectivity has not been a major problem.

Is anyone else encountering this when they explore these newer IIoT-friendly edge devices?

Author: benveenema
Content:
I've been working with Particle devices for years. All the way back to when they were called "Spark". They have several generations of devices now that support both WiFi and Cellular data connects. I am maybe 5% worried about them going bankrupt (I'm probably 5% worried about anyone going bankrupt...). This is a company that's stuck around for a while, made mistakes and recovered (Particle Mesh) and has been committed to open source the entire time.

They are geared towards consumer, and stand-alone sensor/system IoT. They do some things around the IIoT space but I don't think it's a main target for them. They *do* try to push you towards their cloud/console, which is a really great console for fleet management if you want to build a product line on their platform. Not so great for an end user using a UNS.

That said, they're development system is 100% open source (cloud is closed source) so even if they go bankrupt, your devices can still be rescued, just swap in a different SIM, they have a fantastic community on their forums and tons of libraries. I've probably open sources a dozen or so myself for interfacing with various sensors. There's even an MQTT library https://github.com/hirotakaster/MQTT/blob/master/README.md although I don't think it supports Sparkplug B.

Author: richard44160
Content: In a PLC, Ladder language is not the native language. The native language is the instruction code for the micro-processor (more or less like the IL language on Siemens PLC). So when you translate your example into IL, you will endup with this :

Author: richard44160
Content: You see that there is one more instruction in the second case so it's a little slower. By the way, in pure logic, there is no addition value to use the second option. And it will not impact the way that the result of the logic will be send to the physical outputs. As the calculated value is sent to all physical outputs at the and of the execution cycle in one shot to ensure synchronicity between all outputs. This is the default way. You can have more advanced PLC when you can configure different update times; per IO module for instance.

Author: zackscriven
Content: A question we have been getting often: Why use OPC-UA at all if your edge device supports MQTT? Even in a plant and networked environment. What are your thoughts @MParris

Author: mparris
Content:
I've heard the same question: What are we missing by not using OPC-UA.

The things Iike about OPC-UA are the idea of the companion specs.  They have more than 29 (last time I counted).  The two that stuck out to me were AutoID (barcode, RFID, OCR, etc), and Machine Vision. The analogy of a companion spec is like a device driver on a computer.  There used to be a time when the comptuer didn't know how to handle a mouse connected by comm-port.  Now, every operating system understands the companion spec of the USBmouse: left, right, middle clicks, wheel, and 2D movement.  Of course, there are companies that expand this companion spec to add extra buttons, or more axis for games, and those then require proprietary drivers, but the base function of all mice work the same no matter the vendor.

As a developer of applications, we would benefit from these OPC-UA companion specs, where all my application needs to know about the device is the IPaddress and it already has the AutoID driver built in, so it's plug and play (plug-and-work for the Germans lol).  Now, my application is immune to vendor lock (presuming multiple vendors support the standard).  AutoID is the best case I've seen of market adoption of a companion spec.  Turck, Siemens, SICK have products meeting this.

SparkplugB is really a basic companion spec on transferring data. It really doesn't solve the problem of how you model a piece of equipment.  If Sparkplug started releasing standards on types of SparkplugTemplates, that would help.  Then, vendors can include templates out of the box, which would put less strain on integrators to create the model in applications like HighByte Intelligence Hub.

Author: mparris
Content:
I also like in OPC-UA that I can browse methods by connecting to a UA Server.  If an application is exposing methods to allow a client to manipulate it, it becomes intuitive for the human.  The parameters of the methods are advertised and can include descriptions of what is expected.  Without much up-front knowledge, it's possible to command an application that is transparent.

SparkplugB doesn't have a good solution for this. Again, it's relying on the developers to bake in what the possible commands are; there isn't a standard way to browse that and then make use of it.  It's also a challenge if multiple devices are calling the same method, and the Sparkplug topic is common betweeen them where the two clients are subscribed to the same response topic.  There's ways around this, but it would be nice for Sparkplug to standardize this to keep the market from going in many different directions.

Author: jon.forbord
Content:
Got an offer for Versiondog one year back, around 20 000$ + 15% yearly for : - Includes all SmartCompares (without PCS7)
- 25 named users
- Automatic upload and compare (max. 100 upload jobs)
- UserClient, AdminClient, EasyClient, BackupClient, ReportClient, WebClient
- Max. 300 components
Never tried it, but if you're looking for SVN-type compare for PLCs it's in the ballpark. Don't know if it's open architecture. It can compare excel documents and a lot of other standard document formats as well.

Author: benveenema
Content: Ouch! That's a lot of dough for a VCS when compared to really great, free VCS like git... I know git isn't great at non-text based files still.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Mhm, but you're paying for the PLC code comparison capability. SVN can't display that in a way that makes sense for PLC, or even if you're lucky that the plc code is in an open xml-type schema, it's very hard to read the code from those schemas. That's the price of the "full throttle" though. It's lowest range is 10 000$.

Author: benveenema
Content:
They are certainly solving a problem in that graphical, closed ecosystem programming languages are really hard for a traditional VCS to work with. I completely understand the time and effort required to create something like versiondog and I believe they deserve to be well compensated for their effort.

The cost is a symptom of the current industrial controls paradigms closed nature. And it shows why adoption of good software engineering practices like VCS, test driven development and continuous integration is little used to non-existent in this space. 

Every time I get pitched a new PLC, I ask if they have VCS and I typically get a response like "Just use  File->Save-As"

Author: y_u_no_python
Content:
@AndyR , @Ben Veenema 

Edit: I just realized @Paulo Vitor already put a better link, showing supported devices üò¨ 

I have used both MDT and AB AssetCentre.

I like asset center, but like most rockwell products, the licensing got out of control.

I used MDT Autosave while working on contract at GM for years and it worked awesome. It uses Server - Client (each programming computer needs the client installed to monitor changes)

It supports: (this list is not exhaustive, I am sure there are some that I am missing)
- Robots (Fanuc,ABB,etc) 
- PLC's (AllenBradley, Seimens, etc)
- HMIs (AllenBradley, Seimens, etc)
 
It had scheduled intervals to reach into the PLC and copy the program. Autosave compares and records the new most recent version (if a non-autosave user makes changes).

When you want to open a version, Autosave even opens the respective launcher. It monitors the running program editor and if you make a change, when you save, it prompts you for version comments.


You can roll-back changes as well, but there is no text view of changes because of so many different manufacturers file types, but there are other programs that can do that. 

https://www.mdt-software.com/

The top declared volume creates persistence storage (like a virtual hard drive) between starts of the container. 

The other 5 are bindings that move files from my git repository over to the particular folders on the Linux container.

Author: benveenema
Content:
The counter to this is that they could gain a strong, loyal following for enabling things like version control. Also, if the only thing holding you to a platform is that the work you've done on it can't transfer to another, that means the platform isn't that great to start with and you're relationship with the platform vendor is going to sour.

An alternative would be for the platform developer to integrate a version control system into it. Native VCS to a platform would be an awesome feature and I can see it fitting into workflows  a lot better that way.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Totally agree

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: This argument extends to many aspects of a business. But it is often met with opposition internally due to the inherent risk (we need to make it hard for the customer to switch). I think the smart companies will be those that make it easy to switch and then continue to develop the relationship long term.

Author: benveenema
Content:
That opposition is the old world way of doing business. The internet (and therefor democratization of information) has changed everything we used to know about the world. It is no longer possible for a business to lock-in an educated customer in. But there are still a lot executives who come from the old world business ways and have yet to adapt.

In some sectors, like mainstream (ex. webdev) software, businesses have already adapted (or failed). It is taking longer for the industrial sector to catch-up but we are witnessing the transition now. The new companies are being created and the old companies are starting to adapt or fail.

Author: benveenema
Content: The reality of software development today is that you cannot create a piece of software once and then rest and ride it out for the next 10-20 years. Software companies today must continue to evolve and update their software (significantly, not minorly) or they will be quickly replaced by the next guy.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Jeff Jarvis wrote a book many years ago called What Would Google Do? The main point of the book is that companies should make as much information as possible public. And learn how to collaborate with companies that make your product better. He proceeded to make business cases for markets like banking and real estate and how Google would act in these markets. And yet it continues to be the exception.

Author: allyng
Content:
Hi @MParris 

Answering your questions:
- It is docker based technology (docker compose)
- It runs on the Siemens industrial PCs  and HMIs for now, but will run in other automation device from Siemens (Industrial Switches, Drives,etc). In the future, if a 3rd party manufacturer want to be a eco system partner, it can certify their HW to run the Edge Runtime
- The edge devices are on premises (connected directly to the machine) and can send data to the cloud if necessary (through the cloud connectors), or keep that data on premises (network or local data lake). The management part can be on premises (available) and cloud hosted (available in the future)

I Hope it helps!

Author: maz02272
Content:
Hello community!
We recently purchased an Edge device that runs Windows 10 Pro OS and I am trying to test the reliability in the event of a power failure.  

Areas of concern are:
1. OS corruption
2. Database corruption (MS SQL)
3. Project application corruption (Ignition)

What are your thoughts on what to consider or add to the design to ensure robust restarting of the system after a power failure? How to protect the OS, database, and project?

I am thinking UPS with surge protected outlet. UPS can signal the edge system that a power event occurred and shutdown sequence can start from there.

Thanks in advance

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
UPS is a good approach.  There are a lot of options.  This problem space extends well beyond the industrial space.  Because Ignition runs a service, it's pretty resilient to be stopped by the OS.  Likewise, for SQL Server, it's configured by default to wait for stored procedures and perform database checkpoints.  It will figure out what to commit or roll back.  Preventing corruption is a key feature of SQL Server.

Eaton has an elaborate system that can gracefully pause/shutdown VMs and sequence everything.  Probably overkill for a one-off Edge device, but it works well a facility-wide solution.  APC PowerChute is another established data center centric product.
https://www.eaton.com/us/en-us/catalog/backup-power-ups-surge-it-power-distribution/eaton-intelligent-power-manager.html

Phoenix Contact has industrial UPS with communication modules that can command Windows to shutdown gracefully.
https://www.phoenixcontact.com/online/portal/us?1dmy&urile=wcm%3apath%3a/usen/web/main/products/subcategory_pages/Configuration_and_Communication_P-22-07-06/87d15574-8a85-4908-8500-ed7610ac9e51

PULS has a lot of great DC power supply and continuity products.  You could "wire" up a tag to monitor a physical "DC Ok" contact and react accordingly.
https://products.pulspower.com/en/ub10-241.html

Author: maz02272
Content: Thank you for your time and great answer!

Content: I've not used WonderLogix on a real project, but played around with it. When I last looked it could generate code for Siemens S7-1500 and Rockwell Controllogix.  Its USP is that it has a form of predictive English that allows you to write structured English to control the objects that you draw. This English is then translated in to PLC code. No motion control though - at least a year or so ago when I tried it.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Has anyone noticed the Global Chip Shortage affecting IIoT, on PLCs and other edge devices?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: Not IIoT per se.  It's been a bigger problem on automation in general.  It's really showed up on legacy or lower-volume components for automation and electrical.  Think controllers, actuators, and interface modules that can't be easily substituted.  Items that once took a day or two now take months.  Many of these products have limited inventory and their replenishment are tied to just-in-time contract manufacturing.  The problem with contract manufacturing is that not all batches can be produced at the same time.  The capacity must be shared.  Mainstream, higher-volume automation products have not been as bad.  I believe these are produced in larger batches and warehoused (and priced) to avoid shortages and lifecycle issues.  Beyond that, the semi-conductor shortage has induced purchases to horde spares as well as hedge further price increases.  Another factor is how manufacturers in the affected sectors are handling their shut down plants or reduced capacity.  Many are taking advantage of it by pulling ahead planned maintenance or overhaul projects.  It's further driving consumption.  Some manufactures are trying to just catch up from last year.  The shutdowns (and recoveries) hit Asia, Europe, and North America at different times.  This put a lot of stress on global supply chains and created pent-up demand independent of consumer electronics.

Author: benveenema
Content: If we only open outbound ports on our edge devices for security reasons, does this mean a plc can't receive data from the UNS? Or does it mean it just can't subscribe to data, it must request it? Or am I missing something altogether?

Author: Deleted User
Content: If only outbound ports are open and all inbound ports are closed then no, a PLC can't receive data from the UNS. (Similar to a data diode, being discussed in the security channel).

Author: benveenema
Content: Then how is SCADA implemented using a UNS approach? It seems to me there's not much point if we can't even update a setpoint or something like that.

Author: Deleted User
Content: It's a good question that cuts across several topics. If you want bi-drectional communications, you have to open inbound ports.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: The PLC can be setup to initiate a connection to the UNS to read (‚Äúsubscribe‚Äù) values in like an inbound write would on a traditional poll-and-response protocol when a PLC functions as a server.

Author: benveenema
Content: And this only requires an outbound port?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: Correct. To use an analogy... I can read and copy your notes instead of you writing them for me.

Author: Deleted User
Content:
Yes, js has it right. If the PLC initiates communications then the firewall will pass any response from the UNS back to the PLC. However, you would not be able to connect to the PLC from outside. So, let's say a setpoint is changed in the UNS. The PLC will only get that update when it pulls it from the UNS, the UNS cannot push it to the PLC.

It's no different to your home internet connection. Most home firewalls have all inbound ports closed but you can still access the internet.

I wasn't clear in my first response.

Author: mparris
Content:
To further refine the point: with MQTT, a PLC will get all the data that it subscribes to, and if another application is sending commands to that PLC through one of those topics is subscribing to, then you are getting inbound data through outbound connections  üòÉ 

If the applications decide to start writing to a different topic, then the PLC won't get any of that data unless it starts subscribing to that topic.  So what data the PLC can ingest is controlled by what topics the PLC subscribes to. The elegant part: all of this is through outbound ports (from the perspective is the PLC)

Author: pvmagacho
Content: I have a question from a continuous process plant point of view. How would edge driven be applied to remote I/Os that uses either Profinet or Ethernet/IP? Should they be a remote I/O and a MQTT publisher or would that be the job of the main CLP they are connected to? Imagine this in a greenfield project. Thank you

Author: mparris
Content:
Pulling an analogy from home life: should ALL things in your home have direct connection to the internet? The answer is no. There are some things that make sense to be on the internet (IIoT), and others where it's not appropriate.  With IIoT, you are creating an Internet. Not everything should have access to it or live on the internet directly.

Not everything will satisfy the requirements of an IIoT Ecosystem, and that's ok, even for a greenfield project.  The purpose of the IIoT Ecosystem is to connect the higher-level things together, or disparate systems together.

All the field bus protocols will continue to exist and that is a good thing.  IIoT is not out to replace them.  That's similar to IT saying that they will replace all your plant's Network Architectures, security risk reviews, certificate authorities, etc with their processes. It isn't appropriate, and it won't work.

 IIoT does not live at the field bus level; It's intended to be at a higher level than that.  So keep using OPC-UA, Ethernet IP, Profinet, EtherCAT, modbus, bacnet, etc without regretüòÉ  IIoT comes into play as you move outside the fieldbus world and connecting to different applications and systems. That's what gateways will always be for, also.

Author: dundo6741
Content:
I have a feeling that too much concern is given to "security" so it ends up with unplugging everything.
MQTT uses only one port, you implement SSL layer and login/password, certificates etc., if there is a firewall on the network you only open that one port.
Edge devices will typically be on the process LAN (VLAN), which should be protected from the outside anyhow.
If edge device should communicate with the outside world (corporate UNS, cloud etc.) a VPN should be implemented and, probably, a local UNS/proxy that is in the DMZ but also on the VPN.
That should be sufficient.

Author: benveenema
Content: If we want to own and control our own data, this is exactly how we should approach it. A lot of IIoT and I would say almost all consumer IoT is NOT oriented this way though. They are digital threads. This is okay for consumer IoT if you're not concerned about your privacy. I think it's probably a disaster for IIoT, or at least a continuation of the paradigm we have now where a few large conglomerates (Rockwell, Siemens, etc) control the whole space and don't enable innovative manufacturing.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
This is an interesting question.  I have not encountered any standalone safety controllers with IIoT protocol interfaces.  Just fieldbus communications.  I've personally observed it's more effective and practical to globally buy/build automation with a PLC that is *safe* than it is to make a safety controller *smart*.

**Integrated Safety**
Wherever possible, use a multi-discipline controller with integrated safety (and motion).  Yes, the processor and i/o will often cost more, but it lowers the total cost of ownership.  Having everything in one control plane does wonders for engineering, data accessibility, maintenance, and flexibility.  Need to add another robot, conveyor, gate, safety zone, etc?  Just plug it in and update the program.  The resulting changes are made available to the HMI(s) and IIoT infrastructure.  With a standalone safety controller, it's too easy for data to get stranded or lose context.  Everything must be explicitly mapped to a fieldbus or contacts and then deciphered on the other end.  It creates friction.

Rockwell:  Compact GuardLogix 5380, GuardLogix 5580
Siemens:  SINUMERIK 840D SL, S7-1500
Fanuc:  R-30iB Plus w/ DCS, Series 32i-B w/ DCS

**Standalone Safety**
It's not always an option to use integrated safety controllers.  You know the drill... brownfield, unique/disparate controllers, lazy machine builders, etc.  ABB Pluto series is flexible and cost effective.  They have a lot of accessories.  It's a CAN bus safety network with various fieldbus gateways for monitoring.  The software is on par with the market... it's old and ugly.  Rockwell has a programmable safety relay based on the Micro 820 series.  It can be programmed using CCW or embedded into a Studio 5000 project.

ABB/Jokab:  Pluto B20v2
Rockwell:  440C-CR30
(I've heard good things about Pilz)

**Analog Inputs**
The major PLC and sensor brands offer absolute encoders with safety fieldbus interfaces (e.g., CIP Safety, PROFIsafe).  Alternatively, the ABB Pluto has analog.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I should mention that the above examples are for organizations that have standardized around certain platforms (e.g., Rockwell, Siemens, Fanuc).  These are widely adopted and available around the world.  These, of course, can be substituted with another platform.

I've witnessed both buyers and sellers scorn the additional cost of integrated safety.  What they save in the cost of material, they easily lose much more in engineering their way around a less flexible architecture.  The cost of automation is not borne by its mere acquisition, but also the environment in which it operates.

Author: mparris
Content:
Ready for the red pill?  Node (NDATA) and device (DDATA) are constructs of your imagination. Nothing more üôÇ

The node is typically the hardware/software that is the MQTT client, and the device can be ANYTHING. The node can exist as an empty shell categorizing all is metrics into virtual devices. Or it can have no devices and categorize all metrics under NDATA.

What about the Wago led you to expect it to be a device and not a node?

Author: benveenema
Content: The counter argument being that separating safety from control leads to a safer machine. A little bit if friction, although additional work and less flexible may be a good thing. I haven't worked with integrated safety controllers myself so perhaps there's a healthy separation in them already.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I've only touched two different brands of safety rated PLCs, and to me they were pretty much the same, because they both are following the same standard for safety programming. The logic is inherently separated from the rest of the controller, can be easily locked down and is isolated and you have to be pretty darn lost to mess it up. There are a few pitfalls, but they are to my knowledge very specific to Siemens and how our OEM programmed the darn thing.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Jon Forbord, you just advanced to level 9!

Author: mparris
Content:
Thanks Jon. I guess that is my question (PLCs aren't my day job): can it be setup to make it impossible for a general user to affect the safety logic.

One lesson I've learned over the years: "Operations will find a way" to leverage a quote from Ian Malcolm on Jurassic Park

Author: jon.forbord
Content: In older siemens PLCs you could "hack open" locked blocks using a software you could find online (or just remove the _Locked_ keyword in the source code). I'm not sure if this hack is available for 1500-series PLCs from Siemens.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I can only speak to our case, but because our Siemens PLC had it's safe-state variables mixed with normal variables, there were cases where changes to non-safety logic would cause the safety-logic to recompile, and a download would cause the PLC to stop, all safe states triggering, and production stopping for a few hours. The safety logic was unaffected, but the production stops are still not ideal.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
These are all great points raised.

Integrated safety PLCs are like two separate controllers in one.  The safety module has its own compute and memory resources.  It has an independent scanning sequence, routines and specialized instruction sets.  There are limitations in how the safety and standard tags can be used.  It's a much more prescriptive and restrictive development environment.  It actually can trip up old school programmers accustomed to traditional safety relays and MCRs.  Initially, they're likely to struggle grasping all the safeguards to get their program to simply run.  It forces one to account for not just logic, but also tampering (e.g., jumping, latching).  Everything can be signed and locked down.  Safety and non-safety roles can be segmented.

As Jon mentioned, one is much more likely to lock up their PLC than introduce unsafe conditions.  They're inherently safe.  One of the largest lessons learned after settling on an integrated safety architecture and piloting it is training.  While conceptually similar to a standard PLC, there do exist key differences.  Getting familiar with the prescribed ways to achieve safety objectives can take a moment.  Fortunately, a lot of the manuals for these products written in an application-oriented way.  The applications engineers and training programs at distributors are good resources.

Author: luisn8316
Content:
One thing worth noting - Opto22 EPIC controller has only been on the market for ~3 years and it's targeted for larger-scale automation projects and/or DCS. The S7-1200 PLC has been on the market since 2010 and it's targeted for small applications (machine builders). The two are categorically different segments. But it's with noting that a small PLC that's been on the market for 10+ years still continues to add features that address market needs today - the SparkplugB topic is one we are looking at as well along with other innovations (the first step is to even support basic MQTT which only happened as of last year). I'd be interested to find another PLC that has been on the market as long as the S7-1200 that includes these features at a (still) affordable price range.

FYI, The next firmware (V4.5) is set to release this month and mainly includes added enhancements to the OPC UA Server, among other improvements like support for JSON RPC API for easier access to PLC data. I'd be open to listen for more features/requests for the S7-1200 if anyone wants to reach out üôÇ.

Content:
Hello everyone! I need some advice here on how to proceed - 

One of our customers has an assembly line with a number of torque tools (nut runners), mostly Atlas Copco and Tohnichi, but with a few other smaller brands sprinkled in. They want to collect the data out of these tools to monitor and track parameter changes, actual vs set etc.

I know Kepware has a driver that can connect with Atlas Copco drives. My questions is how do we approach this for non-Atlas Copco tools? Or even Atlas Copco tools that use drives not within Kepware's supported devices?

Author: youri.regnaud
Content: In our factories, we have a lot of small devices with RS233, USB and ASCII type protocols, ... Today we prefer to use NodeRed to transform OT protocols into MQTT protocols hosted on simple gateways. We use Edge MC gateway from Tulip.co, and we test Hilscher and Revolution PI gateway. I would be interested to know if the community recommends other industrial gateways with NodeRed hosting and USB/Serial connections

Author: ales7315
Content:
One solution is also to convert serial communication to ethernet via some gateway (Moxa Nport, Advantech Adam 4571, etc.). The next step is to use the Kepware Ucon driver and convert every Ascii / serial protocol to OPC tags (https://www.kepware.com/en-us/products/kepserverex/drivers/u-con/). It is not the best solution, but UCON driver is a nice option.

I was looking for Node-red gateway a year ago, I found this company: https://st-one.io/st-one
From Argentina, I never tested it, price around $ 800, but It supports a lot of protocols.

Author: pvmagacho
Content:
Node.js is used in production for many IT applications, substituting Java or C#, with very good performance. It is IO event based, with only one main thread. This makes a very interesting platform for IIoT as it is basically IO based. And having only one thread makes programming easier. The underlying code that Node.js runs in V8 C++ engine. That translation is not an excuse for not using it.
For instance, Ignition, if I am not mistaken, runs on Java which in turns needs to be translated using JVM environment, the same for Highbyte. I don‚Äôt see any reason why a well design node.js application couldn‚Äôt be used in the industrial automation stack. The fact that node-red might not be applicable to real industrial application doesn‚Äôt have to do with the fact that it uses Node.js. I think it might be related to the fact is that node-red wasn‚Äôt built with the robustness needed for industrial application or at least haven‚Äôt been put to the test.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I thought I'd share a follow up on this discussion on this topic of IFM's IO-Link masters with MQTT.

In another channel, @Durga Kolli posted a link that IFM appears to now publish Ignition templates / UDTs.  Previously, IFM only maintained libraries for major PLC platforms for their products.  This meant that one had to manually parse/decipher payloads if they were bypassing the PLC communications and instead leveraging MQTT.  This appears to no longer be the case.

I really must applaud IFM's approach of providing open *and* turn-key integrations for their products.  Maintaining an integration to a leading product like Ignition (in a non-exclusive way) does a lot more for the industry than endorsing theoretical industry standards that no one is adopting in a meaningful way.  #WinTheResultsWar

https://www.ifm.com/us/en/shared/technologies/io-link/system-integration/ignition-scada-integration
https://inductiveautomation.com/exchange/2136/installation

Author: benveenema
Content:
I'm going to side more with @Gnichi Mohamed on this one. Arduino and Rasp Pi get a bad raps in professional circles because their initial target was education and makers/hobbyists, but their underlying core is state of the art micro-controllers like STMs. It's all about the hardening of the circuits. Both companies have made more and more hardened devices, like Portenta for Arduino and the Compute Modules for Raspberry Pi

They don't hold your hand like a PLC does when you're programming it and I think that is actually going to be the biggest thing keeping them from wide adoptance in manufacturing. It's easy to solve the MTBF problem, add better hardware. It's harder to solve the skill upgrade problem that programming in C/C++ vs ladder require.

The tradeoff is your Arduino or micro-controller based machine controls are way more powerful and flexible for the price. For $40 you can buy a RAMPS kit, which is an Arduino and the necessary hardware to control a 3D printer. That's 4+ stepper motor drives (high speed outputs), motion control, tons of analog inputs, relay outputs, and several PID loops running simultaneously on what is considered outdated micro-controller tech at this point.

Would I use that grade of hardware in a professional environment? Hell no! It's not rugged enough. But don't discount the reliability of any controller just because it's Arduino or Pi under the hood.

Author: faithware101
Content: @Ben Veenema also sometimes you can't justify the cost of C programming a process that is not that fast or time critical. Also customers don't like having their machines running by an electronics board that they are not sure where to get it from in case you are not there anymore.

Author: faithware101
Content: haha you understood my point

Author: benveenema
Content: I think C programming can be just as fast if we have the right tools and libraries. If our goal is to compete with a PLC, we can overspec the processor 300% and not worry about  optimizing our code to sqeeze every last instruction and memory location.

Author: benveenema
Content: As long as we avoid dynamic memory allocation, we can use the standard template library, and use Arduino or other frameworks that aren't optimized for  processor performance, but are instead optimized for programming speed.

Author: benveenema
Content: We do need to build a better ecosystem if we are going to go that way though. In no way do I think that embedded C/C++ has enough libraries and tools yet to make it "manufacturer ready" but this is just a consequence of the decision back in the 70s to go the proprietary PLC route instead of an open embedded route.

Author: benveenema
Content: It will take time and effort to build an open ecosystem to make embedded a viable alternative to the PLC. Maybe it's not worth it? It's tough to say and I don't know PLCs well enough to make an educated call on it.

Author: faithware101
Content:
I am looking at boost.sml , it is a pretty lightweight state machine library in C++. I might give up function pointers. For example here is what one implementation looks like.
pumpStateHandler pumpFSM[]={
        {STATE_PUMPWAIT,StatePumpWait},
        {STATE_STARTPUMPBUTTON,StateStartPumpButton},
        {STATE_STOPPUMPBUTTON,StateStopPumpButton},
        {STATE_STOPPUMPERROR,StateStopPumpError},
        {STATE_STARTPUMPCALL,StateStartPumpCall},
        {STATE_STOPPUMPCALL,StateStopPumpCall},
        {STATE_STARTPUMPMQTT,StateStartPumpMqtt},
        {STATE_STOPPUMPMQTT,StateStopPumpMqtt},
        {STATE_ERROR,StateError},
        {STATE_POWERBACK,StatePowerBack},
        {STATE_STARTPUMPAUTO,StateStartPumpAuto},    {STATE_STOPPUMPCONTACTORISSUE,StateStopPumpContactorIssue},
      {STATE_STOPPUMPWATERLEVELISSUE,StateStopPumpWaterLevelIssu,
        {STATE_STOPPUMPTHERMALISSUE,StateStopPumpThermalIssue},
};
this is an array of structs that holds the state and it's function pointer. An I can jump between state with events.
In boost.sml it is much clearer and you can avoid a lot of issues.
The cool thing is that in parallel to this you can have all sorts of timers, rs485 communication, encoder hardware readings ...

Author: dundo6741
Content:
I was searching for (couldn't find) and thinking of building my own (couldn't find the time and motivation) a C++ library for MCUs that would, for starters, enable to chain blocks together.

For instance, every component (analog and digital inputs and outputs, specific sensors, stepper motor drivers, ...) would have its class that would perform necessary tasks.
There would be, as I imagined, set of virtual components (filters, integrators, voting components (2-out-of-3), signal processors in general) that would accept 1 or more other components (digital or analog) on input and send results of processing to 1 or more outputs which could again be inputs to other blocks etc.
There would be a "master" class (I call it component manager) that would initialize all components on startup, read all hw inputs and write them to component raw input data on start of the cycle and write all the component output data to hw output pins.

In other words, one could accomplish "manual operation" by configuring hardware in Excel or such, export it to CSV or something, include that in your program and there you go, your MCU reads, filters and process all the inputs, and is writing (or is ready to) all the outputs.
Components would be easy to modify or extend (inheritance) and it would be also easy to add new ones (new class, inherited from some super or abstract class).

Programmer "just" needs to add logic. üòâ

Have anyone find something like this?

Author: benveenema
Content:
In my mind what this more looks like is a unique class for devices that inherits from a standard interface so that higher level classes can use them with a known set of methods. 

I usually organize my controls code into devices and systems. Devices are things like actors and sensors and Systems are groups of devices that perform an action.

A good example is a hydra-pneumatic piston. You have multiple valves and position sensors that all work together to form the h-p piston. If you use abstraction properly, you can focus on the writing good, reliable routines for the valve, and then forget about the implementation details of the valve when you are writing for the piston.

Author: luisn8316
Content: The video I believe you are referring to uses an older version of the library (V2.1). The updated version (V3.0) removed these UDTs and as they were not required ... To help answer your question, the array of bytes is your payload. Each byte in the array represents a character that will be passed to the broker. Another thing that changed with V3 is that you can specify how many bytes/characters you are passing by setting the "PubMessageCnt" to the amount of bytes/characters to pass (no longer limited to 800 characters). In the application example, they are passing a message "HELLO WORLD" as the payload. The "pubMessageCnt" parameter is therefore set to 11... I am hoping to build a demo for the new blocks soon, and share with the community but unfortunately have not had the bandwidth to do so lately. It would be great to get your feedback once you get this running on your end.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I've just tried using a MQTT library for our Bosch rexroth controllers, and when I compare the two, there are a couple things I think could make the Siemens MQTT library a lot more useable. Add the possibility to easily build multiple topics and payloads and set the block input to publish a set of payloads and topics. Currently I'd have to build this myself, as well as manage the iteration of topic publishing. Not very hard to do if you're well experienced PLC programming - but I would argue it should still be even easier. Bosch rexroth have a payload structure add method that even checks if value changed in order to decide to publish or not within the cycle. The publish method also handles the queueing, so for every cycle I can push all the structs to the publish block, without having to consider if the block is finished with the previous publish or not. FYI I've only read the documentation and briefly tried it with Tia Portal. I guess my question is - have I understood the docs correctly if I assume that in order to publish to multiple topics, I'd have to send each one separately and wait for the .done feedback to push the next?

Author: luisn8316
Content: Thanks, @Jon Forbord for the feedback! I'd love to get a little more understanding on what you'd like to see improved with the LMQTT library. I can pass this feedback along to our R&D/systems engineers to see what can be done to fix these issues, if you're interested üôÇ

Author: sampath2806
Content: https://litmus.io/litmus-and-cantier-partner-to-offer-agile-smart-manufacturing-solutions-with-mes-and-iiot-4-0-platform/

Author: jon.forbord
Content: That would be great if you were to pass it along. The initial impression of the library is that it would require too much time to make use of the library, because it doesn't inherently invoke the functionality to publish loads of topics and payloads, so in short: Make it easier to set up with multiple payloads and topics. Even doing some of the string conversion necessary a part of the library, rather than leave it up to the user, would also make this easier. I don't even know if this is possible on a siemens  PLC, but say supply with a json-library, that can convert a value based on data type, and build json payloads with timestamp, value and data type. It don't even have to support passing complex types, but further down the line, this is an obvious further improvement, including Report By Exception. So I'd just have to call the json value converter for the values I'd like to publish, add each value to an array of payload/topics that I could pass to the MQTT block. Anyone else have any thoughts on what they would like to see to make the LMQTT library even better?

Author: phil_s2342
Content:
" i am measuring liquid level and temp
which goes to 34.55555555555
and you dont want all changes"                            

Could you just use sleep (microcontrollers generally have this functionality) to reduce how frequently the sensor value is reported? I wouldn't think a trending average or other reductions of tank level would need to be done on edge for "static" (not changing in ms intervals) measurements like tank level or temp.

Author: mparris
Content:
Is the idea to reduce the number of decimal points, or to create a deadband, where a new value isn't reported/saved to disk unless it is different by at least a minimum threshold, such as 0.001?

OPC-UA actually includes a deadband filter option out of the box, which is nice when connecting to analog IO through opc-ua. The client gets to decide what level of data is important.

It would be great if MQTT offered a similar option: when a client creates a subscription, it states the maximum rate data can be sent to it, and could specify a deadband. Would help lower end devices not get pummeled by data beyond their capability

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: This is correct in our analysis too‚Ä¶ Docker deployment is still very much in its infancy in Industry ‚Äî primarily because most vendors develop to demand (what they want) rather than developing what the market needs.  Container support will move quickly‚Ä¶ they make deployment so much easier and they are perfect at scale.  No worries‚Ä¶ Docker support is easy to do‚Ä¶ Like Josh said, its all about moving it up the list‚Ä¶ keep pushing!

Author: jeastburn9264
Content: Yup... this is the product development chicken-egg problem. If we build it, they will come... unless they don't üòÜ  Sometimes we really believe in a particular technology and are willing to take a gamble on it ahead of the demand. Arlen Nipper showed us Sparkplug B and we jumped on MQTT before a lot of other folks. (Hence the relationship with Inductive, another early adopter.) Same thing with Ethernet I/O back in the day and a few other big ones. In other cases, we've been way too far ahead (see: https://documents.opto22.com/1504_Nvio_Starter_Kit_data_sheet.pdf) and gotten burned. So typically, we're following the demand, like Walker said. If you've got a big project that relies on docker and you want to build it on groov EPIC, that always gets attention. Which I know kind of sounds lame... it's just a balancing act we have to play so we can stay in the game. It's also why we included SSH access---because we knew there would be these edge cases (relative to the rest of our customer base) and it's such an easy workaround since we're already running Linux. Full transparency: it could also be that we've just misread the field in this particular case and should be pushing the envelope more.

Author: para5844
Content:
Hi I am new to the industry! Nice meeting all of you üôÇ
I do have a requirement to monitoring our controllers. The protocol is BACnet/IP. As such, I noticed that Ignition Edge seems like the first step in exposing BACnet/IP data to the internet. Would like to hear from you all on your experience in this üôÇ

Author: luisn8316
Content: Siemens' IOT 2050 might be a good option, or IPC127E if you're just looking for and edge device

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
The protocol conversion is the easy part.  Ignition recently released a BACnet/IP driver you could use or opt for a dedicated connectivity solution.  I favor the latter.  The more challenging question will be, after converting from BACnet, what kind of architecture should these controllers connect to?

Kepware has a BACnet/IP driver.  This can expose your controllers' data to your IIoT ecosystem via its OPC-UA or MQTT interfaces.

https://www.kepware.com/en-us/products/kepserverex/drivers/bacnet-ip/

Some examples:

[Controller] <- BACnet/IP -> [KepServerEX] <- OPC-UA -> [HighByte] <- MQTT SpB -> [CL Chariot (Broker)]

[Controller] <- BACnet/IP -> [KepServerEX] <- OPC-UA -> [Ignition Transmission / Edge] <- MQTT SpB -> [Ignition Distributor (Broker)]

[Controller] <- BACnet/IP -> [KepServerEX] <- MQTT -> [HiveMQ (Broker)]

[Controller] <- BACnet/IP -> [KepServerEX] <- MQTT -> [Ignition Distributor (Broker)]

Author: para5844
Content:
Hi @js thanks for your feedback.
What do you mean by a dedicated connectivity solution?
From my limited research, it seems that Ignition Edge can convert BAcnet/IP to MQTT right?
Thus, my intention to expose my controllers to IT via MQTT is as follows:

[Controller] <- BACnet/IP -> [Ignition Edge] <- MQTT -> [External]

However, I do have requirement to control remotely. So instead of creating a separate BMS for the controls, I am thinking whether this solution or IIoT in general is able to achieve this?

Author: youri.regnaud

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: If possible I would only do certain pre-processing on the edge using Lambda functions (when using Greengrass) or plain services, eg. if you have to reduce the amount of data, for data acquisition from PLCs or if you need low-latency results and do the rest in the cloud. Another typical use case for edge devices would be visual inspection via ML. For visualization / dashboards Grafana is great but for it to work you would also need some form of database (which one depends on your specific data & use case). It‚Äôs difficult to give a generic answer without knowing what you are exactly trying to achieve and why.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
@Taicho had a great question in the chat this morning‚Ä¶ *do you become limited to the selection of sensors that supported io-link, or can anything be hooked up to io-link?*

IO-Link is a serial-based protocol for sensors governed by PROFINET International.  It can work with actuators too, but vast majority of products on the market are sensors.  I've encountered pneumatic valve manifolds and servo motors with it.  Because these types of actuators were "big" and "smart" enough to have Ethernet-based fieldbuses, offering IO-Link interfaces was not much of a challenge. Sensors, on the other hand, are much more mixed world.

**[IO-Link benefits on ‚Äúsmall‚Äù and ‚Äúbig‚Äù sensors]**
Some sensors are "big" and expensive while others are "small" and low cost.  The "big" sensors can be critical instrumentation for the process industry.  They cost thousands or even tens of thousands of dollars.  Think Endress+Hauser.  These often have enough compute to support an Ethernet-based fieldbus.  The "small" sensors, by comparison, are much more simple.  They can cost tens or hundreds of dollars.  Think IFM.  They might have no compute at all or just enough to pass a basic 24VDC or 4-20mA electrical signal over a basic M12 cable.  Much of the intelligence is derived by a PLC interpreting discrete or analog signals coming off the sensor.

IO-Link exposes much more intelligence and context in sensors.  It's not just an unscaled process value (e.g., 4-20mA scaled to temp) or switching signal (e.g., 24VDC when below temperature set point).  It can exchange multiple process values natively, units of measure, configuration, product info, diagnostics, etc.  And it does so in standardized way with required documentation.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
-
IO-Link also simplifies the physical interfacing.  It leverages standard, unshielded M12 field wiring manufacturers are already accustomed to for control power and low-voltage field devices.  Single-pair ethernet is becoming available for longer and more complex cable runs.

While IO-Link can benefit both ‚Äúbig‚Äù and ‚Äúsmall‚Äù sensors, it‚Äôs most beneficial for ‚Äúsmall‚Äù sensors.  These smaller sensors could take the form of a low-cost level or pressure switch.  Today, these don‚Äôt provide much intelligence.  They only are used for basic process control (i.e., good state, bad state).  But, tomorrow they could provide much more information and context.  Unfortunately, replacing these sensors to become IP-based nodes could be cost prohibitive and impractical.  Supporting things like TCP or UDP is a step-up in device and infrastructure complexity.  This is where the simplicity of IO-Link excels.  It‚Äôs lightweight and simple enough to run on smaller sensors.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
-
**[IO-Link Support]**
An IO-Link connection consists of IO-Link Master and IO-Link device.  The IO-Link Master functions as the ‚Äúclient‚Äù node.  It manages all the IO-Link configurations and connections.  Sometimes the IO-Link Master is an interface module on a PLC backplane.  More often, it‚Äôs a gateway with various forms of Ethernet fieldbus connectivity to connect to a PLC‚Äôs fieldbus network.  All the data from the IO-Link Master (and the devices connected to it) get mapped into the PLC‚Äôs memory.  

Some IO-Link Masters have IIoT interfaces (e.g., MQTT, OPC-UA, HTTP) that enable standalone use without a PLC.  Some even allow simultaneous PLC fieldbus and IIoT connectivity.  This provides the flexibility of determining whether to consume sensor data from the control layer and any associated context -or- directly from the sensor itself.

Any IO-Link Master can connect to any IO-Link device.  The IO-Link spec requires all devices to have a defined payload in what‚Äôs referred to as an IO Device Description (IODD).  Each device has an IODD file.  This is an XML document which functions as a driver of sorts.  Most IO-Link configuration software or software libraries can import the IODD files.  This informs the application of what the IO-Link devices are and what data can be exchanged with them.

Leveraging an IO-Link Masters and devices of the same brand with a mainstream PLC (e.g., Rockwell, Siemens) typically yields the best experience.  The larger sensor companies, especially IFM, have done an incredible job at building out PLC software libraries (e.g., AOI, FB) that map in the IODD data structures from their IO-Link products.  They maintain libraries for virtually every mainstream PLC platform.  IFM has even built out libraries and visualizations for Ignition.  This frees the user from having to build out UDTs for each sensor they want to connect.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
-
Without these slick libraries automatically transforming and mapping the data structures for you, setting up IO-Link can feel like programming a fieldbus.  It involves reading the IODD and parsing out the payload accordingly.  The IO-Link standard defines the payload, but it does not define what each application should do with it.  As a result, leveraging products that do this work for you end-to-end can pay off. 

**[IO-Link Masters + sensors without IO-Link?]**
As for whether any sensor can be connected to an IO-Link Master, the short answer is no.  The long and somewhat brand-specific answer is yes.  Strictly speaking, the IO-Link spec defines a protocol between IO-Link Masters and IO-Link devices.  But, there‚Äôs no reason why an IO-Link device itself can‚Äôt be I/O.  

Some IO-Link Masters have configurable ports for IO-Link devices or discrete I/O.  Some models even have high-current outputs for larger actuators.  A 0/24VDC sensor could be connected a port configured as a discrete input.

There exist IO-Link devices called hubs.  They‚Äôre basically remote i/o.  They connect to an IO-Link Master and provide both discrete and analog I/O.  Connecting multiple hubs to a single master can create staggering volumes of I/O.  There are even standalone devices that convert an analog input into IO-Link.  A 0/24VDC or 4-20mA sensor could be connected to any of this I/O.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
-

Here are some scenarios:

[UNS] <- MQTT -> [IOL Master] <- IOL -> [IOL Sensor]
[UNS] <- MQTT -> [IOL Master] <- 0/24VDC -> [Discrete Sensor]
[UNS] <- MQTT -> [IOL Master] <- IOL -> [IOL Hub] <- 0/24VDC -> [Discrete Sensor]
[UNS] <- MQTT -> [IOL Master] <- IOL -> [IOL Hub] <- 4-20mA -> [Analog Sensor]

[UNS] <- MQTT -> [PLC] <- fieldbus -> [IOL Master] <- IOL -> [IOL Sensor]
[UNS] <- MQTT -> [PLC] <- fieldbus -> [IOL Master] <- 0/24VDC -> [Discrete Sensor]
[UNS] <- MQTT -> [PLC] <- fieldbus -> [IOL Master] <- IOL -> [IOL Hub] <- 0/24VDC -> [Discrete Sensor]
[UNS] <- MQTT -> [PLC] <- fieldbus -> [IOL Master] <- IOL -> [IOL Hub] <- 4-20mA -> [Analog Sensor]

With both node-red and others like this, what is the use case in a UNS based IIoT deployment?

Author: dep05d
Content:
There are a few webinars on youtube that demo it. It looks like a customized version of Node Red and it's editor that runs centrally. The main feature is that subflows can be executed in parallel on many edge devices or remote runtimes.  The wiring and passing of information is maintained across the parent flow and distributed subflows.  The edge device runs a curl command to download node-red and join the platform.  In the central editor, right clicking on a subflow shows a checklist of all joined devices that are available to have that subflow deployed to them.  There were also some other features like centrally monitoring edge resources, rolling back deployments and restarting edge runtimes if they hang.

In UNS terms, these remote subflows could act as sparkplug edge nodes, or consume UNS data streams and republish derived information into new topics. In the webinar I clicked through, they deployed a subflow to a raspberry pi running a usb camera. Using tensorflow nodes running on the pi, they were able to make predictions on manual valve positions from the camera input.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Kepware and Matrikon's drivers are considered somewhat of the gold standards.  They have robust ecosystems.  Huge customer bases globally and ongoing support.  These drivers are rebranded and even embedded in other products.  It would be worthwhile figuring out what's driving the negative perception.  

The only people I've met that had strong opinions on Kepware were those that were unfamiliar with it or the technology in general.  They usually were accustomed to using something else (e.g., RSLinx, InGear) for a very narrow purpose.  They almost always prefer it after being enlightened.

I'm assuming this is in Europe.  Might be mis-priced or an issue with the local distributor?  Reach out to Ole Borgbjerg at Kepware for assistance.  Super friendly and helpful guy.

As @Jon Forbord mentioned, Ignition and Factory Studio have native drivers.

Other options:
-Siemens CloudConnect 7
-Maple Systems CMT-SVR
-HMS Anybus Edge Gateway
-Options with just OPC-UA:  Siemens SIMATIC NET, Real Time Automation, IBH Softec

Similar discussion on how to enable connectivity on an S7-300

Author: bensonhougland
Content:
As @Josh Eastburn  indicated, Opto 22 groov EPIC supports DHCP on all interfaces (2 segmented gigabit Ethernet ports, Wi-Fi, and VPN). DNS is also supported to access the PLC by hostname. Also built-in and supported: LDAP for account management, SSL/TLS certificates management (server and client), OpenVPN client, firewall configurations for each interface, and zoning (network segmentation) and conduits (port redirects). All of the above is configured from EPIC's HTTPS web interface, or RESTful APIs.
Oh, I work for Opto, too (full disclosure).

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I‚Äôm not familiar with any Siemens library that does this, so you may be left on your own for now. It‚Äôs definitely doable. I left the LMQTT approach in favor of a OPC UA-> Mqtt gateway (opto 22 RIO with Ignition onboard for instance). My immediate thinking is that if your plc has more than a handful of datapoints you want to send with LMQTT, is to use code generation to generate the code that takes a data block, converts to json and adds time stamp etc on change. My basic code generation approach with Siemens is to first write the code for one instance of what you need in TIA, export the blocks to xml (Tia openness or Tia version control), add placeholders for the code that changes for each instance, and that‚Äôs your xml template. Then to generate code you add instances of the template and replace the placeholder for each instance of the object (data point in this case). Its actually not very time consuming if you know some C# for instance. I‚Äôm not sure on whether limitations in the LMQTT library would allow this to be done at scale though. Could you for instance send thousands of tags with it? I dont know.

Author: henning8936
Content:
lets say you have a maschine state signal: Running, Idle, Error. But the signal needs some processing before being really useful. Where would you do this processing. Right at the edge before publishing it or for example in ignition when writing edge-tags to the line-namespace?

Some background: As the machine is not providing proper state signals, we want to utilize some valve actions in order to see if the process is running. Only if the signal is low for an extended period of time, we know that the process it stopped.

Author: andersgustav
Content:
@henning : I would choose the place that was most convenient from case to case. Do you have compute-power needed at the edge - fine. Do it there, or do you have the tags for this in ignition, then do it there.

The important part is however to publish the state back to the UNS from whatever place it is calculated, so that it's available to anyone else that might need it.

Author: henning8936
Content: Thanks @Anders Gustav. That sounds reasonable. Sure, will publish the calculated values back as the line state.

If you are looking for a package Node-RED + all the other stuff (OS, MQTT broker, firewall, etc.) you could look at the United Manufacturing Hub, which is an open source project (disclaimer: i am co-founder, i hope it is okay that i mention it). Would be a little bit more effort than just using Node-RED, but you would gain more control about the program flow and the logic.
