Content:
Within Windows? And you know the IP addresses/subnets of the PLCs ahead of time, you just want a faster way to switch between them?

And in this case, it's not feasible to get them on the same network (such as a production scenario, not development, where different PLCs are in separate networks)?

Author: andersgustav
Content:
`on connect mqttpublish(r)(ISA-95->Node-Info->IP->hash(dhcpassignedIP))`

There. it lives in the UNS

Author: benveenema
Content:
Yes windows. Yes I know the IP/subnets ahead of time (most of the time anyway). Currently the IP addresses for programming aren't networked. They may be at some point, but I'm usually happy to connect to them directly when updating programs.

My biggest complaint is that once I statically assign my IP, I have to remember to change it back to DHCP if I want to use ethernet to access internet/intranet.

I'd just rather be lazy and leave my ethernet on DHCP all the time but still be able to program the PLCs.

Is there a secure way to network the PLCs for programming?

Author: mparris
Content: Do the programming ports have the same IP address? Maybe an idea is to get a USB-Ethernet dongle that you configure with one static IP address, and leave your built-in Ethernet port as DHCP. then when you need to program, you plug in the Ethernet adapter and windows should remember it's Network settings (I have an external dock that includes an Ethernet port on it and works this way)

Author: mparris
Content:
On the network side for programming ports, yeah there's things you could do.

The first thought is to create an ADMIN VLAN, which is similar to what Network engineers do for their gear. It's a separate layer 2 (virtually, not physically) with separate IP address scheme to administer the network equipment. It's kept separately from the data of the users on the network.

You could probably do something similar for programming the PLCs, then control who has access to that VLAN.

I'll have to check, but I do remember someone saying there was a way to set up windows to accommodate different IP addresses. At a minimum, I wouldn't be surprised if there's a freeware software that would run in the task bar, and help you manage different profiles of network configurations, with a couple clicks.

Author: benveenema
Content: I like this idea. Seems nice and simple and doesn't require network changes. There's no reason we couldn't put all of our PLCs on the same subnet to make it easier.

Author: benveenema
Content:
I like the idea of having PLCs on a controlled VLAN that allows for remote programming. I'm assuming this would be separate from the data collection network for security reasons.

I'm also guessing there is a security risk if (maybe even if) this network is not secured really well. It's definitely outside of my wheelhouse but probably something to start looking at with our systems integrator and IT consultants.

Author: mparris
Content:
If you ask your IT/Network team for a "Management VLAN" for your PLCs, they'll know exactly what you are after.

In the meantime, maybe you can get all the PLC programming ports on the same subnet so your single static IP will work with all of them, or if you don't want to have to remember different IP addresses, then make them all the same IP address as long as they are not connected together.

Author: benveenema
Content: cMT-SVR can convert Ethernet/IP to MQTT cheaply and efficiently at the edge.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I would add a possible caveat to this recommendation.  This may or may not work.  Not all EtherNet/IP connections are the same.  From my experience, learning this can be painful and time consuming.  It's not always obvious in product documentation.

Most SCADA/HMI/Gateway drivers are designed to interface with a PLC and not necessarily field devices.

Most scales are treated like field devices (e.g., drives, valves, remote i/o) and their EtherNet/IP interfaces are implemented as such.  That is, they are EtherNet/IP Adapters.  They serve up data cyclically when initiated by an EtherNet/IP Scanner such as a PLC.  This is referred to as a "Class 1" or "implicit messaging" connection in the ODVA CIP spec.  Basically, it's the real-time control traffic that goes over UDP.  It's for efficiently moving I/O.

cMT-SVR has a generic EtherNet/IP driver, but it's for explicit messaging.  This is a "Class 3" CIP connection.  This is the non real-time traffic that goes over TCP.  Think HMI commands, parameter setting, recipe management, etc.  These benefit more from a stateful connection (e.g., handshaking, acknowledgement) than they do speed.

I would strongly recommend researching the EtherNet/IP interface on those scales.  Most drivers and gateways don't function as a typical EtherNet/IP Scanner found on a PLC.  The ones that do are much more specialized and rare.

For this reason and others, I've found it can make a lot of sense using PLCs as gateways.  Many field devices are designed with the assumption that they only connect to PLCs.  They're also sufficiently "dumb" without a PLC.  The effort to connect to and contextualize some field devices without a PLC can exceed the cost of leveraging a PLC.

If PLCs are already present, I would leverage those.  With most off-the-shelf products, it's easier to connect to a PLC than it is to a scale.  Either way, the data can still be published via MQTT from the edge.  Coming straight off the scale may not be the most efficient way.

Author: luisn8316
Content:
I would say this architecture provides a little more detail and relevant context to what Walker preaches. I particularly like it because it specifically calls out where the UNS resides within the networking infrastructure - is it IT? OT? DMZ? (in this case it shows a "Neutral zone", a.k.a DMZ). From an industrial cyber security perspective, this is more clear. 

To answer your question as to "relevancy of OPC UA at the edge" - OPC UA, as shown in the diagram provided, is great for the OT space where you have to communicate to an edge gateway or controller or horizontally to other PLCs/machines or SCADA systems. Anything above the PLC/SCADA, MQTT is recommended because it is ultimately more scalable than OPC UA

Author: luisn8316
Content:
Depends on your needs. Do you just want to use to convert messages to MQTT(e.g. a gateway)? Or do you want a PLC that has the ability to use some sort of edge-driven applications like node-red to contextualize/pre-process PLC data?

"Edge controllers" are nice if you want to convert protocols to MQTT SpB and contextualize process data, but how do you manage all those edge controllers/nodes from a central location? Do you manage each node/controller one-by-one? How do you deploy edge apps/updates centrally to all those devices? These are critical questions to consider if we really want to talk about scalability of edge controllers and digital transformation..

I think if UNS as a defined name structure. It's only on theory until you apply it to an IIoT stack.

Not everything will be able to, and many you won't want to, connect to the IIoT ecosystem. Those things that are translating from legacy to IIoT ecosystem are thought of as the"edge" since they are on the edge of the IIoT bubble.

So regarding your defined UNS structure, it may not make explicit what is on the edge and what is native IIoT or what is infrastructure.

Author: mparris
Content:
As @Daniel_H. mentioned, Pilz.

Also SICK (another German company) or Banner.

Don't know if Keyence has any.

The idea of a safety controller is that you program it like a PLC, but just for the safety functions. So it isolates your safety function. People like to go with the safety PLC (all in one), because many times the same IO being used for safety is needed for general logic, and creating a remote IO interface between the general PLC and the Safety Controller may be too cumbersome, compared to a safety PLC, which allows access to both safety and non safety IO all in one place.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
EtherNet/IP is a separate protocol from BACnet/IP.  The name is somewhat misleading.  EtherNet/IP is ODVA CIP over Ethernet.
```
[Media + Link]    | [CIP]        | [BACnet]
Serial (RS485)    | DeviceNet    | BACnet MS/TP
Ethernet (802.3)  | EtherNet/IP  | BACnet/IP
```
What's confusing about that manual is that it uses the phrase "IP/Ethernet".  I even found one that says "Ethernet/IP", but it does not make reference to ODVA or CIP.  It's illustrating a connection between Johnson Control's ADS software and the SNE and BACnet/IP devices.  In that context, I believe it's merely describing a typical ethernet network (i.e., TCP + IP + Ethernet MAC + Ethernet Physical) as infrastructure.

The documentation is not very thorough.  It talks about other protocols, but implies that it supports client and not server interfaces.  That is, it can "consume" other protocols from the field but not necessarily "provide" other protocols to external systems.

I‚Äôm going to make some assumptions and draw parallels from other systems.  Hopefully this will help.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
-
This looks somewhat similar to Honeywell / Tridium‚Äôs Niagara framework.  Niagara, like JC ADS, is a building management SCADA.  They have edge devices, called JACE controllers, that function as remote I/O and protocol gateways for legacy field devices (e.g., compressors, air handlers).  These appear to be similar to JC SNE devices.

If Niagara was relegated as brownfield and the context in it didn‚Äôt matter, an instance of Kepware would be stood up to talk to field devices directly.  If context in Niagara mattered, data would get pulled from it.  Typically, the HTTP or OPC client drivers would get used to write to an external server.  In more recent versions, OPC-UA Server and MQTT client drivers were added.  This is preferable.

The only difference is that this JC system seems much more ‚Äúsolution-centered‚Äù.  There appears to be a lot of ways to get data into the system from the field, but not many ways to get it out.

It looks like JC ADS has a client interface for the SNE devices over its own, presumably, proprietary protocol.  It also appears to natively connect to BACnet/IP devices.  What I don‚Äôt see is a way to expose the SNE or ADS software as a ‚Äúserver‚Äù for an external system to connect to.  I only see third-party protocol support on the ‚Äúfield‚Äù side of the SNE.  It‚Äôs not clear what the SNE can connect to ‚Äúupwards‚Äù other than the JC ADS software.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
-
First, decide how much of the JC system matters.  If the JC software does not play an important role, consider bypassing it.  Decoupling the field devices from the JC application with a more open gateway (e.g., Kepware, Maple Systems) could provide more flexibility.  The SNEs are ‚Äústranding‚Äù field data into a silo.  With an alternative gateway, all the field devices could be publishing and subscribing to a broker.  The JC ADS and other applications (e.g., Ignition, Canary) could connect to this.  It‚Äôs much more preferable to build context in a ‚Äúhub‚Äù (i.e., UNS) than in a spoke (i.e., JC ADS).

If the field devices are tightly coupled with the JC system and this cannot change, you‚Äôll need to find a way to get data out of the software.  Inquire if there is a way to expose the application as an OPC-UA Server or an MQTT client.  If not, you may need to take the context and publish ‚Äúdown‚Äù through one the SNE interfaces (e.g., OPC-UA Client, BACnet/IP) to a ‚Äúpseudo‚Äù field device.  The SNE could write to memory tags exposed as a OPC-UA Server from something like Ignition or Kepware.  Or, work with a protocol gateway company like RTA to develop a specific solution.

In short, figure out what level of context you need from these devices.  If you‚Äôre pulling from the SNE gateways or BACnet/IP layer, there won‚Äôt be a ton of context.  This is okay if there are bigger and better plans beyond the JC ADS and you plan to rearchitect.  If you simply need some existing building management data published into your IIoT infrastructure, look for a way to connect to the JC ADS software.  This is where the context is.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Not these, but others (e.g., Wittman, Fanuc).  The injection molding industry is very solution-centered.  The machine builders typically have their own proprietary controls.  They assume that plants are homogenous with one brand and series of machines.  They base their approach to software and connectivity around this.  At the same time, they're very active in Euromap and OPC Foundation.  Euromap, in general, is puzzling to me.  It's cool the machine builders coalesce around a standard, but they standardize things in weird ways.  

Euromap 67 is a not really a protocol, but a machine-to-machine discrete i/o implementation.  It's like integrating an injection molding machine with an old robot without a fieldbus.  It's basically a standardized handshake over dry contacts.  Because it's for machine tending robot applications (e.g., load, unload), the intelligence it will provide is limited.  With some interpreting logic, you could possibly derive availability (e.g., machine not ready) and utilization (e.g., cycling) information.

Euromap 63 is a file-based protocol.  I like to think of it as the "What if injection molding professionals tried to build a "data hub" (e.g., OPC Server, Broker) in Excel?" protocol.  The machines and apps read/write to a text file on a server.  In contrast to other protocols (e.g., HTTP, OPC, MQTT, E/IP, S7), Euromap 63 is perplexing.  Why use files?  I'm sure there is some reason and history behind it.  Perhaps it was originally intended for program transfers (think like direct numerical control on CNCs) and it blossomed into data collection?

Anyways, if you can get access to the machine builder's OPC-UA Server, use it.  Some machine builders actually create decent OPC-UA interfaces for their products.  It's much easier than setting up FTP connections, learning the nuances of the machine builder's Euromap implementation, and then mapping text fields into OPC tags. 
 Another option is to ask if they have a fieldbus interface.

Author: andymellor
Content: Andy, this is a bit outside of your question, but a little relevant. We work with a Schneider tool call EcoStruxure CENG Verification.  It is a static analyser for PLC code.  We've worked with it for about 5 years. The static analyser compares a set of standard rules or programming guidelines against your code and identifies deviations.  For instance you may not user backward jumps or your may have parameters in function blocks that are not being used.  Things that the compiler would be happy with.  The main use for this is companies with very large PLC programs looking for high availability in their PLCs.  Airports, Nuclear, Navy/Marine, Rail and so on.

Author: ales7315
Content:
The newer version of Arbug has an OPC UA interface. With some limitations (max number of clients, max number of tags, some tags are readable only if "expert" card is inserted in Arburg machine, etc.). 

In the past, we did one implementation on some older versions of Arburg, via RS232 and Selogica (I believe so). In that case, we used Siemens PLC with RS232 interface, on which we developed this custom protocol to communicate with Arburg. Communication speed and number of data were a challenge, RS232 has some limitations of course. It depends also on Arburgs cycle time - can all data be exchanged in one cycle?
In this case, Siemens PLC was our OPC UA server. 

I think it would be possible to develop the Selogica protocol in Kepware UCON. It would make sense to use some serial-to-ethernet converter, like Moxa Nport. 

I am not an expert, but my guess would be that Selogica was in use before EuromapXX and OPC UA were available.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Hmm, interesting challenge.  OPC-UA becomes very scarce at the low-cost end of the market.

Other suggestions:

- Here's a weird one.  IO-Link Master or similar with IIoT protocol.  One of the lesser-known benefits of these is that the ports can be used for discrete i/o.  It's very cost effective.  Put relays on the outputs. Check out IFM or Comtrol.

- Wago controller or remote i/o.  Some have OPC-UA onboard.

- Automation Direct controller or remote i/o (e.g., Click, Do-More, Stride).  MQTT is an option on some controllers.  If you can compromise with other Ethernet protocols like Modbus TCP, a lot of ultra low-cost options open up.

- FreeWave ZumEdge with IO expansion

- EZ Automation

But what about something where you don't need visualization you only need comms gateway? Author: koios6274
Content: Does Kepware have a way to be the edge gw / talk to all of the various devices at the local level (via poll/response) but then publish (preferably via sparkplug) to a centralized Broker?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Here's one way of approaching that application:
[Fanuc Robot] <- GE-SRTP -> [KEPServerEx] <- OPC-UA -> [HighByte] <- MQTT SpB -> [MQTT Broker]

Yes, it's best to keep move the native protocols to the edge of network.  This keeps the poll/response and unsecured traffic away from everything else.  This is accomplished by leveraging a gateway.  Ignition Edge is an option.  I believe this might be able to be licensed for just connectivity (e.g., drivers, MQTT transmitter) not necessarily as a local SCADA/HMI.  You could also use HighByte Intelligence Hub, Maple Systems cMT-SVR, etc.  Edge does not necessarily mean it has to be a physical gateway residing in a panel.  It could be on a centralized server.  The point is to avoid native protocols and OPC-UA client/server traversing rest of the network.  Past this point, the IIoT ecosystem can exchange intelligence with security pub/sub and discoverability.

Personally, I'm a fan of a segmentation.  I typically opt to put every operation (i.e., group of machines) or machine (i.e., group of devices) in its own VLAN.  First, this minimizes the broadcast domain for field traffic.  Second, it simplifies troubleshooting, management and security.  If an operation needs to reach another operation or be exposed to an centralized protocol gateway, it gets issued a role associated with a policy to do so.  By segmenting and identifying everything, the infrastructure can be intent-based and self-aware.

The purdue security model implementations typically involve standing up rigid DMZs at each level of the ISA95 stack.  This is well-intentioned, but doesn't scale well in most environments.  Many orgs don't know what's on their industrial network and what the traffic should be.  They just know when something is down.  Combine this with manually administering DMZs explicitly rule-by-rule and appliance-by-appliance, and it does not serve anyone well.  It's also not particularly effective against internal breaches within a layer.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Why not just go from Kepware to the MQTT broker?  Kepware supports publishing to an MQTT broker without any intermediary software.  Sparkplug is overrated. üòâ

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
That's option too.  It works well in certain use cases.  

The Kepware MQTT interface, however, requires additional licensing which can cost almost as much as HighByte.  And HighByte does a lot more than publish large JSON payloads to a topic.  In addition to sparkplug, it also has "vanilla" MQTT interfaces.  I acknowledge that using two gateways can appear counterintuitive.  The modeling, above everything else, is the reason to pair the two.  The Kepware plugins, such as Advanced Tags or Scheduler, can't come close.

Most Fanuc-based assets aren't all that contextual off-the-wire anyways.  They still have old-school, register-based addressing and no memory structures.  The implementations, especially on CNCs, vary wildly.  They almost always require extensive modeling work to make their data useful.

Elsewhere, they have primary and secondary interfaces for just about every fieldbus protocol. Author: rickbullotta
Content: Let‚Äôs fix Sparkplug first.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Do you mind going into detail on your Sparkplug grievances?  You should let @Arlen Nipper and company know.

My critiques are on segmentation.  The whole Group/Edge/Device thing can create contention organizing the structure of the data.  The topics get very big very quickly.  It would be nice have something that is more semantical than structures and naming conventions.  But, it's good enough relative to other solutions.

Also, it was born out of the energy industry and is very telemetry-focused.  It's clunky doing structured services over it.  It's great at moving i/o and data sets, but not necessarily transactions.  Think of the APIs found in an MES or ERP.  These can have quite a bit of business logic involved and, as a result, require a particular handshake.

Author: leightaylorf1
Content:
Hi all. I have a question related to the edge use of MQTT and/or SpB and controls/setpoints from the topend system (lets say ignition).

I love this model of connection from the edge up and all the benefit this brings, however how would the Edge know that a Control/Setpoint it needed to know about had changed state/value?
My worry is that unless an Report by Exception event occurred (on the edge device)the Control/Setpoint would not move out to the edge until the edge made contact.
I understand that you could publish to the edge control/setpoint but would this mean opening up and inbound connection to the edge device from the topend?

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: The client makes the connection, but it is persistent. A control setpoint change would be received by the client at time of change.

Author: rickbullotta

Author: youri.regnaud
Content: https://solace.com/blog/topic-hierarchy-best-practices/ A good article about topic namespace for applications (MES, ERP, CMMS, ...)

Author: rickbullotta
Content: That article is super vague - could use some specific examples.  Also, in general I'm not a huge fan of versioning embedded in naming/topics.

Author: andersgustav
Content: Are you sure that not some of these fixes to MQTT already is there in MQTT 5?

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
99% sure they aren't there.  And the implementation of request/response in MQTT 5 is an ugly hack IMO - it needs to be done correctly or at least a better pattern on top of "plain" MQTT.  If we want to implement event-driven apps, a better path would have been to have both response and error topics.  But there's so much that needs fixing with request/response (which DCMD doesn't really fix), that some major surgery is needed or a completely different invocation path.  

Topic aliases aren't really topic aliases - MQTT would benefit hugely from true topic aliases which would allow multiple projections of topic namespaces/UNS's optimized for different purposes (e.g. devices could publish into a device-centric namespace, which could be mapped transparently into an asset or other organizational namespace - kinda like symlinks).  

Topics should have optional metadata (durable attributes of a topic), and creating child topics is a crappy way to do this (leads to topic bloat).  This metadata would be useful for a number of things, including providing search parameters for discovery APIs and for enabling far better kinds of wildcard subscriptions.  MQTT needs a discovery API, desperately.  Something far more flexible and considerably less "chunky" than the way Sparkplug does it.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
On the issue of "chunkiness" and lack of granularity in Sparkplug (which is one of my major issues), pumping all data updates through a single topic isn't all that optimal in many use cases, so you still end up having to map into another namespace for easier, more application-friendly consumption or interaction.  I've heard the argument repeatedly that "you can still use plain MQTT in parallel" - which of course you can, but this requires a ton of additional work and mapping.  The antithesis of the supposed plug-and-play nature of Sparkplug, which is basically a super generic entity model rather than knowing that X is a pump, Y is a storage tank, Z is a case packer, etc...

I have some concerns about base data types as well :  I'm not sure why they chose coarse grained timestamps (milliseconds aren't enough in some applications), not sure why there aren't richer concepts around device types or reusable models, and there are some similar odd semantics around Template(s), very little control over subscription/notification granularity (e.g. no deadbanding or time boxing), lack of common IoT data types in the base type model (location being a glaring omission, no blob type, etc), and so on. 

Anyway, they're both a starting point and don't need to be scrapped, but there's a lot of room for improvement and enhancement in both MQTT and Sparkplug.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: I would go a step further and say don't ever put versions into your topics. Instead do schema evolution for your data in a backwards compatible way. In general using versioning for any kind of interface often doesn't add much. For example in the end another version of REST interface is just a different REST interface. Is it really relevant that the user of the interface knows that the one endpoint is related to the other endpoint in a predecessor-successor relation? Maybe sometimes.

Author: andyott33
Content:
Hello all, I would like to get feedback from the community for IoT features or general features that you would like to see in a VFD. I have received a request from the Lenze Application Engineer (AE) Manager to create a wish list of features that I would like to see in the VFD that we typically use (Lenze i550 Protec). The Lenze AE manager said it would be great to get feedback from this community.

Current items in the wish list:
- Support MQTT and MQTT/Sparkplug B (Lenze does sell a Drive that supports MQTT already - https://www.automationworld.com/PEC-2020/article/21202280/iiotenabled-multipurpose-servo-drive)
- Built-in PLC

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
MQTT/SpB is a great start.  I went through internal standards and added [more than] a few things.  Hopefully this does not make the the unit prohibitively expensive.

-Mainstream fieldbus support (e.g., EtherNet/IP, PROFINET, EtherCAT) with integrated motion and safety (e.g., CIP Safety, PROFIsafe, FSoE)

-Support for both general and motion instructions.  Sometimes its nice to program a drive as axis of motion and other times it's not.  Sometimes, motion control is not even an option on some controllers.  Having options makes one flexible.

-PLC software libraries (e.g., Add-On-Instruction/Profiles, Function Blocks) for programming and setup

-Dynamic UDTs that expose all data but "hide" what's not being used.  It's annoying sorting through "null" parameters tied to features not being used.

-Reference projects and libraries for major platforms to consume these UDTs (e.g., Ignition Perspective, AWS, Canary).

-Technical marketing collateral on how to implement predictive maintenance practices and leverage the intelligence coming off the drive.  They should be showing how to orchestrate this in third-party platforms and CMMS/EAM apps.

-Available companion accessories (e.g., line reactor/filters, resistance breaks, encoders)

-"Modular" commissioning software.  Ideally, something that doesn't require downloading every version of every product.  There should be easy way to install/update for just what's needed.  After finally creating an account to login and locate what software is needed, there's nothing worse than installing a massive application to simply run a setup procedure or set a few parameters.  In other words, make it easy, but don't make it bloated.

-Perhaps some sort of CLI or HTTP console to avoid installing software and all the lifecycling headaches that comes with that?

-Strive to make as much management as reasonably possible available in mainstream PLC development environments (e.g., Studio 5000, TIA Portal, TwinCAT 3)

Content: I'm not sure if this is the right feed or not but does anyone have any experience with Opto22 communication with GE/Emerson PLC's?  I reached out to their customer service and they have been ZERO help and can't even tell me if its possible.  I gave them simple use case requirements and pretty much hit a wall.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:

For example, are you trying to connect Opto22 I/O to the GE PLC?  Or, is the GE PLC connecting to an Opto22 Groov EPIC?  Or, something else?

Author: jester7896
Content:
most of our Processors are either CPE305 or CPE400.  GE/Emerson plc's do not have an abundance of communication drivers to speak of.  the Indusoft we are currently uses has a kepware type driver on the backend that is included.  The Ge/Emerson PLC's use SRTP protocol and have some Modbus capabilities that can be a PITA in certain applications.

as far as intended application... Basically we currently have an IPC sitting on every one of our standard weld cells running 2 independent displays and Indusoft HMI software.  Indusoft was recently acquired by Aveva and they pulled sales from our supplier and the price got jacked up.  so I am looking for a replacement.  It needs to be on-machine (For Now) and have the ability to push a display to 2 seperate 40" screens.  I told the Opto22 rep I would prefer 2 HDMI connections but could work with other options as long as I could push the different screens to 2 displays.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Which Opto22 product are you wishing to use to replace the Indusoft HMI?  What protocol does this speak?  I thought they just made hardware that could run Ignition Edge?

Since the devices speak SRTP, I would look into connecting them to Kepware with the GE Open Ethernet drivers.  This will allow you to expose the GE CPE305 and CPE400 as an OPC-UA Server or MQTT client to your infrastructure.  I use a similar setup for Fanuc robots.  From here, really any HMI solution could be used (e.g., Ignition).  You could run the HMI clients on the industrial PCs.

Other gateway and/or HMI solutions with SRTP drivers:   Proface, Maple Systems, Red Lion.

Author: jester7896
Content:
Unfortunately I really need an on-machine solution for this.  we trialed the red lion system before but they are built for 1 screen only so it doubles the cost and complexity for 2.  

I was looking for their recommendation on a device but hit a wall when talking protocols.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Could you be more specific the "on-machine" requirement?  Kepware + Ignition Edge can be deployed on industrial PC.  They don't necessarily have to be large, server-based SCADA deployments.

Most apps/devices will not support SRTP natively.  Most likely, a gateway will be required.  It can be software (e.g., Kepware) or hardware (e.g., Maple Systems).

Two screens coming from one device is probably best done with a software-based HMI (e.g., Ignition Edge).  The only other solution I could think of possibly is to explore if Proface has a product with an auxiliary monitor option.  A less elegant, but lower-cost solution might involve using two "headless" HMIs from ProFace (SP5000 Open Box) or Maple Systems (cMT-SVR).

Author: jester7896
Content: I guess I considered an individual Kepware instance on every machine cost prohibitive.  Indusoft used to cost us around 650$ for the license which included the kepware type-backend. I didn't look into Ignition Edge but that may be an alternative.  Depending on the cost of the combo it may be a good solution.

Author: benveenema
Content:
Rockwell/Allen Bradley noob here:

I need to connect to and modify a couple of programs on old CompactLogix L32E and MicroLogix 1500. Our only version of RSLogix is installed on an old Windows XP machine and I've been told by maintenance that "the license can't transfer to a new PC"

Author: benveenema
Content: I'm wondering how true this is and if there's any new software from Rockwell that would let me connect to these PLCs and make a few small changes.

Author: benveenema
Content: Free or cheap would be best. We don't do much with Allen Bradley if we can avoid it and I'd rather not throw $$$$ at them for something I won't use much.

Author: benveenema
Content: I've reached out to our Rockwell Distributor (Horizon) but have not heard back yet.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I know more about licensing automation software more than I'd care to.  It's surprisingly non-trivial to figure out what is optimal.  It's almost as bad as Microsoft, Cisco, or even Oracle.  And it's not just Rockwell.  Siemens, Fanuc, and others are a pain too.

All licenses should be transferable.  There should be some license file residing on the machine.  You would use the FactoryTalk Activation Manager utility to "re-host" the license.  This can be downloaded from the Rockwell portal.  Basically, you would check in the license to your Rockwell account using the utility and then check it out to "host" it on the new workstation.  It will be helpful to know the customer no, serial no, product key, etc.

If you want to bypass the licensing transfer debacle, take a look into the new subscription licensing.  You could purchase the software for just a year.  Unfortunately, because you're using CompactLogix and MicroLogix, they each require a different development environment to program.  CompactLogix are programmed with Studio 5000 (aka RSLogix 5000 for older firmware levels).  MicroLogix 1500 is programmed with RSLogix 500.  Check out the Studio 5000 Legacy Edition bundles.  This will include both development environments and everything else for the old architecture (e.g., SLC, MicroLogix) and the new (e.g., CompactLogix, ControlLogix).

If I recall, there might be a 30-day grace period for activation.  This might allow you to make the small changes on your own workstations without messing with the legacy Windows XP deployment.

Author: geoffrobinson
Content: A few years ago we built a service that gather a number of PLC tags (via an OPC Server) into a message in order to interact with a Rest api. The system uses a couple of boolean flags to signal when the message is ready/received and then similarly when the response is delivered/processed. In other words it allows the PLC to behave transactionally. We now have to rebuild it because the opc client library (ClientAce) we used is no longer supported.  Is anyone aware of an existing tool that can do this sort of thing? - or perhaps know of a different approach? I looked at Highbyte but it only works in one direction and so can't write back to the boolean flag.

Content: Zenoh will need more adoption before it's completely viable. It is similar to MQTT with topic/payload structure and brokers, but it adds mesh between clients, db query using the namespace or topic, evals which are functions that can run on data to produce information to be queried, and data localization, all within the protocol.

Author: mparris
Content:
I have two use cases that are likely two different products, but maybe not: 1) general compute and 2) limited IO.

if a single device, it would look like the following:

**Industrial device, din rail, 24vdc in
**Raspberry pi 4- class compute capability
**Local web-based GUI to manage network interface settings, NTP server, device hostname, etc
**Run docker containers
**Limited IO (2inputs, 2 dry-contact out) available through an embedded opc ua server
**Ability to power through POE

Author: mparris
Content: There are some industrial raspberry pi 4 devices slated to be released. I've messed with ubuntu and the Cockpit Project, but would rather have something more out of the box and minimalistic to get a simple docker interface

Content: OK fun, let's keep going with this... If you had that device, what would you be able to do (or do better) that you can't do now?

Author: mparris
Content:
The number of IO devices that support OPC UA is limited. It's difficult to find one with a few IO points that is less than $300. The Advantech ADAM6760D is a good example but costs more.

Most industrial PCs are in the $500-$700 range, but are Intel processors with larger storage and more ram.

There are use cases where some compute is needed and maybe an interface to a photoeye or stack light or other device using discrete IO. but nothing to the scale that justifies over $1k.

So functionally, it wouldn't be adding any benefit, but would be reducing cost, decreasing footprint by combining the compute and IO into a smaller package, and reducing setup time by having these functions more readily available out of the box rather than having to set them up from scratch.

Author: mparris
Content: Many embedded devices that offer IO require some sort of development with their proprietary SDK.  Having this device expose the embedded IO through OPC-UA would keep the application running in a container to reuse any code by accessing the OPC UA through opc.tcp://localhost:4840

Author: mparris
Content:
Regarding the latest OPC FLC (field-level-communications), how big of a pain-point is it to get PLCs of different vendors to communicate with each other.

As an end-user, I'm of the opinion that receiving multiple vendors of PLCs into the facility increases risk and cost of training maintenance, spare-parts, etc.

Having a system with multiple vendors (the primary use-case for FLC), seems like a bad idea from the get-go, but would like the opinion of others...

Author: mparris
Content: I think the controller-to-controller has been solved today through protocol gateways, but again, making this painful has been useful for facilities to remain consistent with the PLC platform that is in use.

Author: mparris
Content: Now, the future work of Controller-to-Device seems way more valuable, where devices of multiple vendors should be able to connect to multiple vendors of PLCs.  I could see that unlocking capability for end-users and simplifying a deployed ecosystem

Author: rickbullotta
Content: ...and you'll *STILL* need to map into each PLC's unique addressing scheme at some point.  There's something to be said for just running an wire from an output of one PLC to an input on another...you still get to communicate at the speed of light, with a lot less to go wrong.

Author: mparris
Content: So, you're not optimistic that they developed some level of consensus regarding prescriptive modeling that each PLC will understand out of the box? ü§£

Author: rickbullotta
Content: The presence or absence of positive voltage or infinite/zero resistance is the one protocol they all understand.

Author: akoscs
Content: The FLC tries to solve a problem, which already has been solved by fieldbusses (mainly CanOpen, ProfiNet, sercos and EtherCAT). However, it tries to leverage existing OPC-UA technology to do this. At the field level, they will be just another fieldbus, I did not yet hear of any feature, which e.g. EtherCAT does not already support. The one big thing would be TSN to make it both real-time capable and fully IP-layer compliant (which none of the above have, but with TSN they also could implement, with the exception of CAN). At this level, even a comp spec based standardization of device data model will not bring much, since at the field level the above 4 fieldbuses already have standardized data models (well, not all of them independent ones, some borrow from eachother). So hopefully OPC-UA will also borrow the information models for field level devices (e.g. DS402 for drive amps) and not create completely new ones.

Author: akoscs
Content: you would need to crank up the I/O scan times üôÇ

Author: mparris
Content:
Thanks for the detail.

Regarding information modeling for FLC, do you know if they have solved the most basic use-case: accessing IO of a device?

For example, if I have two PLCs from two different vendors, I can access PLC1.card5.INPUT3 and PLC2. card2.OUTPUT4 and there is zero ambiguity of what is being accessed?

In OPC UA land, I've seen PLCs use whatever naming avenue they want, and it varies from vendor to vendor

Author: paul_kopcak
Content: If you are surprised about Modbus being so widely used.  There are many multi-billion dollar companies still using legacy PLC's.  Such as SLC-150, PLC-5, SLC-500 and so on.  My last employer was one of them.  My major project four three years ago was updating a Windows 98 SE industrial PC to a PanelView Plus 1000 on a SIMATIC TI-505 PLC.  Also, get it to populate with OPC-UA and figure out how to translate Visual Basic scripts into FTV macros.  Did I mention Rockwell engineering support said it cannot be done.  Siemens charged $200 per hour just to ask questions not guaranteeing answers.  After six months on the project DONE.  Mission accomplished with pushing the operational performance of the PVP 10 performance model with FTV version 9.   Too many large corporations create unnecessary problems that lead to over convoluted solutions.  So pay now or pay later but your going to pay.  Usually, more payment in the future than they are willing to admit or own.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
That's a good question about the prevalence of Modbus.  SIMATIC, as a brand, has technically been around since the 1950s.  It had a solid foot in industry before the Modicon 084 PLC came out in the late 60s.  Between this period and the advent of PROFIBUS in the early 90s, there were all sorts of early serial protocols (e.g., AS511 in the S5 era).

I would say another contributing factor is Germany's natural resources.  Germany is much more likely to import oil and gas than produce it.  Hoppe is far less likely to see what Nipper has seen in the American-Southwest.  I suspect that industrial assets in the energy sector make up the lion's share of legacy nodes.  Anecdotally, I hear of all sorts of ancient Modicon and Allen-Bradley controllers still chugging along in this sector.

Personally, I have not encountered much Modbus in discrete manufacturing.  But that's because I'm generally working with Rockwell, Fanuc, and Siemens.  Regardless, Modbus is almost always an interface option.  It's easier to find a Modbus interface than it is OPC-UA or MQTT.  Fieldbus (and protocols in general) adoption has always been function of automation brand than consumer choice.  If one has spent their career around Siemens or Beckhoff, they're only seeing a slice of the global automation market.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Interestingly, out of all the flagship "IO level" companion specs, Modbus is absent.  Present are EtherCAT, EtherNet/IP, IO-Link, CANopen, PROFINET, POWERLINK, CC-Link, and SERCOS.  To the OPC Foundation's credit, the "owner" of modbus, Schneider Electric is present in the FLC initiative.  But, Schneider's "byzantine empire" of a portfolio also has preferential support for EtherNet/IP, SRTP, etc.  It's just odd that a company can be working on Modbus/TLS and OPC-UA FLC/TSN in parallel.  It's confusing for the consumer.  Perhaps Schneider is bearish on OPC-UA (beyond basic Client/Server Data Access) and hedging it by enhancing good-old Modbus with security?

In terms of fostering adoption, I must call into question any strategy that prioritizes POWERLINK and SERCOS nodes over Modbus.  There are probably more Modbus nodes produced each year than B&R or Bosch-Rexroth have produced in a decade or even a lifetime.  Sure, Modbus is just register-value pairs.  But, in practice, are other fieldbuses much more?  For example, most EtherNet/IP nodes barely scratch the surface of what the ODVA CIP spec is capable of.  If one is serious about adoption, wouldn't there be a "seamlessly map your modbus registers into an information model today" marketing campaign?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: here's the thing though...almost all of those old/creaky/legacy PLCs and controllers are already connected up to some kind of SCADA, DCS, and/or historian.  That's where we should be integrating with them - not adding more comms load, security risk, complexity and fragility by connecting directly to the controllers.

Author: mparris
Content:
I think that the latest architectures must assume a higher level application, since those devices are typically limited to four connections or so. You will need to aggregate it to a more powerful piece of hardware. Coupled to security concerns as you mentioned, there will most certainly always be a gateway. So this begs the question if it's worth the monumental task to standardize on a common protocol at the device level.

Should the link between the PLC and SCADA be solved? That seems to already be covered by software like Kepware.

So the real value is above SCADA and into MES and above.

So definitely confused by the enthusiasm for FLC of having all the PLCs talk the same language.  If it's real, it will be nice, but there's a good chance that these companies are all playing lip-service to appear to be cooperative and progressive.

The big push should be with DataOps as suggested by @js and targeting MES platforms to make this more feasible.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
This is great point.  I have a very similar mindset that people over-value the edge data.  It's there and useful, but it's little context.  Machine control technology is too rigid and limited to gather context at scale.  Industrial HMIs suck more than ERP or MES interfaces.  Why do we think this will elicit more context?

You're spot on about SCADA/DCS should be the gateway to the brownfield intelligence.  But, none of the technology standards focus on this in a meaningful way.  It's all about collecting data from the edge to relay to the cloud for monetized compute and processing.  It's the most lazy "fleet" use cases.  Every cloud provider or telecom company wants to provide low-context data collection and analytics for the low-low price of x per y per z.  Any org with sufficient scale and homogeneity in assets is going to eventually elect to do this themselves for less.  If we were serious about SCADA/DCS as gateway, we would see more than the basic OPC-UA-DA or HTTP interfaces.  For example, why aren't there OPC-UA information models with reference architectures for FactoryTalk, WinCC, DeltaV, Wonderware, Ignition etc?  Why isn't there standard way to expose all the proprietary alarm modules these applications have?  What about process values and units of measure?  What about OEE inputs?  What about asset state?  Recipe management?

Author: du5tins
Content: With SP-B you want retain on. The published birth and death certificates will let the client know if the data is stale or not.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: But that‚Äôs pretty easy with most brokers.

Author: dep05d
Content: I believe the only retained message spB uses are for primary host id (STATE/scada_host_id).  Device and Node BIRTH/DEATH message are not published as retained.  From observation of the MQTT Engine module, I think it's the clients responsibility to issue rebirth requests to all previously discovered nodes upon connection, assuming bad quality until that new (re)birth message arrives.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @dep05d, you just advanced to level 3!

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Great example of why I made my comment.  They all should be retained IMO, since they're also timestamped.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Another thought is that even with "plain" MQTT, it would be desirable to store topic values in VT or VTQ format (value, time and quality) so that the "freshness" of the data was implicit.

Author: dep05d
Content: That's what we do when we decode and flatten the spb payloads, however the quality value is also RBE, so you either have to update the previous VT payload, or store quality in a separate topic.  I agree data/birth/death should all be retained.  I recall a sparkplug webinar where it was mentioned all messages were QOS 0 due to the danger of delayed command execution; I wonder if the lack of retain comes from a similar perspective.

Author: mparris
Content:
I think it's an issue of how valuable is stale data.

Take the case that a device comes online and issues a BIRTH certificate (with retain = true as you are proposing).

Then a month later, you have a consumer device join the network and get that BIRTH certificate.  Is that month-old data valuable?

Author: mparris
Content:
I think one improvement is to split the BIRTH certificate into two items: (1) the template of values that the device has and (2) latest values.

So, having the values broken out by individual topic, and potentially selecting which values are okay for retain = true can be done by the device on a item-by-item basis. so if there is some adverse effect from getting stale data on a certain topic, the retain can be disabled

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I personally think it is ridiculous to not persist device metadata (half of the *BIRTH content).  Application tooling should and must be able to discover this even when device(s) aren't connected.  I'd go so far as to say that that information should also be available via a REST API so that it isn't necessary to spin up subscriptions and such, and so that metadata can be queried more flexibly.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Also, I think a good enhancement to the MQTT spec would be to allow subscribers/clients to request "retain" on topics of interest to them.  It's the broker that handles it anyway, not the publisher.

Author: mparris
Content:
I don't exclude OPC UA as an option. All options are on the table to solve a problem.

I am, however, no longer interested in speculating what could be possible if OEMs would only implement OPC UA standards.  I am also tired of being encouraged by OPC UA advocates that if only end-users would ask for these standards then OEMs will implement them.

I am very much interested in the discussions of problems being solved and what products are available to make it happen.

After experiencing the work required to integrate hundreds of OPC UA servers and experiencing the ease of integrating hundreds of SparkplugB devices, the benefits cannot be overstated.

In the scope of data access, OPC UA and Sparkplug are both tools to do the job, but at some point one must ask if it's worth chiseling letters into stone vs writing them on paper. As you would say, it depends on the requirements, so if "the writing shall survive rain" then stone is an option, but know that there are other quicker options.

The kick in the teeth is that OPC UA could have implemented the concepts of Sparkplug, but they didn't. Sparkplug was commercially available 2 years prior to the release of the OPC UA pub/sub spec, and even then they failed to spec out the ability to discover other devices (topic standardization). And now nearly 4 years later, the best function I can find in Azure, the most staunch cloud supporter of OPC UA, is that they can decode any JSON payload over MQTT...no native OPC UA parsing included. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Author: mparris
Content:
Going forward, for the majority of applications that are interested in pushing data up from isolated networks on the plant floor using gateways, it will be difficult to convince end users to invest in OPC UA aggregators to connect to devices when MQTT brokers are much cheaper and less complicated to configure and allows OT to control the connection from their equipment to IT's services.

It could be the case that end users still prefer implementing the"Kepware" strategy which is to connect directly to devices over their native protocol, then it's a question of what protocol to use for the next hop. Maybe it's goes to a database, historian, MQTT broker, or other OPC UA client. So I'm still confused on how the unified vision of OPC UA from sensor to the cloud will be realized.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Well, someone needs to implement the ‚ÄúKepware Strategy‚Äù.  The data isn‚Äôt going to magically jump from the PLC to the broker on its own.  üôÇ

Author: mparris
Content:
Yes, my comment was more of a centralized gateway (Kepware) vs decentralized gateways (devices at each piece of equipment or native devices).

In the centralized approach, there's less opportunity for OPC UA to help, since once the data has been ingested via fieldbus, it can exit via any number of protocols.

In the decentralized approach, that's an opportunity for OPC UA to be used between the gateway and the central IT infrastructure, but should be compared to Sparkplug as well, which I think is easier to integrate for data access applications.

Author: mparris
Content:
All that to say, it's not clear to me where OPC UA properly fits into an Enterprise.

Not many historians use Historical Access. Cloud providers don't use it to ingrst data. Some PLCs use it in server only.

It's sweet spot is foggy, which likely also is contributing to lack of adoption (negative feedback loop)

Author: rickbullotta
Content: My take thus far is that Sparkplug is ok for a SCADA app but not ideal for a UNS. Too opaque and ‚Äúlumpy‚Äù and device centric (vs the way it is best represented in a UNS that may blend data from many devices into a better unified model. Blending Sparkplug and ‚Äúregular‚Äù MQTT topic naming seems ideal.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: The true sweet spot is as a replacement for OPC DA that is platform agnostic and doesn‚Äôt use DCOM.

Content:
Hey... question for those who maybe have done it... can I have two or more edge nodes publish into the same group/edgenode/device in SP-B? On the surface I think it works but eliminates some of the benefits of SP-B.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It would be a bad idea because of the way DBIRTH and DDEATH messages work

Author: mparris
Content:
Don't do it.

Just ask @DavidSchultz 

You'll get into a loop of a device publishing a metric, the Primary application not understanding the metric and requesting a birth certificate, both devices publishing their birth certificates, a race condition on which arrives at the primary application first, receiving a metric from the device whose birth certificate arrived later, primary application not knowing the metric and requesting a birth certificate....repeat!

Author: du5tins
Content:

Do not let edge nodes and devices publish into already established edge nodes and devices. May cause unintended equipment operation or injury and death!

Also OPC UA information models can be useful to define the machine interface that a machine manufacturer must implement when they sell machines to you. Beyond that I've only seen people directly convert it to something else as a first step, be it through Kepserver or custom built gateway services.

Author: marc.jaeckle

Author: jbonhage155

Anyone know what advantages upgrading an OPC server from OPC DA to UA brings? (specifically in this case RSLinx to FactoryTalk Linx)

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Mostly just platform independence and easier network connectivity.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: Thanks. I'm getting confused on what side of the OPC server. To connect to the ControlLogix/PLC5/SLCs it would use the existing native protocol but on the server side it would publish the data in UA format instead of DA?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Just finished my last training on Kepserver. Yeah, DA means Windows DCOM which can be complicated to use outside of the localhost and nearly impossible to secure.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
FactoryTalk Linx (or really any modern OPC Server) will have interfaces for both OPC Classic and OPC-UA.  While the transport and payloads are different, the namespace is logically the same.  The same tag structure will show up in the ItemIDs when the client browses the server.

If you can, I would advise ditching FTLinx and using Kepware (e.g., Allen-Bradley Suite, Manufacturing Suite) instead.  It's a far more polished and intuitive product.   Rockwell actually embeds some of Kepware's own native drivers into one of the FTLinx versions ("KEPServer Enterprise").  I would only recommend sticking with FTLinx if there is across-the-board Rockwell investment as well as some of the security and device management features are in use.

As @Richard Shaw and @RickBullotta mentioned, the benefits are cross platform support and security.  Because UA transport is standard TCP/IP and sheds away COM/DCOM dependencies, a Windows OS is not required.  UA also provides transport security (i.e., TLS) and, if implemented, application security.  It's always good to "sunset" OPC Classic.

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
Great info, thank you! 

If the plant had existing OPC-DA servers would it be worth the effort to convert the servers to OPC-UA or instead use an IoT data driver which reads OPC-DA and converts to a target protocol? 

Or maybe that's not a great idea as Richard  mentioned that using OPC-DA means an IoT data driver would needs to traverse thru DCOM hell to get to to the target topic/data?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It all depends on what nodes you're working with.  What's currently connecting to these OPC-DA servers?  

**IIoT Connectivity for AB PLCs**
When you say existing OPC-DA servers, I'm assuming you mean a software gateway like RSLinx Classic?  In that case, yes, I would replace it.  This is an especially good idea if you no longer have an OPC Classic application nodes ("OPC-DA Clients").  Why bother converting to OPC Classic if it's eventually converted to something else?

As you can see, you have many options of the adapting native AB protocols.  You can use OPC-UA or you can bypass it all together.  It really depends on what other nodes and protocols you work with.  I personally prefer a Kepware + HighByte approach.  I like Kepware's wide selection of native drivers and I like HighByte to cleanse/organize the data coming through those drivers.

[AB PLC] <- E/IP or PCCC -> [Kepware] <- OPC-UA -> [HighByte] <- MQTT / SpB -> [Broker]
[AB PLC] <- E/IP or PCCC -> [Kepware w/ IoT GW] <- MQTT -> [Broker]
[AB PLC] <- E/IP or PCCC -> [Ignition w/ MQTT Transmitter] <- MQTT / SpB -> [Broker]
[AB PLC] <- E/IP or PCCC -> [RTA 460ETCQT] <- MQTT -> [Broker]

**Adapting OPC Classic Nodes**
If you still have some legacy nodes running OPC Classic, it's best to leave it at the edge and "tunnel" with OPC-UA.  For example, if there is a legacy app with only an OPC-DA Client interface, you can install a software gateway locally.  On one end of the gateway, the application would connect to OPC-DA Server interface.  On the other end, the gateway's OPC-UA Client interface would connect to an OPC-UA Server across the network.  

[Legacy App | OPC-DA Client] <- OPC-DA -> [Gateway] <- OPC-UA -> [OPC-UA Server]

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
In deciding on how to architect the data flow, does the size on the system impact your decisions?

Assuming the functionality out of a Kepware would be higher but would an IoT converter 'box' be simpler/more reliable ?

Author: hayden3921
Content: Anyone have any experience with Euromap 15?  I'm trying to connect to a Netstal IMM and publish to OPCUA, Kepware, MQTT...

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
No, but I'm familiar with other Euromap specs.  The name Euromap can be misleading because sometimes it's one of many OPC-UA specs (e.g., 83, 77, 79) , other times it's a flat text file protocol (e.g., 63), and other times it's multi-conductor "dry contact" connection (e.g., 67).

Euromap 15 is like an old-school fieldbus spec for injection molding focused MES apps to communicate with machines.  It uses BITBUS for transport.  BITBUS is an RS-485 fieldbus based on ancient IBM networking technology (SDLC).  In other words, it couldn't be anything further from Ethernet or TCP/IP.  You'll need some sort of gateway.

It looks like HARTING offers a Euromap 15 gateway.  Unfortunately, it's not compatible with any of the protocols you cited (e.g., MQTT, OPC-UA).  It has a REST server interface.  This makes sense as Euromap 15 is more of a "method-based" protocol consisting of request/response telegram messages for specific purposes (e.g., "What's the job?, "What's the status?").  It's not like a "data access" style protocol used for the SCADA or telemetry applications often associated with MQTT or OPC-UA.  You could use the HTTP client interface (e.g., "REST", "Web Services") on something like Ignition, HighByte or Kepware's IoT Gateway to execute calls against the HARTING gateway's REST interface.  The nice part about this approach is that you don't have to bother learning all the Euromap 15 commands and structure.

The other option is to roll your own.  This will require some knowledge of the Euromap 15 structure.  You could purchase an serial gateway device from Real Time Automation or HMS Networks.  These products can be configured basically create your own serial driver.  For example, you might define the structure of a telegram (e.g., header, line feed, carriage return) and then the gateway will parse out the payload for you.  If you already have Windows PCs with serial connections, look into Kepware's U-CON driver.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
-
Related links:
https://www.euromap.org/media/recommendations/15/1992/eu15p1.pdf
http://mica-container.com/container/Euromap15_Gateway/Euromap_15_Gateway_User_Manual.pdf
https://www.rtautomation.com/product/460aqt/
https://www.rtautomation.com/product/460aus/
https://www.kepware.com/en-us/products/kepserverex/drivers/u-con/

Author: hayden3921
Content: thanks for the quick reply, its frustrating how a new multi million dollar press requires such an outdated protocol.  The HARTING gateway looks simple enough to configure and according to the manual may publish to MQTT but the Netstal documentation I have refers to "Euromap 15 over TCP" so I will try the U-Con first as software/hardware is already installed for this.  Will let you know how I get on

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Absolutely.  It's so damn frustrating.  And if you try to spec otherwise, the machine builder will obstruct it like they've been asked to do something impossible.  It's even more frustrating when the standards bodies like the OPC Foundation pretend like this isn't a problem.  There are like nine different OPC-UA companion specs for Euromap and there is still brand-new, multi-million dollar machinery shipping without it.

That's good it's at least encapsulated over TCP/IP.  Serial interfaces are especially a pain with a lot of machines.  Beyond this, if you know the Euromap 15 commands you're after, it should be pretty straightforward.

What kills me about these scenarios is that one one simply can't "browse" the machine's registers for available data.   Every time one wants additional data, it's another engineering project.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It generally comes down to scale (e.g., number of devices) and scope (e.g., drivers, protocols, network).  A proper software gateway (e.g., Kepware) implementation is just as reliable as dedicated hardware gateway.  I would even make the argument that it's even more reliable because it's easier to maintain and lifecycle.  Kepware is a service and should be deployed on a server.  A server will be stable and managed as such.  It's not going to be a GPO guinea pig or break after patch Tuesday.  Policies designed for the laptop of the gullible employee opening emails from Nigerian princes are going to be different than for a server.  I'd recommend discussing this distinction with your IT department.

Do you need broad protocol support?  Software gateways tend to have more drivers.  Hardware gateways tend to focus on only the very most popular devices (e.g., Rockwell, Siemens, Modbus).  Maple Systems is a notable exception to this.

Do you have a lot of devices?  Software gateways tend to scale up much easier.  The cost of hardware gateways adds up quickly.  A handful of premium hardware gateways can cost about the same as Kepware deployment with a driver suite, plugins, etc.  This doesn't include the cost of installing hardware gateways.  At a certain point, it comes very obvious where the cost advantage is.

What does of edge of network mean to you?  Is the edge 1-2 hops from a network core with multi-gig uplinks?  Or, is it traversing a constrained WAN or cellular network?  If there is a constrained network or lack of network, a hardware gateway with pub/sub may work out best.  On the other hand, bigger plants to tend to have network infrastructure in place.  In these plants, the term "edge" may be more a physical than a topological or performance distinction.  For example, there may not be significant difference in performance between deploying a gateway in a machine panel next a PLC vs on a central server.  Both scenarios may handle a 100ms poll/response just fine.

Author: mparris
Content:
Comparing a standardized folder/metric structure VS a UDT:

which is easier to find instances of objects: folder instances within an expected location OR UDTs?

I haven't used Templates or UDTs before.  Can UDTs be placed in any folder and the script can locate them after a recursive search?

With two edge nodes that are intended to be the same"type", is there a parameter in the Sparkplug template that let's Ignition recognize they are from the same UDT type definition?

Can an edge node publish more than one template, allowing it to represent multiple, different objects simultaneously?

Author: jon.forbord
Content:
Recursively: yes
You can do both, but why even bother with UDTs at any layer if that‚Äôs the thinking. UDTs basically ‚Äúforce‚Äù standardization, and should be more robust. Other than that anything is possible without UDTs, with some carefully constructed scripts/expressions. 
Absolutely: versioning/variants of UDTs from different assets needs to be handled carefully. Having a UDT representing a AGV may just add more complexity down the line as changes are implemented. So if you‚Äôre implementing Sparkplug B on smaller assets that are identical, I‚Äôd say that there‚Äôs probably limited value using templates. What do you mean multiple templates? I‚Äôd use templates to standardize subassets within an edge node to put it that way. And Ignition has no problem if the templates are identical from different edge nodes. If there are variants, now that‚Äôs a different beast.

Author: mparris
Content:
I haven't used UDTs, but I'm assuming a script in Ignition could parse the tag provider looking for a UDT of type "Pump", for example.

I also assume that when a Sparkplug edge node publishes a template, it has a way to say it is of type "pump"?

And when a 2nd edge node also wants to publish as a type pump, Ignition will only see one definition of Pump, but two instances of this?

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Correct. I don‚Äôt know how it handles a conflict if there‚Äôs differences on those pumps. System.tag.browse(folder, type object (tag/UDT/folder), recursive = true, ‚Ä¶). Something along those lines.

Author: mparris
Content:
Yes, I think the main benefit of UDT rather than a well-defined folder structure is to allow something like:

system.tag.browse("path", {"typeId":"myUDT", "tagType":"UdtInstance","recursive":True})

which should detect all instances of a UDT of a certain type no matter where it resides within the tag provider structure.

Using the well-defined folder structure requires apriori knowledge of where the folders reside that represent the root-folder of the object.

Author: mparris
Content: My question regarding two UDTs from a single node using templates was more of if a node wanted to publish a pump and a motor, can that node publish two templates, one for each type (pump and motor) and Ignition would see them as two separate objects.  Or does Ignition see these two objects as a single, complex UDT containing a pump and motor?

Author: jon.forbord
Content: you can set up as many different types of templates as you‚Äôd like, and instances would be identified as whatever type they are. And you can have tags that are just normal tags right next to templates. And you can have templates that contain more templates..

Author: jon.forbord
Content: A subassy template with two pump template instances and three motor template instances and one valve..

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Yes, using UDTs is the easiest and most robust way to identify like objects in the tag provider.

Author: mparris
Content:
Given that, with the potential to switch what nodes publish what objects, UDTs are definitely the way to go.

It would be a nightmare keeping the consuming application up to date with configuration changes made on the publisher side if the nodes ever change what objects it's publishing when just using folder structures

Author: rickbullotta
Content: UDTs are also extremely useful for handing a group of values and their context as an atomic entity (eg events and alarms)

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: I use tags for dynamic data like pressure, temperature, level, flow, etc. with engineering units. Parameters are good for static data like Site, Area, AssetID and tag structure values (pumpNum, compNum, etc.).

With Kepserver it's windows only (and a 32bit application to boot) and a "heavyweight" client/configurator.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
The Siemens driver suite will run about $1.5-2k.  The manufacturing suite, which includes drives for nearly any PLC, is about $4k.  This is low enough that it would make it hard to justify processor updates solely for protocol support.  It would be worthwhile if it were part of a holistic modernization strategy that would involve rebuilding the programs in TIA Portal to enable other outcomes.

Kepware does not support PROFINET or PROFIBUS because these are not "vanilla" Ethernet or Serial protocols.  That is, they require special hardware with an ASIC to interface with.  They bypass the typical OSI stack of technologies in TCP/IP and RS-485 based protocols.  As a result, conventional PC and networking hardware can't connect to it.  But, this shouldn't be a problem because PROFINET and PROFIBUS are generally not intended for this.  They're intended to be a deterministic fieldbus for field devices (e.g., I/O, Motion, Safety).

Generally, one is not going to use the fieldbus (e.g., PROFIBUS, PROFINET) to access the memory tables on a Siemens S7 device from a SCADA or IIoT infrastructure.  They're going to use the native S7 protocol (RFC 1006).  This is actually the underlying protocol used in Kepware's Siemens TCP/IP driver.  Basically, every S7-300 or newer with an Ethernet interface supports this.  The only issues you might have is with an S7-300 without an Ethernet port.  You can purchase an Ethernet module for it.  This will add native S7 protocol support.  Or, if you can't add an Ethernet module, you can connect an external gateway to the PROFIBUS interface that does (among other things).

Options for retrofitting an S7-300 w/o an Ethernet interface:
https://discord.com/channels/738470295056416930/740336217580765245/818874764982222918

Author: cyberwrights
Content: Thanks @js - clearly there is more to consider here than I realized (no surprise) so I really appreciate you taking the time to lay it out like that. I need to re-read this a few times but can already see some of the fog beginning to clear, and you confirmed several of my assumptions. Pretty sure I now know more than this customer does about their hardware, and THAT should terrify anyone! Much appreciated.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: I forgot to mention one other thing.  One of the biggest differences between using a newer S7 processor with Kepware's drivers vs other options (e.g., S7-300, Ignition's Siemens drivers) is the automatic tag generation.  This automatically pulls in the tags through the native Siemens S7 protocol.  This is preferable to maintaining a list of tag names, memory register addresses, and datatypes.  If you anticipate making a lot of program changes or regularly modifying the asset(s), this can be incredibly useful.  Being able to browse the namespace of an asset or always target a specific UDT is so convenient.

Author: ales7315
Content:
If you need to connect legacy Siemens PLC without an ethernet option, it is sometimes easier to install a hw gateway. 
In this case, you don't need to make any major changes in the PLC and you can bridge OT and IT networks at the same time. 

You can check these examples, there are plenty of others on the market.  
PLC S7xxx->OPC UA/MQTT :
https://industrial.softing.com/products/gateways/gateways-for-access-of-controller-data/uagate-si.html 

Profibus/MPI to ethernet (Profibus->RFC1006->Kepware):  
https://industrial.softing.com/products/gateways/gateways-for-access-of-controller-data/echolink-s7-compact.html

If you have control over PLCs, then it is better to just upgrade controllers with original modules to get an ethernet connection.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I can answer that for me, but not completely in one reply üôÇ We currently have 3-4 installs of Kepserver in Azure, one for each of our manufacturing geographical regions and then piping the data over OPC/UA to our Tulip platforms. For the most part it "just works", but we consider it a method to talk to "legacy machines". It doesn't meet the minimum technical requirements. We're polling CNCs and PLCs from the cloud, so it's not super scalable. I've spent more time than I care to checking network connectivity, verifying IP addresses. Setting up tags. It can be somewhat fragile and requires static IPs which is a scalability issue of it's own.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Also due to the channel layout it has a very "rigid" path/tag/topic structure which can't conform to ISA-95 Part 2.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Also, because it's running in the cloud, it requires inbound network access.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Yeah, in my day job (Litmus) I'm starting to see two different sort of IIoT frameworks on a regular basis.  One is what you're describing, take data from the edge and send it to the cloud, and the other is to handle much of the work at the edge, with the cloud being used for centralized monitoring and advanced applications such as ML/AI development.  Both methods have their advantages and disadvantages, but I'm more partial with keeping things at the edge if you can.  It does lead to almost an extra layer, but it's a fairly useful layer since it can reduce the data that is being sent to the cloud without having to sacrifice much in the way of functionality.  This provides two huge advantage, reduction in latency and reduction in cloud costs.  That said, each application is different, and there can be some big advantages of just piping everything out to the cloud.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: That‚Äôs basically what Kepware‚Äôs business is today and has been for years.  Nothing new at all.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: What you should be doing, and I‚Äôve told any people at PTC this, is selling a MUCH cheaper version of ThingWorx at the edge and use ThingWorx federation to implement a hub and spoke model.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Full ThingWorx can run on most edge devices.  Most people at PTC really don‚Äôt seem to know how to best leverage ThingWorx.

If trying to have Kepware Edge to run on equipment outside the Enterprise (builders location, etc) it's a no-go

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
If one were to a build their own IoT device product and they "owned" everything in the stack, a ThingWorx client on the edge would be appropriate.  But, if it's something industrial with specific requirements (e.g., safety, motion, fieldbus), it may be impractical or cost prohibitive without sourcing from the industrial automation vendors.  A solution is needed for the native connectivity.

Here's an example.  Suppose there were a machine called the Omaromatic.  It has a custom user interface app and connectivity to ThingWorx.  But, the machine also has a Mitsubishi PLC with some servo drive inside.  Kepware would be used to connect the app to the PLC.  In this case, ThingWorx is not necessarily connecting to the PLC, but the app on the machine that is "supervising" the PLC.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I think Arduinos are good for VERY specific tasks and yes they are cheap, but I haven't had the best experience with them. Even a very simple program, which was reporting sensor output every second, would only run for a few hours before stalling. I assume it was some sort of memory leak, but as they are extremely memory limited, it didn't take long. It wasn't totally locked up because I could push a new program.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
Why not a purpose built system?  That's not a lot of I/O.  Perhaps an RPi compatible device with a Blues.io (Blues Wireless) Notecard + Notecarrier Pi?  $80 includes 10 years/500MB of global cellular data.  With enclosure, power supply, Pi device, I/O isolation, etc you'd probably be at 20% of the cost of RIO + Moxa but obviously a bit more DIY.

Or maybe something like MyDevices?  A ton of "ready to use" sensors + a gateway and managed service?  Plus, since the sensors are wireless you could theoretically have a much easier/cheaper site install.

https://store.mydevices.com/

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
I need a sanity check please. 

Say you had a bunch of PLCs you wanted to communiate to but corporate IT says the IoT/OPC servers should be hosted in a datacenter out of state. 
I've always been under the assumption those servers should be as close to the controllers as possible but maybe things have changed in 2022?!?!

Author: mparris
Content:
What are the communication requirements for applications needing PLC data? Frequency, amount is data, etc?

Generally, the further away from a PLC, the network latency increases, and potential cost of the business through bandwidth consumption moving PLC proprietary protocols through external data pipes.

I think you're right to think that it's generally better to connect to PLCs on-prem and convert to a more scalable protocol to leave the building

Author: rickbullotta
Content: And cybersecurity risk increases.

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
Currently there is no SCADA, only local control of the equipment via local PanelViews. A new MES is coming into town and needs data  to read some of the equipment data. I would assume MES needs data no faster than 1 sec therefore, having the IoT/OPC server 900 miles away may be ok? It will polling a bunch of Rockwell PLCs (and some Labview cRIOs) 

But I wonder down the road if we wanted to add a SCADA for more realtime control we might regret this decision? (a press of a SCADA stop button needs to make a 900 mile round trip to get back to the PLC) ... this is a medical device company and they have gone 20 years without SCADA so I think needed one is unlikely.

Overall I'm debating how much I should fight to have an OPC server on site.

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
I'm going to check how the network is set up between the plant and data center. 
Does the cybersecruity risk show itself in the hops it takes along the way?

Content: Ive done several systems where the SCADA comms were not OPC. The DA Server I cut my teeth on used  DAS MBTCP,  DAS ABCIP  drivers had to run on the old galaxy-repository machine. Or all of the ignition systems ive done use OPC right on the ignition gateway, often in the cloud. So if the MES is at that data center, I would expect OPC to be there as well

Can it reliablity poll lots of tags across large geographic areas?
