Author: ryankershaw
Content:
From an architecture standpoint, I usually see SCADA working next to an IIoT system, since both of them have different requirements.  Typically, the IIoT system is seen more as the enterprise system that is there to provide a return on investment, while the SCADA system is there to handle the critical applications in the plant.  Also, having everything run through a Level 0 <-> Cloud architecture is going to end up causing issues, especially in the case that you mentioned about the stop button (even worse, what happens if the connection is down at that moment?).  Ideally, you want to have some edge-level system that can act as a filter between the decisions that need to be made on the plant floor and the information that needs to be passed along.

Our ops and engineers did a good webinar a couple of months back where they described the SCADA/IIoT divide.  In terms of how the two would work together, it could essentially be boiled down to this:

Author: benveenema

I also checked with qmodbus and it shows the same behaviour. 
has anyone seen this behaviour before or has an idea whats the issue?

Author: p.j.leblanc
Content: I love the diagram.  In it, does the "IIoT" circle include broker and / or UNS or is that a separate layer not explicitly shown?

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @p.j.leblanc, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: ryankershaw
Content: The IIoT circle would include a broker, as for the UNS, as all good answers go, "it depends".  It really comes down to the architecture of the system.  The one shown is one, and one that could be seen as ideal with the SCADA and IIoT systems operating in parallel.  Definitely helps with latency and redundancy.  However, I do see a lot of clients looking to run the SCADA system in series between the PLC and IIoT systems (Historian could also be between the SCADA and IIoT systems, I've seen that too).  In that case, the diagram would need to be moved around to match.  So, to make a long answer just that much longer, yes, the green circle could represent the UNS, but an actual architecture drawing is probably going to look a little different.

Author: p.j.leblanc
Content: Thanks @Ryan Kershaw.  I appreciate the explanation.  I'll can dig through #reference-architectures for more detail.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Not a problem, and definitely something to research, it's the foundation of anything you put in later, so good to get it right the first time!  We always run workshops with our clients before we do anything else to go over their set up, and ensure that everything is ready to go.

Author: niravpatel16
Content: Hello Community. Which is the suitable edge device that provides the buffering sometimes called store and forward in the event the connection from the edge to the application node is broken. Edge will Poll PLC using the native driver and then pass data as OPC UA, MQTT, or SpB. I looked into Weintek CMT-SVR but it has a limitation of 50 tags with 10000 entires then FIFO. This may not be enough. Alternatively, I looked in the Ignition Edge which buffers for about 1 week but is this only good for the Ignition platform only. Will it support other nodes like Kepware?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: This is a software issue, not a device issue.  What‚Äôs the native driver?  You could likely use HighByte plus Kepware to do this.

Author: niravpatel16
Content: I understand the problem is application-based and not device driven. S7 is a native driver in my case. What is the ideal setup between Kepware and Highbyte? I have used Highbyte and I am aware it has store and forward but it needs to collect first from the source like OPC UA, MQTT, SQL, CSV, etc. I know MQTT supports Buffering. But in my case, I want to use OPC UA. So when data arrives from PLC to Kepware can you buffer the data in Kepware if the connection to Highbyte is lost?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: That‚Äôs highly unlikely (connection lost).   Don‚Äôt know about Kepware‚Äôs buffering.  The HighByte team wrote the Kepware software, so they‚Äôd know.  üôÇ

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Not to toot our own horn too much, but Litmus (litmus.io) would handle what you're looking for.  We have a built in OPC Client/Server, but we can also run it as a device, or you can skip over OPC-UA and just connect directly to the S7.  In either case, this would allow you to do store and forward.  As to how much could be stored, this would depend on the amount of memory available at the edge.  As for where the data would get passed to, that's up to you, it supports just about anything.

Could anyone help credibly speak to the reliability of the Opto 22 Grove Epic?  Thank you for your help!

Im not nailing the question here but I'm trying to elicit anything that might speak to this clients concerns. Was this true? Did Opto have a reputation of being unreliable  2. If so is there something in the development of the Groove Epic that mitigates that argument.

Content: Thanks man!

Content: I do remember Walker making off handed comments sometime on an old video where he said something along the lines of 'when Opto came out with the Groove epic, I was surprised, really? this is an Opto'  Anyway I'm fishing so I can disarm this person who's resistant.  I'm a fan for the record of Opto and the groove epic!

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
Back 20+ years ago there was basically Rockwell, Siemens, Modicon and Mitsubishi. Everything else was largely non-critical or hobbyist type applications. There was not the proliferation of factories that could make the hardware required for a PLC. If you look at the old G series, it is pretty basic stuff. But a lot of it is still in use. There were 22 products in all (hence the 22).

The comment was not so much that Opto did not make quality product, but they made basic product. Component quality is much better than is used to be. The reality is that Automation Direct makes a great product. The aforementioned companies use a lot of FUD to keep people away.

Start with the Opto22 is American made an 100% tested. And it is highly reliable. I will see if I can find something the speaks to the specific issue.

Content: OHH awesome stuff David!

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
Response from Garrick...

Nothing directly related to reliability.  More to our reputation for reliability.  Going back through our history, we have provided lifetime warranties on our I/O modules trusting that they will not fail.  We do not have planned obsolescence like many other manufacturers do in order to remove older hardware from the market.  This means we have Opto systems that have been deployed and are still supported that are over 30 years old.   

Opto 22 has always had very reliable hardware, it was trusted by James Cameron to go to the bottom of the ocean(life support).  We are in mission critical O&G, water & wastewater applications.

Author: mparris
Content:
Anyone know of an EtherCAT master that provides an open interface for an application running on a PC, allowing reading registers and configuring slave devices?

We use the Beckhoff EK9160, which exposes all the EtherCAT slave registers over OPC UA, but there are no options to configure the EtherCAT slaves through the OPC-UA interface.

Author: mparris
Content:
@Jon Forbord and @Jonny Wright

 I see the Bosch CtrlX may be a good option... Don't see any documentation for what the interface is of the EtherCAT Master Module

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Interesting use case.  Are you trying to prepare or test EtherCAT nodes before deploying them?

While these EtherCAT Masters are primarily intended for machine builders with PC-based controls, it looks like the drivers come with diagnostic software that might be able to handle the configuration duties.  Hopefully they provide something more than a library. 

https://www.advantech.com/products/ethercat-master-cards/sub_7d3c9775-8c30-4f65-83ec-755bee93b1d4
https://www.hilscher.com/products/product-groups/pc-cards/pci-express/cifx-50e-reecm/

 I would also check if the EtherCAT Technology Group or one of its partners have some sort of conformance and testing tool.

Another crazy idea might be to use a Beckhoff PLC?  Can you accomplish this over the native ADS API?  If not, taking a step further,  could you go online with TwinCAT and expose that as a service (e.g., WCF, HTTP)?

Author: mparris
Content:
I'm trying to see the feasibility of our PC-based control application to take on being the EtherCAT Master for EtherCAT slave IO devices. Right now, the EK9160 is our master exposing the data over OPC UA. Rather than going into the webGUI to configure each of the slaves for settings different than default, I'd rather have that within our own configuration file that gets backed-up and is under revision control.

It could also be a reduction in cost, as the EK1100 is cheaper than an EK9160.  I suspect that any additional Beckhoff software licensing won't save us money than what we are doing today...

I wonder why there is no USB adapter. Most EtherCAT is 100Mbps, which would handle the low-level, fast moving EtherCAT traffic (without burdening the CPU) then should be able to have some virtual UART interface for the software to get the data, which shouldn't be an issue even for USB2 at 480Mbps.  Having a USB would also alleviate the need to have low-level drivers in the OS (like WinPcap). Having a LAN adapter could be better as that would let the application reside within a docker container.

Even Hilscher has this device:
https://www.hilscher.com/products/product-groups/pc-cards/m2/cifx-m223090ae-refecs/?&techCats=8

Also, I thought this was a good option, but was quoted to me at twice the cost of the EK9160
https://www.hilscher.com/products/product-groups/gateways/for-the-control-cabinet-ip20/lan-gateways/nhst-t100-enecm/?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I really dislike Fanuc products for similar reasons.  One can manage logic and programs in their software, but the configuration is managed directly on the controller's HMI.

This is a big problem with industrial automation.  One can back up the program, but not necessarily the configuration.  Doing a simple update to a node on a field network requires someone in-the-know.  A GUI doesn't abstract the complexity away if one is not a subject matter expert and disciplined to track/document changes.

My understanding of TwinCAT is that the runtime is licensed, but the IDE and associated services are not.  I was curious if these EtherCAT network config settings were exposed via the ADS interface.  Or, if the IDE could manage the settings and somehow be exposed as a service to your application.

I wonder if the issue might be EtherCAT.  Because it requires an ASIC, it will drive up cost and limit its audience and even further drive up cost.  Does your application benefit from EtherCAT's performance?  Could you get away using the same kind of field devices with EtherNet/IP?  This opens up a ton of "hardware-less" possibilities.  

That's a good question about USB.  Throughput should be no problem.  Perhaps it's a determinism or implementation issues.  Usually, with fieldbus stuff, OEMs aren't looking for a mainstream OS like Windows.  It's more licensing cost and bloat.  It's going to be implemented for more specialized embedded systems at the firmware-level or for an RTOS.

It doesn't surprise me the Hilscher interfaces cost more than a complete product with the interfaces.  I would check if HMS Networks has anything.  I wonder if you could have RTA build something for you.

Author: mriiot
Content: You can dump the config of a Fanuc, just need to walk all the registers via API.  Oem should have the ladder.

Author: bladesandrazors
Content: hej, has the supervisory device in bacnet ms tp to be at the end of line or can it be placed anywhere in the bus like modbus?

Author: akoscs
Content: You can get a TwinCAT instance and you can automate the ‚Äúengineering‚Äù tasks, usually done n Visual Studio (and the TwinCAT plugins) peogramatically using their API. That is one option, you only need a TwinCAT licence and you might need to stop/program/restart the TwinCAT runtime when you change the EtherCAT settings (I am not aure if you can do online change on EtherCAT changes), but you can do stop/prog/restart programmatically. Another option would be to use the open source C++ EtherCAT Master. However this will violate some real-time constraints when running on a normal PC, depending on your EtherCAT config. There is no USB - EtherCAT adapter because you would not uave much use for it. You can use your EtherNet port and the open souce EtherCAT Master (this will violate some real-time constrainta) on your PC. As USB is inherentoy non real-time capable so it will never be true EtherCAT on the USB side, so you are better of using your Ethernet port

Author: akoscs
Content: Yes, the issue with USB/ Win is determinism. If you do not need the determinism part just use an ethernet port why bother with a USB-EtherCat converter when the USB is not real-time capable. Just ise your (also non real time capable) ethernet port. Or a USB-Ethernet port.

Author: akoscs
Content: With TwinCAT the communication betwwen the engineering environment and the runtime is via ADS, so yes ADS is used to configure ethercat slaves on the runtime, however i am not sure if configuring ethercat slaves via ADS is documented (well enough). Doing advanced  stuff with ADS (like eg. feeding G-Code to the TwinCAT CNC is poorly documented)

Author: mparris
Content:
Yes, this is for an application where 50ms update rate is acceptable (not doing motion)

The EK9160 is a fantastic device in that it is an EtherCAT master and offloads the polling of the slaves from the PC and does the polling as fast as it is able.  Since EtherCAT is a poll/response architecture, that is a lot of processing for not much benefit if the values are not changing.  Then the EK9160 is also an OPC UA server that allows subscribing to only the data of interest, setting up the desired publish rate, setting up deadbands on analog values, and all this over TCP/IP which is typical for operating systems (no special low-level Ethernet drivers required).

A USB EtherCAT adapter could do something similar, and not require the PC to have a dedicated Ethernet port for EtherCAT.  I assume the LAN adapter from Hilscher is for the same purpose.
https://www.hilscher.com/products/product-groups/gateways/for-the-control-cabinet-ip20/lan-gateways/nhst-t100-enecm/

Author: akoscs
Content: Usb-ethercat is the same as usb-ethernet if you do not have real-time capabilitiea on one and why would you need it on the other end? No the hilscher adapter is not just a simple transciever.

Author: mparris
Content:
Let me clarify... The consequences of jitter or latency won't affect my application like it would a motion application.  That doesn't mean I don't want the data as fast as possible. üòÅ

All the benefits I listed above for the EK9160 is why a USB EtherCAT would be better than a generic USB Ethernet dongle. It offloads the full poll/response stack from the application/PC, and the application can subscribe to a stream of exactly the data that it wants, each of which would have filters on it like deadbands, rather than getting all the EtherCAT data and having to filter thorough it itself.

All of this together keeps the bandwidth/processing minimized for the application, and would not require a special licensed EtherCAT Master software with special Ethernet drivers to allow applications to bypass the TCP/IP stack typical of Windows. The cost of the hardware would be the license.

I'm considering an application running in a Docker container, the Hilscher LAN Gateway device looks promising, as it would be doing all the processing I mentioned above, and instead of a USB interface, could make use of a standard Ethernet interface easily accessable from a Docker container?

Author: akoscs
Content: I agree that the functionality you describe is verx useful. I would not call such a device a dongle. That is a full fledge ethercat master with a usb connection to a usb host. As such a device would be a standalone device‚Ä¶it would be weird to connect it vie USB. I mean you do not connect together two PCs via USB. But that is just my subjective opinion on the matter. On a more objective note, you can run an open source, free ethercat master on a raspi and communicate to Beckhoff ethercat slaves (e.g a bus coupler). I assume it could work feom docker also, i think you need raw socket access to the eth port. I think it was using this library https://github.com/OpenEtherCATsociety/SOEM

Author: plarochelle
Content:
So looking for some opinions on how to best build an open interface to some hardware.  Without getting into the protocol debate lets just assume that MQTT is the chosen path.  When writing commands would it be best to expose all of the parameters within the topic structure and then have a command boolean to execute the function - or - set something up like a parameterized get/set function?  
I come from the industrial automation world where these types of things were always just exposed as tags and commands were written once the 'recipe' or set points were downloaded.  All the parameters are available in real-time and can be tracked/monitored without having to ask for them. my inclination when building an industrial protocol for a device would be to expose all parameters as 'tags' and then execute the command.
Can any one speak as to why perhaps a get/set function with parameters may be a better solution?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I don't have an "experienced" answer for you just my thoughts. I can see the merits of both but let's walk though one example:

Author: hobbes1069
Content: You have some kind of oven controlled by a PID loop and you want to change the temperature. You could have a generic command topic path and just embed what you want to change and the new setpoint in a JSON payload. You could also have a specific topic path `/temp_sp` or something like that with just the value of the setpoint.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: From the UNS "holy grail" AI point of view, I think it would be better to have a specific topic just for the setpoint because if you're historizing everything (and you should be) now you can easily track when the setpoint was changed and how long it took for the oven to change to the new setpoint.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Of course, thinking about it a bit more, the setpoint should already be exposed as a topic, which you should be subscribed to so you can confirm it changed, so now we're back to "either way would work" ü§£

Author: plarochelle
Content: Thanks @Richard Shaw  - your thoughts are in line with mine.  It makes sense to me to expose all information to the topic path in accordance with the principles of the UNS.

Back then, the news were mentioning MQTT but with a disclaimer that it was specifically for AWS IoT Core, but soon other possibilities would come out. After that, I never heard about it anymore. Does anyone know if LOGO can work as a client to a broker on a local network?

Author: djuje
Content: Hey People!!! What does Walker means when he says a technology must be  edge driven and light weight?

Author: nickn5549
Content: edge-driven = no more polling, PUB-SUB (don't ask me, I will tell you the values, just Subscribe) as MQTT does. MQTT also adds the report by exception - sends out only the values that changed. lightweight = small data packets, less overhead - don't use up the bandwidth with non-important data

Author: djuje
Content: Thanks Nick... invariably means every devices/nodes in our ecosystem would talk MQTT and every MQTT enabled device is an edge driven device?

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
* Open architectures means non-proprietary communication standards. Everything plays well with each other.
* Lightweight means the data payloads are small and do not require much bandwidth. There is a lot more data on the wire.
* Report by exception means a device only communicates when there is not information. This is opposed to poll/response.
* Edge driven means several things. Data is published as close to the sources as possible (ideally the source). The edge device instantiates the connection. The edge device ideally models its data as it know best what data it provides.

Hope this helps.

Author: djuje
Content: Very Elaborate...  Thanks David

Author: nickn5549
Content: yes

Author: colinfinck
Content:
Hey all! This is Colin from ENLYZE.
When integrating machines into our Industry 4.0 platform, we often need variable lists from unknown S7-300/400 PLCs. This information is buried in the STEP 7 project file - which is often only available to the machine manufacturer and not shared with the customer. Furthermore, STEP 7 has no 1-click way of just exporting a variable list to CSV.

To solve these problems, we have written the ENLYZE S7-Project-Explorer. It's a standalone tool to open a STEP 7 (.s7p) project file, browse through all variables from symbol lists and data blocks, and save a complete list as a CSV file. No STEP 7 installation or license is required for that!
This tool has been successfully used at ENLYZE and our partners for the past 2 years. We made the experience that machine manufacturers gladly use it and send us CSV files, even when they are reluctant to provide the .s7p project file.

In order to make this frequent problem a no-brainer for even more people, we have just released the S7-Project-Explorer as a free download, including the full source code on GitHub.
We hope the tool is as useful to you as it is to us! üôÇ

If you're interested, check out:
- https://building.enlyze.com/posts/enlyze-s7-project-explorer-released-as-open-source/
- https://files.enlyze.com/S7-Project-Explorer.exe
- https://github.com/enlyze/S7-Project-Explorer

Author: juliusscheuber

Author: loganmoline
Content: Hey all. This is my first post here, other than the obligatory hello. I am trying to find a solution for a temperature control problem in my facility. We currently run 3 chillers and 4 boilers to provide heating an cooling for wine tanks. Roughly 150 just cooling, and another 75 heating and cooling. The system is VERY antiquated and I'm trying to find a solution that doesn't involve hundreds of individual temperature controllers. most rtd analog input cards only provide space for between 2-8 inputs... is there a better option? Also do any of you know of anyone who makes iiot rtd's or thermocouples that mount in a thermowell?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Hard to say without more detail. I wonder if something IO-Link based would be good to collect all the temperatures. It's not clear what you mean by 150 and 75, but is that the number of discreet temperatures you need to measure?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I agree with @Richard Shaw.  This is a great application for IO-Link.  IO-Link solves the analog and rtd module problem well.  Most of the major sensor manufacturers have already had some sort of transducer and basic signal processing embedding into their sensors for years.  They were converting that to a "dumb" digital (e.g., 0-24VDC) or analog (e.g., 4-20mA, 0-10VDC) signal for a PLC to consume.  With IO-Link, it's like hooking up a serial connection over a standard cable to that "brain" inside the sensor.  It negates the need for input cards, backplanes, panel space, shielded cables, scaling, etc.

Even if you can't find a thermal sensor with IO-Link your application, you'll likely achieve higher input density and better economics using a conventional sensor with an analog-to-IOL interface.

Similar discussion, but on power monitoring:
https://discord.com/channels/738470295056416930/740336217580765245/1020708458934308864

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: BTW, it drives me absolutely crazy when machine builders design and equip their machines with sensors setup to interface with digital inputs (e.g., 0/24VDC).  It strands all the intelligence and context out in the field.  What good is an alarm if one had no idea what was happening that may have caused that alarm?

Author: loganmoline
Content: Thanks @Richard Shaw and @js . I‚Äôm definitely going to investigate IO-Link further. For clarity I have roughly 225 tanks with temperature controls. 150 are only cooled, and 75 have heating and cooling. Almost all the temperature controllers are ancient omron E5CN controllers with no connectivity. Even if they did have pins for RS485 comms the proprietary software for these old controllers isn‚Äôt available. From what I read the 485rtu protocol doesn‚Äôt play nice either‚Ä¶ Each tank has a PT100  rtd. There aren‚Äôt currently any temperature sensors on the sub-loops that pick up groups of tanks for a given area. The boilers (4) work together to feed the heating loop but only measure temperature coming out of and into the skid. The chillers (3) work independently to cool 3 separate loops throughout the facility, but again only capture temperature data immediately coming and going from each chiller respectively. I would like to capture temperature data on the supply and return of all the sub-loops so that I can actuate the bypass valve on any given sub-loop. That way dormant loops aren‚Äôt falling way out of spec. Say for example a cellar hand fills a tank with red grapes to start a fermentation. If the loop temperature has normalized to room temperature due to not running, the boilers are taxed for no good reason because the return water is coming back at 10-20 degrees Celsius instead of 70+. Right now the SCADA that runs the boilers and chillers it totally disconnected from everything they are heating and chilling. Step one is a plan to collect and map all the cellar data, then create a new SCADA that encompasses all the data.

Author: ryankershaw
Content:
If you already have the RTD, which probably means that you have the thermowell, your best bet would be to look at getting a transmitter puck like this: https://www.octogon.org/en/product/measuring-electronics/io-link/io-link-transmitter-temperature 

Even if you can't mount it on the RTD itself, you can always put it in a small box next to the sensor.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Given the volume of legacy sensors/controllers, it might worthwhile getting in touch with a firm like Real Time Automation (RTA).  They might be able to come up with a solution using their serial gateways to recoup some of your existing investment.

It sounds like this is enough of a business continuity risk that it might be worth overhauling or retrofitting the controls and sensors.

Also, given the volume, you've probably crossed many price breaks.  I highly encourage speaking to account managers of potential vendors to negotiate volume discounts.

Author: loganmoline
Content: Thanks guys. The transmitters look slick @Ryan Kershaw   And yes @js it makes sense to me to overhaul the system.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Yeah, and to @js ‚Äòs point, this would be big enough to get a sales guy drooling (I say this as a sales guy). Also make sure you put a couple vendors up against each other. If you already have thermowells in place, you‚Äôre looking at a pretty standard piece of equipment.

Author: alandelvalle.
Content: Hello y'all. Has anyone tried out Ewon Flexy Gateway?. What are your thoughts on it?.

Author: .stibbits
Content: Currently testing one right now. Not a huge fan!

Author: alandelvalle.
Content: What are the downsides?

Author: .stibbits
Content:
It was actually pretty easy to set up. I used it to convert compact logic tags to mqtt. 

You have to use their BASIC scripting language to actually set up the mqtt and what tags you want to publish/subscribe. They have examples on their forums. 

A lot of my downsides come from comparing it to other gateways that use sparkplug B and have auto browsing of tags. With the flexy everything is manual entry of tags. Which is not a big deal, but when entering in a 100+ tags it's not ideal. 

I think if you're using the Cozy product and looking for some additional capabilities without adding some additional footprint to a panel, it has its place!

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: This FlexEdge product is interesting.  What's the use case for the gateway to handle VLANs?  Is it to rely less on switching configs?  I normally would think this would be handled by a decent L3 managed switch.

Author: mparris
Content:
Assume I have a PC that wants to communicate with multiple machines via their local machine network and not through the corporate network. Each machine network is a flat VLAN, typically on a 192.168 subnet. Also, there is the strong possibility that these 192.168 subnets have overlaps. So its not feasible to connect all these machine networks together through a managed switch.

You could try where each machine network is a separate VLAN on the switch, but don't know how a switch would handle a multi-VLAN access port for the PC wanting to talk to the machines, especially with the potential for overlapping subnets.

So the next idea is to use a double-NAT device, one per machine network, which would translate the local machine network to a common subnet that the PC would use to avoid any duplicates on the machine network. For a small number of machine networks, this could be ok, but it doesn't scale well.

So, my idea is to have a 24-port managed switch with a single-VLAN access port assigned for each machine network. One of the ports will be a trunk port to the FlexEdge. The FlexEdge can configure virtual IPs for each VLAN.

I'm waiting to get a FlexEdge in hand to validate this setup...

Author: georgeforde
Content:
I think what you are architecting is aimed at addressing the MFG chasm of our day, whether greenfield or brownfield site as @js mentions, that we have to deal with.  Equipment vendors embed 100's of man-years of valuable development (Bottom Up) within their equipment, dictate to you about 1 of 4 network proliferations (from what I've assessed) that you have to harmonize w/ site (Top Down).

In imperfect attempts to solve, I've been involved w $50 Edge Routers (i.e. NAT), to abandoning 1/2 the data w/ OPC UA DA, to the dreaded OSI Pi tunneller app, to flattening network, forcing  vendor to take on a L2/L3 Cisco Industrial Switch retrofitted in field for enterprise management of such, to forcing their OT Equipment (in production) to be Patched in a security hardening dance (add 30 weeks to and 2 lawyers to that dance).  

Although IMO, what you have looks like more of a top down approach vs. bottom up.  While I'm definitely biased towards bottoms up / subsidiarity in technology, business, and society, I like the thought process.  I have NFI what FlexEdge is - need to get smarter on it - thx for introducing.  I also wonder is there a edge convergence play possible to solve the equipment harmonization.  You know, like solve like 3 issues in one device Network security, NAT, and information in one.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: Currently we are looking at way to implement a new corporate 'standard' OEE / MES data connectivity while keep existing networks/legacy software running in tandem while a new network is stood up. I just recently discovered the Cisco IE series switches (similar to Stratix 5700) to provide L2NAT to the existing equipment. That L2NAT can then provide the L3 switch a new VLAN which has all the devices on the same network (avoiding duplicate IPs). I guess the tradoffs here are relying more  on network switch technology over smaller edge devices which are dual-homed between plant IO and enterprise network.

Author: mparris
Content:
All the complexity I'm outlining is just to get production to run by interfacing two machines together... It's not addressing the larger problem you point out of how to get good "information" out of traditional equipment.

All of the bend-over-backwards interfacing certainly feels like a hack.  After seeing one type of equipment plug into cloud infrastructure at the supplier for monitoring during FAT, then during SAT plug into the local infrastructure to get the latest configurations downloaded, telemetry automatically uplinked and displayed on production dashboards and reporting tools, it's painful to then turn to ask the controls guys of the other equipment..."Now what PLC register are you wanting us to control?"

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
A server in an MDF can be just as edge-of-network as industrial PC in an electrical panel. Ignoring segmentation, they‚Äôre on the same LAN for a performance perspective. A more meaningful distinction decoupling a node from a WAN or other nodes.

But, you do make a good point, I think there is a lot more ‚Äúedge‚Äù potential with native protocol support. It would be nice to extend the modeling down to the native namespace or registers. I‚Äôve always wanted a comprehensive solution to manage the native protocol mappings. It would be amazing to have some sort of GitHub where the industry could share this stuff and collectively reverse engineer assets. Especially for CNC machines.

Even in 2022, it‚Äôs still surprisingly non-trivial to expose a machine as an OPC UA server. Even with native protocol, most machine builders are honestly pretty useless.

Content: Sorry for the month-old reply. (just ran a search on S88 to see what has been written on here) In case it's still relevant: yes you can do S88 in codesys. You can do it in any programming language. And yes you can go from MES directly to the controllers without a batch-engine in between, but your MES does need to be able to handle it. In fact a separate batch engine is often not the best choice in many cases and would even prevent you from scaling up properly.

Author: purnendusaptarshi
Content:
Want to reach out to community for general thoughts on integrating instruments that only have serial data.
Has anyone worked extensively in programming related with parsing RS232 data? Do you have any recommendations/opinions/examples?
I have been using Kepware Ucon driver so far which works but is a bit hard to maintain. Cheers in advance!!!

Author: hobbes1069
Content: My preference is to use an embedded or small IPC running Node Red to communicate to serial devices (I assume RS485?). Then I can do whatever I want with the data.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: You could parse the message using Ignition via Python, maybe that's better than Ucon? -- I've used Ucon in the past with GE IGS, I know what you mean...

Author: zeratall
Content: I have developed my own software to do this for various projects, the hard part with working with RS232 is working with the data format being transmitted, its easy enough if it's in plaintext or you know the structure. If it's encrypted/obfuscated or binary and you don't know the data structure to marshal the bits, you have to reverse engineer the packets and it can be a real PITA.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Hopefully it's at least somewhat documented? I could see it being base64 encoded or maybe even big vs little endian but both could easily be marshaled in Node Red üòâ

Author: zeratall
Content: You'd be surprised how many are not.

Author: jeffmorgan.555
Content:
Recently, I have been testing a couple of Edge devices for RS232 & RS485 interactions, here are my insights:
- Siemens IoT 2040, device with node-red embedded, worked well with RS232, could create different flows and send data externally via MQTT when needed, had a some challenges with RS485 mobus which caused a few crashes (not stable), also the Device can take >5min to boot.
- Weidmuller IE-CS-2TX-1RS232/485, Serial to Ethernet converter, I used python libraries: pyserial (rs232) and pymodbus (rs485), this worked well, as I could have 1 master computer connect to multiple of these converters, only downside was it was not self-contained, and I could not get Ignition Ethernet/Modbus to collect data from through it, perhaps Serial/Modbus would work with Ignition Edge, but didn't test it.
- OMRON CP2E, small PLC, worked very well with both RS232/RS485, only challenges are you will needed to build the logic to run the serial sequencies, I was not however parsing the data in the PLC, more of using it as a remote interigator, data can be collected from the device in many way, e.g. openly through OMRON TCP/FINS protocal, Ignition and Kepware both have this driver, also there are several free libraries you could use if you wanted to write some code.

Content: Thanks Richard, I think I could test devices to the end of time, key for me is identify what my use case is, what functionaly I need, ease of programming / preference, and ultimatly cost. In the three I evaluated, the OMRON CP2E was the best for me, low cost, functional RS232&485, access to data via Middleware or open access standards (FINS & MQTT), and provided some edge processing (not the best, but good enough for my application).

Content: There are three that I use. Maple Systems cMT, Opto 22 EPIC or OnLogic industrial PC with Ignition/Frameworx.

Author: broken_ger
Content: @Richard Shaw interesting! havn't seen any Opto 22 stuff in german factories... most plc's are siemens, beckhoff, b&r and bosch. how is it in the US?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I think a lot of people that were "raised" in the automation/controls role are comfortable programming PLCs. My background is Manufacturing Engineering, so while I can usually "decode" a little ladder logic it's not a language I speak. I am very comfortable with Node Red which is onboard with groov products.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: But what a really meant, is that if you have a completely dumb machine (take a VFD for example). I can tie into it and pull if it's running or not (DO), how fast it's running (AO, usually 0-10V or 2-10V), and even lock it out using 3 I/O points of the groov RIO. Then I can either publish that directly to a MQTT broker from the Rio (goes into an OptoMMP namespace) or using Node Red, customize the topics as much as I want.

Author: zeratall
Content: That is also why I'm excited for PLCs that run on higher level languages (such as the Arduino).

Author: hobbes1069
Content: If you're comfortable with Python, you can obtain a free SSH license and program it that way.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: And, at the risk of being a broken record, because the Rio can run on PoE, you can even detect if you're equipment is powered down/offline.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: You can obviously do the same with a RPi for much less money, but working for a multi-billion dollar med device company, the speed of implementation and my personal scalability is more important than saving $300.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Yes, I think CmT-Srv can do a great job. For PLCs with MQTT, I'd say PLCnext and Opto 22 line. For DNP3, I believe that to be implemented in a hardware it is much more time consuming, unless you invest on some 3rd party driver such as those from Triangle Microworks. Therefore, I can't talk about popular PLCs with DNP3, specially because it is more used only on the electrical sector, but I have worked with several equipment that had it well implemented, such as Invensys/Foxboro RTUs. It is a very efficient protocol and I have used it also between SCADA systems for remote and local control.

Author: trentc
Content: For cloud hosting, make sure you consider that for scalability it may be best to have an on premise gateway that does the local communication and streams the data to/from the cloud. This could be more robust and efficient for connecting multiple machines at the site. This architecture would allow flexibility for the most effective communication to the equipment, and consolidation of the data on the most effective connection to the cloud.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: First option is integrate direct to PLC to catch the rising/falling edges of tags. Second option is to integrate to the OI Server using OPC and publishing MQTT/SpB.

Author: loris6780
Content: S7-300 isn‚Äôt opc server so use OI sidir , then if you use System Platform create your objects and use the model view to build your isa 95  architecture. Afterwards you can use the OI MQTT spb driver to publish your objects structure and metadata, etc directly in your uns

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: You don't need an OPC endpoint for the PLC. Just a driver to connect to it. Maple Systems has 250+ driver and works great for this.

Author: loris6780
Content: This is what OI sidir does by using s7 protocol

Author: loris6780
Content: Do not use OI gateway for that it has still the capability to use mqtt but it doesn‚Äôt offer extra functions like OI mqtt does. It will be discontinued in the coming releases to be fully handled by OI MQTT

Content:
hey folks, I'm not sure it's the right channel.. would appreciate some directions. 

We would like to deploy (probably) label printers for the shop floor that spits out the same thing when the operator presses a button. The use case is that they are working on a confection line and putting the produced stuff into boxes. We need the labels for the boxes with basic info like item name, measures and how many pieces of stuff is in there. The products might be changing multiple times a day, so we would like to publish the data (new label content) to the printer as well. 

We don't know the solution yet, but we are looking at many options currently. We might buy a printer with ethernet connection, plus we need a server (mqtt client, printer driver running in the same linux environment and some "gateway" app that can transform the data to a print file(?) that the printer could use, than we hope the printer has some functionality to retain the print file until a new one is given)

How would you solve that in terms of technology and architecture? I'm open to any suggestions.

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
The easy(ish) answer it to look at a Zebra or other ZPL compatible printer. Then you come up with a template of the label and substitute the variables you need on the fly to produce your label. Labelary is a good resource for developing your label:
http://labelary.com/viewer.html

Author: hobbes1069
Content: How you feed it data is up to you. We already have Tulip which supports sending ZPL over Ethernet and it works quite well.

Author: mriiot
Content: +1 on zebra with LinkOS.  You can HTTP the ZPL to /pstprnt , us the XML printing feature, etc

Author: nickn5549
Content: print labels on-demand with Zebra using Node-Red, ZPL and MQTT is doable. Like, send data that you want to print to MQTT, a node-red flow is subscribed to the topic, gets the data, generates the ZPL, saves the ZPL into a file and then sends the file to the printer. When you play with ZPL, you can use http://labelary.com/viewer.html to visualise your code.

Author: .__ink__
Content: wow guys, you are awesome! Thanks. @MRIIOT @Richard Shaw @NickN

Author: mriiot
Content: We have also built a zpl interceptor where the business system sends a label to us instead of the printer, we pick apart the zpl, display data on screen, queue the label, fill it with sensor data and release to the real printer when a case or pallet is complete.   Customer labels often have a lot of good info on them.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: We do this with ignition and MES. Printing labels to zebra via ZPL. User screens are setup to set the required data dependent on operation and just send the required commands to the printer.

Author: ico_joe
Content: Our team is having trouble connecting our edge devices to various mfg facilities via wifi. I know a lot of the issues come down to the fact that there is a lot of metal and equipment around the factory, but was wondering if there was anything we can look at to improve our wifi connection?

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
Very common issue, in general mfg facilities may not have robust wifi for equipment connectivity (for a lot of reasons):

Obvious answers are:
- get a wifi booster to amplify whatever signal is being broadcasted
- use ethernet and hardwire
- use cellular 4g/5g
- integrate your edge devices with another edge device on the floor that already has good connectivity....and use that to push your data to where it needs to go

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Looking at the two posts from @Joe Bonhage  and @MRIIOT  I decided a bit of an experiment. I decided to use Chat GPT to see if I could create a Node-RED flow to map a Modbus

For some background, I downloaded Node-RED onto my Raspberry Pi yesterday. This was my first experience with it I am also getting used to using SSH and a headless Linux.


About 10 years ago, I integrated the Ion 7650 power meter into a Siemens S7-1200 PLC many times, so  I am familiar with that Modbus map. I downloaded the Modbus map pdf. I pasted the Modbus map into Chat GPT and asked for a JSON output to allow me to create a Node-RED flow that could read from Modbus and publish to a MQTT broker. I then imported the JSON.

I encountered a few issue that required debugging.  I did have to ask Chat GPT how to use the debugger. Here's what we had to address:

1) I needed to add the Modbus modules to Node-RED. Chat GPT guided me through this process.
2) The JSON created a Modbus block that was looking for register 40010 using FC4. I had to change it to use FC3 and start at 0010. My modbus knowledge helped here, but I was able to get good advise by posing the hexadecimal communication messages from ModbusSlave.
3) The scaling block operates directly on the msg.payload.data object within Node-RED. However, we discovered that your msg.payload didn't include this data. I asked Chat GPT for advice on what to do, which involved pasting the message from the debugger. and the data was in the msg.payload object . I'm not 100% sure what that last bit means, but Chat GPT gave me a new script to cut and paste into node red.

It took me about 3 hours of work, and that included downloading ModbusSlave from WinTech to simulate my Power meter.

Without chat GPT, I'd still be reading the manual, or watching some videos, and probably know less about node-red

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Just wondering if anyone knows, if it is possible to have a Allen Bradley PLC read the Make and Model and Firmware version. I want to be able to write some code for the PLC that reads the hardware information and then pull that into the UNS. so If an Electrician replaces the PLC at night, the new  PLC Model and firmware version is automatically recorded. so they might have taken out a L81 FW16.4 and replaces it with an L85 fw21.4

Even better if I can record the IO card and any Drives that are connected.

Author: plarochelle
Content:
ChatGPT says:

In the Allen Bradley Logix platform, there is a way to access the controller model and firmware version information programmatically and store it in a tag. This can be achieved using the Controller Properties and System Tags.
To access the controller model, you can use the Controller Properties, specifically the "CatalogNumber" property. This property contains the model number of the controller. You can read this property and store the value in a tag of your choice.
Here's an example ladder logic code snippet in RSLogix 5000 programming software:
1. Add an "XIC" (Examine If Closed) instruction and enter "System.CatalogNumber" as the tag to monitor.
2. Connect the "XIC" instruction to an "OTL" (Output Latch) instruction and specify the tag where you want to store the controller model information.
3. After executing the code, the tag you specified in the "OTL" instruction will contain the model number of the controller.
Similarly, to retrieve the firmware version information, you can use the System Tags. The firmware version is available in the "System.FirmwareVersion" tag. You can read this tag and store the value in a separate tag.
Remember to create the appropriate tags and configure the ladder logic to read the Controller Properties and System Tags. Additionally, the specific syntax and available tags may vary depending on the Logix PLC model and the version of the programming software you are using. It's always recommended to consult the product documentation and programming software's user manual for precise details.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Cheers, I am not sure I trust Chat GPT 100% on this one. I have tried to Google Allen Bradley System.Catalog Number.
I'l have to get my hands on a PLC and programming software.

Author: thunt.career
Content:
I'm certain I have done this but do not have my hands on a PLC or Studio 5000 so cannot test. It will either be a CIP Generic Message to the Controller or possibly using one of the GSV instructions.

Discussion of accessing controller items -http://www.plctalk.net/qanda/showthread.php?t=125628
Linked tech note from above thread (requires contract) - https://rockwellautomation.custhelp.com/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/55301
Discussion of pulling into Ignition - https://forum.inductiveautomation.com/t/allen-bradley-logix-driver-not-legacy/60134

Example of InGear Net.Logix polling this data directly, my guess they are sending the request for 'CIP IdentityObject' within their code and not grabbing any "tags" - https://ehelp.ingeardrivers.com/netlogix7/WebHelp/Retrieve_CPU_Property_Info.htm

If I recall, most of the product code values and maybe even firmware were enums that needs to be associated to value via definitions in one of the manuals.

Author: d_leblanc
Content: Looking for recommendations for on premise software/hardware gateway that can connect to many devices/protocols and publish over MQTT with Fanuc Focas2 (CNC controllers) being the main requirement. Not many gateways support Fanuc Focas. cMT-SVR looks good but has a max of 255 topics (at the price point, adding multiple could solve that issue). Have a call with Litmus to learn more about Litmus Edge and get a quote. I will also be looking into Cybus and what it offers. I am currently just looking into Kepware alternatives. I currently manage 50 Kepware servers and 80% of my work in KEPServEX is done through the configuration API and python to push device/channel configurations, tag templates and MQTT agents/configuration

Author: d_leblanc
Content: My python code is more for launching a new production line into our current system. We have a system that we launched about 13 years ago that is deployed globally. It is very rockwell based with kepware for non-rockwell equipment. The python script will basically ask which facility/line and then give you the option to launch new (create database, complete PLC program as XML import, FT Transaction manager import XML, create all Kepware channels/devices in the server (all thats left is added the addresses to the tags). The other option presented is to update a line which will update kepware server for new devices, create import files for hardware/logic on the rockwell PLC. Current state is maintaining this system and was really just interested in alternative products that support Fanuc focas and MQTT that could be used as an alternative to kepware to evaluate for the future.

Author: d_leblanc
Content: My call with Litmus did not end with "this is not for us". I really like the platform and we will be scheduling another call to discuss what our future plans are and where Litmus can fill the gaps in what we are looking to do. From a cost standpoint and what we pay for maintenance on our perpetual licenses, it doesn't make sense as a purely kepware alternative. Litmus is much more then just a protocol gateway and we need to evaluate the product as a whole.

Author: d_leblanc
Content: My issue with MTconnect is that on most CNC machines, you are limited to the data that the mfg provides and generally does not cover the data required. I had worked with the developer for the  Okuma MTConnect agent back in 2016 for the PLC IO Monitor in v3.0 and did beta testing on it as we needed the ability to map specific I/O in the machine to MTConnect. Some companies are pretty good and develop features that will benefit everyone for free (Okuma) while others will charge. It took a few years but most manufactures are now providing the signals in our spec.

Content: Hey Daniel! Would love to understand why you want to move away from Kepware (price, flexibility, etc.) - thanks in advance!

Author: d_leblanc
Content: I do really like KEPServerEX and it has a lot of flexibility with he config API. We purchased perpetual licenses for over 50 servers about 6 years ago and just pay the support agreement yearly for updates/support. I'm not a fan of the recent changes with support as I can no longer work with kepware directly and must go through my vendor and they create a ticket with kepware support if they cannot help. this is just a delay for me as I have been using kepware for over 15 years and when I need support it is generally bugs with the software or drivers that the vendor cannot help with. The other thing is ThingWorx Kepware Server. It is pretty much identical to KEPServerEX with some extra functionality like AD support. In order for me to get AD support, I basically need to abandon the 50 license and start from scratch with the subscription model for Thingworx version.  Before I can make a decision on relicensing 50+ servers, I need to look at all my options.

Author: sim_sam3

I agree that it‚Äôs a shame you have a wait period for items that your vendor can‚Äôt handle. I also think it‚Äôs a bit nuts we wouldn‚Äôt give you an upgrade path to Kepware Server especially since you‚Äôve kept your support agreements in place all those years. Is there any chance you‚Äôd jump on a call if I were to organize one with my colleague Tucker / Director of Sales? I can prep him about the situation so he can come with ideas for upgrade path.

I would not yet call the ecosystem expansive,  as an example,  and there are still some enterprise level feature gaps, but overall I like the vision.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I‚Äôm gonna stay with ‚Äú "Why bring another player into the orchestra?"

Author: rickbullotta

Author: yonglichen
Content: Siemens's got a new initiative called IOX, being part of Xclerator: https://www.siemens.com/global/en/products/automation/topic-areas/industrial-operations-x.html.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Siemens seems to be focusing more energy on marketing and branding than on actually creating software or customer value.

Author: ajbh2o
Content:
Siemens marketing has never been great. I should know. I am from Siemens and one of the Industrial Edge (SIE) guys in the US. I don't blame our marketing team they are great people. It is difficult to convey being all things to all people. 

I joined this group because I think most people don't really understand SIE. If you take more than a passing glance to understand what it is, you wouldn't compare it to Ignition Edge, or SCADA. They aren't the same thing. You install Ignition Edge (or if you want better WinCC OA IOT Suite) on SIE. Factory floors are alive and constantly change. Think about SIE as the devops tool for the OT world. Control your system through scripting with IECTL Manage users/roles by connecting your IEM to your MS-AD. Use the relay server to connect to devices across your network. Use Siemens apps if you wish, or bring/build your own. A fan of Node-Red. It runs natively on SIE.

As a large facility operator, SIE should be what you require your contract engineering companies to develop on. The basis of your playground when you are trying to test. Consider trying to install ML/AI across your factory but not slow cloud AI that has high latency. Want a vision system inspecting my PCBs before I solder them, use SIE. Want a python script to do some work, use SIE. Found an opensource docker app tested it and need to deploy 500 copies use SIE. How many black boxes do you need? How are you going to support and maintain them? Don't want physical black boxes but need something simpler than K8s, run the virtual edge device on your ESXi server. Don't want to be locked into a particular black box, SIE is open and has alternate IPC vendors.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: IOX and Xcelerator and SIE are FAR more marketing and branding than product.  I look at the so-called "ecosystem" of offerings, for Xcelerator and SIE, and that tells me all I need to know.  But I'm open to being convinced otherwise.

Author: ajbh2o
Content: I'm not going to speak to IOX or Xcelerator, they're not in my wheel house, as for SIE my opinion is that it is far more real than you understand. The apps in our marketplace (https://www.dex.siemens.com/?selected=edge) are useful for those who don't want to build or don't have the technical capability, or they want to have a general solution. The ecosystem is young and Siemens is conservative on what is released. If you adjust your browsers location to Germany additional apps can be seen that haven't been released in the US market and we have a large group of apps that are still maturing. Still SIE is so much more than the collection of apps available on the marketplace. The marketplace is how Siemens will monetize the ecosystem of SIE, but the ecosystem itself is there for anyone to build on. Here is some documentation. https://docs.eu1.edge.siemens.cloud/index.html  The backend of SIE is what you really want. It is there to help you manage what you build so you can focus on building not maintaining.

Author: ajbh2o
Content: Luis, I would be more than happy to answer any questions you might have on Siemens Industrial Edge.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: My issue is that it's missing the real value add layer - there are many options (some of them free) for managing edge devices and their containers.  What is missing are 1) a lot of useful containers and 2) an application layer for integrating the containers for accomplishing useful stuff 3) consistent APIs and pluggable components into that applistructure.  Allegedly Xcelerator was going to accomplish some of this, but even the Siemens apps/components at that level have widely divergent API patterns and data models/formats.  This is where I'm coming from when I refer to these more as "marketecture"

Author: ajbh2o
Content:
I don't think SIE is missing that layer. SIE supports OpenAPI for device control and RestAPI/OPC UA/GraphQL/MQTT for accessing the data. Here is a better link for the API information. https://docs.eu1.edge.siemens.cloud/apis_and_references/apis/index.html
As I said, Siemens tries to be all things to all people, in this case it forced SIE to be broken down into small pieces. This means that you can tailor an edge device to solve a multitude of single scenarios or group apps and solve several scenarios with a single device. 

It can be helpful to think of scenarios, but don't lock into the scenarios because at the end of the day, SIE is there for you to bring the power of docker on the edge device. The documentation is there for you to tie your apps to the Siemens apps if you want or ignore them completely. You're not stuck using just prebuilt apps or devices.

1) Collect, organize, store and/or forward data.
      S7, EI/P, Modbus, SQL, etc. allow you to collect data from a multitude of systems. This data can be sent into the application we call Industrial Information Hub(IIH).
      The IIH essentials allows you to aggregate the data and makes this aggregation of data available via RestAPI and forward the data from a child edge device to a parent or into our applications Insights Hub or Senseye. At this time Azure requires pushing the data to MQTT before going to the cloud breaking the feature to update the asset model in the cloud from the                 edge device. (We are working on a better solution). For AWS, Snowflake runs on SIE.
      The IIH Semantics allows you to build an asset model and publish the live data to the OPC Server and a GraphQL interface. You can use a free tool such as SIOME to create an OPC UA Namespace or you can roll your own with the built in editor. Once the model exists, connect your data or create equations from multiple tags. 
      https://support.industry.siemens.com/cs/document/109755133/siemens-opc-ua-modeling-editor-(siome)

Author: ajbh2o
Content:
2) Create dashboards or help schedule maintenance. Add applications like Performance Insights, Energy Manager or Machine Monitor and quickly create dashboards/reports/notifications for things like OEE, Sankey diagrams and lifetime cycle counts. If you want to ensure your line is running optimally, take the time to build out Performance Analytics inside of performance insights and zero in on where your line has unnecessary stoppage.
3) ML monitoring motor torque.
      Using the app Drive System Framework, you can extract high(8khz)/low speed(100msec) torque data from your Siemens S120 drive This data can be fed across MQTT to the application named Anomaly Detection where you have the ability to monitor the stream of data for errors.
4) AI vision - connect IP cameras to the vision connector to stream into the AI inference server (take your created AI model using your favorite AI framework such as Keras, TensorFlow, Caffe, Amesim, PyTorch and run it inside the inference server directly on the edge device)
5) Execute a digital twin. An engineer built a model in Matlab to simulate a process, why leave it in the lab. Run in directly on the edge device with live data from the PLC.
6) The Virtual PLC is a 1517 PLC that I can run on a virtual edge device on my ESXi server. I get that you might think of that as a strange use case, but when I turn on the fault tolerance capabilities of vSphere, maybe I just created an invincible PLC using IT tools? (Currently we don't support technology objects, and safety is coming too.)
7) Want Low Code... Use Mendix. https://docs.mendix.com/developerportal/deploy/mendix-app-on-industrial-edge/
8) Use what others have already created. https://github.com/industrial-edge, https://github.com/siemens-nl-fa, https://github.com/SiemensIndustrialEdgeITA
9) Need a tool to see what's going on inside your edge device... https://github.com/siemens/edgeshark
10) Build HMI screens and run them on the WinCC Unified server on the SIE using TIA.

Author: ajbh2o
Content:
With those scenarios, I don't want you to miss the fact that apps aren't the SIE platform. The SIE platform isn't SCADA, MES, AI/ML, a maintenance system, an HMI, a vPLC, or a dashboard. Though Siemens is building aspects of all of these things for our marketplace, you aren't forced to use them. SIE is an open platform architected to allow smart people to solve problems inside their facility by building on a platform that dovetails into their IT infrastructure and uses IT tools to make things supportable into the future.
Have a nice evening Rick.

Author: ajbh2o
Content:
Thank you for your candor John. I appreciate free two way communication. One more question though. Aren't you mapping your data someplace? In a perfect world you would be using something like MTP inside the PLC, but for brownfield installations, the edge device is typically the first step away from the machine. To me it make sense to add semantics in the edge device once instead of likely doing it multiple times further up the chain.  Admittedly, I'm not the most familiar with your final installation but I believe it differs from the aforementioned typical configuration which may have caused you to not use the Semantics app. 

For those following along. SIE currently supports IP protocols such as S7, E/IP, Modbus TCP, SLMP, ADS, OPC UA, (vanilla)MQTT, S/G120 Drives, Profinet, Sinumeric CNC, Fanuc CNC & SQL. Serial protocols are not currently supported, though SIE can drill through a Rockwell PLC with EIP and connect to networks like DH+.

Content:
Have you Modbus RTU, on a 2 wire cable in a star topology without terminating resistors.
How long are the runs., how many legs in the star?
you can  have you Modbus master in the middle of a run, and I think you need a resistor at the end of each leg
And a star topology might work in a small system.

single daisy chain will likely sort you out.

Author: george9330
Content:
I want to connect Siemens PLC with Ignition SCADA using the MQTT Sparkplug B protocol. Application is wastewater pumping stations. I would like to save real value (float) if I lose connection with the MQTT cloud (bad GSM signal) and send data with a time stamp when the connection is established again. That data would be except for the Ignition Chart.

I already programmed PLC and Ignition SCADA and tried communication between PLC, Ignition SCADA, and MQTT Sparkplug B through Node Red. Because I am just starting to learn Node Red, I still haven't succeeded in saving real value (a float) if I lose connection with the MQTT.



If you know how, can you give me an example in Node Red of how to store

Float value (real number) in file or database if connection with MQTT broker is lost and send when connection is established again. I am using¬†node-red-contrib-mqtt-sparkplug-plus (node).

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
So you have Siemens PLC connected to node red at the pumping station and a remote MQTT broker and Ignition and float goes 
PLC --[s7]--NodeRed--[SpB]--Broker--[SpB]--Ignition

If so would make a buffer in the PLC that stores the information.
Add the data to the the Buffer at the bottom. There is also a data in buffer flag that you need to set.
Nodered reads the data and if it the data in the buffer is not 0 it publishes. The successful publish then resets the data at buffer to 0.
The PLC logic then shifts the buffer and if there is data in Position 0 of the buffer it sets the bit to 1. 

You could do an similar approach where you poll the data and put it into a DB table.
Colums(serial ID. Timestamp,tagname, description, value,quality,topic,published.

The second function looks for the latest values in the DB that have False in the published column and publishes topic and sets the published values to false.
Simple enough for one or two tags but more difficult for more.


A second function then looks at the DB and published the

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
By implementing an Edge Broker, Node-RED can be utilized for data buffering through the "node-red-contrib-mqtt-sparkplug-plus" node.

I configured Node-RED on both my Raspberry Pi and laptop, integrating a Mosquitto Broker for MQTT communications. My setup included a publishing flow on one device that incrementally sent numbers, and a subscribing flow on the other device that listened to these publications.

In one scenario, the Raspberry Pi acted as the primary server (mimicking an Ignition system), with the laptop sending data to the Mosquitto Broker on the Raspberry Pi. Node-RED on the Pi was set to subscribe to this data stream. However, during a communication outage caused by disconnecting the power to my network switch, this setup failed to store and forward the data properly, leading to data loss.

Alternatively, when I configured the Raspberry Pi as the publisher, sending data to the broker hosted on the same device, the system successfully retained and forwarded all data once the network connection was restored.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
The manufacturing Device Licence is available and ‚Ç¨4098 and it has Siemens and Modbus drivers.

That said, I do not think it is worth that, 4k and you can't put context on the data.
I think Ignition is competitively priced to use as a gateway, to connect, data, create contextual information and collect that information in a Broker.
I know people who go Device->Kepware-> Ignition and I cannot understand it at all. 
More configuration, more points of failure. If you are using Ignition anyway then I do not see a compelling case for 99.999% of use cases for Kepware

Lots of other approaches, too Node Red can communicate to Siemens Step 7( I have not tested) and to Modbus( I have tested) is certainly good enough to get started.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Kepware supports more protocols and its device drivers are more "complete".  They have a lot of additional configuration options that come in handy.  I've also observed they're more performant in high throughput use cases.  I recently saw a very large AB user explore replacing it and they discovered their use cases would have not been possible without it.

Kepware's drivers are not just used by the Ignition ecosystem, but many other ecosystems.  I think it's a good thing when solutions cut across verticals, ecosystems, etc.  More users and diverse deployments lead to a more robust product.  Kepware also tends to support more features and have the nuances of newer device firmwares vetted out sooner.  Because their TAM is larger and extends beyond a SCADA market, I would imagine they have larger labs and teams to work on this stuff than others.

I can see why SI- and OT-type personas prefer monolithic solutions and to limit the number of line items in a project though.  They're more price sensitive and need every bit of margin.  I still think there is a lot of value to decoupling device connectivity / protocol conversion in architecture.  This is something that, in my opinion, is more stable and should not need to be upgraded as frequently as data infrastructure and application nodes.

Author: d_leblanc
Content:
a huge plus for me is the config API in kepware. I run a python script to create channels, devices, tag groups, tags and more recently configure IoT gateway through the API.. 

Aside from the lack of a Fanuc Focas driver, the hard part of switching to ignition for me would be that I have to manually configure everything in Ignition. 

Going down the ignition route, I would rather configure everything programmatically in Kepware and connect Kepware to Ignition.

It also the reason I stick with Rockwell. I can generate a PLC import file and accompanying tag import file in under 30 seconds and have that downloaded to the PLC in minutes. 

Time is money and I don't have time for things I can automate üôÇ

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
That is an interesting approach and actually a very good point, .I'll have to look into in.
But don't forget to add back in the additionally time now to maintain the two systems üòâ 
And I will have to  see if you can use a python script to create the connections in Ignition.

@js  I am not saying that the Technology inside Kepware is not great, but I think a lot of manufacturing users, don't need that extra performance, especially if they already have an application that can communicate with their device, 

4k  is a lot of money, and more if I want to have redundant connections, and I am not a plan of my plant stopping because a single VM that hosts Kepware is being updated or fell over.


I never here anyone proposing HighByte--[OPC-UA]-->Kepware--[OPC-UA] -->PLC

 and of course there are cases where Kepware makes sense,Yes I can connect to more things, with Kepware, and it is more performant, and if it is needed to support certain usecases absolutly go for it,. But I think for a lot of manufacturing plants it is not worth the additional cost.

In a Hub and Spoke approach Kepware can function as that Central Hub. But if I am planning to use a UNS to be by single source of current state, and I need to contextualise and transform my data using a IT/OT Gateway/IIoT hub, I cannot justify the additional expense, especially for Siemens and Modbus.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It's not as streamlined as people think it is:
[ Ignition ] - [ PLC ]
[ [Perspective] - [Tag Namespace] - [OPC UA Client] - [OPC UA Server] - [Core Drivers] ] -- [ PLC ]

While it's one thing to buy and one thing to install, it's not exactly one thing to maintain and troubleshoot. It's like SAP. It's not just one application or service.  What one thinks they're upgrading could have an impact to other things. There are nuances.

In practice, I would say it's a greater risk concentrating all of the solutions into one component set. For example, does one want to disturb and validate all the connections coming into the Core Drivers module when they really just need to patch the Perspective module?  I think the money is well spent to have architectural flexibility to decouple connectivity and application nodes. But, if an SI is working on point solutions for an individual plant, this added cost and complexity may not be beneficial. The buyer may be less interested in architecture than solving a specific problem.  They may not care about these features.

I have actually seen versions of what you described with HighByte. I've seen it done to normalize data collection among both native and OPC UA based PLCs. Sometimes this is done because a SCADA may have been on a separate network and it was desirable to limit the number of connections traversing networks. It's been done to leave OPC classic nodes on the edge. I've also seen people aggregate connections into one hub and securely publish out via MQTT to another hub on a different network. Additionally, sometimes it's more productive to scale data acquisition within a single, aggregated OPC UA namespace. For example, one could leverage a pattern in the ERP or CMMS to drive a parameterized subset within OPC UA identifiers (e.g., Asset_ID).

At some point, when solutions are running production critical workloads, they'll be running on managed infrastructure. Whether on one host or many, it should not impact availability.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: We use Kepware for most of our connections.  Serves 2 purposes - 1) Splits the functionality out of Ignition as @js mentioned.  So once I have that connection created, i can somewhat forget about it.  Espeically as i try to keep Ignition updated.   2) I can now have multiple Ignition installs hitting Kepware.  Which saves some of my devices that don't handle more than one thing polling them (Omron).  So my Dev server can be setup to grap OPC data from Kepware, with the connection set to read-only.  I can't test writing, but I can at least develop everything else with production data.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Could Node-Red not do the same.
1)Set up a connection to pull data from the PLC and Publish to Broker. 

2)You can have Ignition and as many other nodes you want to subscribe

You can set up a CSV or XLS to manage the mapping from a Tag to a topic.

I wonder can Inset up two Node Red instances to act as Primary/failover IO Servers

And save the best part of 10k on redundant Kepware servers with some development time admittedly.

Or just use one ignition instance instead of Kepware for Data Acquisition, and another Ignition as SCADA.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I take the points but I am wary of relying on Managed Infrastructure and High Availability converged solutions.

1 you lose the system for a short period during failover. But one out of 10 times some service doesn't start up and your system is not recording untill someone notices the problem, raises a ticket, IT investigates, it passes through a few levels of support until the SI is called X hours later and reboots the server

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: Managed infrastructure means that there is observability on all the dependencies in the architecture.  If a service isn't available, it's considered a problem before a user notices or reports it.  Anyone, even without being a domain expert on OPC UA or SCADA systems, should be able to detect that the system and its dependencies are not in the right state.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: Of course.  The point is not solution-centered.  It's a distinction in architecture.  It could be decoupled Ignition gateways, Node-Red, Kepware, Matrikon, RTA, Softing, etc.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
But to get back to the original point.

For most users who want to pull data via Modbus and step7, I don't think the cost of Kepware is justified.

And for most manufacturing users, Ignition meets their needs more cheaply.

And if they already have Ignition, I'll take the 4k in my pocket.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I previously acknowledged this point.  It's a valid point.

SIs can be more sensitive to price and will tend to opt for monolithic solutions that bundle features because its more efficient to procure and it yields better margins.  Their customers are more often paying for specific projects rather than broad digital capability.  Because the buyer's scope is narrow, they likely don't bare the opportunity cost of one solution over another.  But, going beyond this, there's more to TCO than licensing cost.  If licensing costs were the sole factor, everyone would be using Node-Red or custom code.

Author: arjan445
Content: Hi, for a proof-of-concept i want to subscribe to different topics, as an example 50-100 topics in a S7-1500 PLC. I used the LMQTT for one topic, this works. But someone has experience with subscribing to more topics? It looks like a LMQTT is not very good developed for this.

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
Hi @arjan445. Here is a suggestion from our Solutions Architect Michael Walker.

Michael Walker
Subscribe to each topic individually using a loop.
Use MQTT's topic wildcards (+ for single-level, # for multi-level) if the topics follow a predictable pattern, though this approach depends on your specific needs for uniqueness and granularity.

Author: eoinmurphy
Content: I did a bench test of the LMQTT library with an S7-1200 PLC awhile back. Like you said, it works but to me it was a lot of effort and programming to achieve simple results. Also I noted that even with a small amount of topics being published/subscribed it was extremely resource heavy on the PLC. I think the memory usage on the PLC went to approximately 80%. Obviously the S7-1500 is a more performant PLC, but I‚Äôd suggest to take note of the PLC resource usage with a few topics configured. My feeling is it won‚Äôt scale well. Maybe enabling the OPC UA server on the S7-1500 and using something like N3uron would be a better scalable approach
