Author: ted.garrison
Content: I believe Thingworx relies on Kepserver for PLC comms.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: ThingWorx can connect to pretty much everything on that list (historians, anything that Kepware connects to). Note that Kepware speaks ThingWorx "always on" protocol, so no OPC in the mix.

Author: zeratall
Content: Kepware really is the swiss army knife for Industrial L7 lol, I just wish Thingworx had better MQTT support, the extension only covers the basics, although the auto thing property to mqtt topic mapping is nice.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Wait until you see the extension I built a couple weeks ago.  It's f*cking magic.  You literally install it, configure the MQTT broker, then drop a ThingShape on any things/templates you want to automatically publish their property data and events/alerts.  Before I release it I'm trying to get PTC to support it natively.  It's soooo easy and pretty much instantly converts ThingWorx into a decent UNS platform (along with an MQTT broker).

Author: zeratall
Content: Oooh that sounds amazing, Ive had to create a lot of custom services in Thingworx as a work around to do something similar. That's something I've really been trying to get my head around lately, is how to get the Thingworx "Thing Model" and a UNS "Model" more in sync. Right now I only model in Thingworx what is needed to consume in Thingworx, aka UNS has everything, Thingworx just has "Things" in "Things Model" that are needed for Mashups, etc that pull from the UNS. It would be nice if the Thingworx Model was just a reflection of the UNS model, so you didn't have to create and manage the model in Thingworx.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: You can sort of do that via the ThingWorx APIs (create "Things" via that API), but it would need a periodic sync.  I've done that in both directions with external object models (TW -> external system and external system -> TW).  You can also combine this with what TW calls a Network to create a more hierarchial model.

Author: zeratall
Content: Yep, those are exactly what my "Custom Services" do via the API

Author: rickbullotta
Content: If PTC doesn't want to support this, then I'll probably add the ability to use a TW "network" as the foundation for the UNS namespace.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I'm also trying to convince them to create a version of ThingWorx priced at a fraction of the current pricing, as a UNS "edge node".

Author: paapero_001
Content: I have a project where data is read from the factory's PLC and written to the InfluxDb server located in a private cloud. However, we need a way to do store&forward at the factory level if there are problems with connections. What solution would you suggest for Edge? We have not yet decided which software we will use to read the PLC data, but we have considered e.g. Kepserverex or Ignition. Is the easiest (and cheapest) way to put a local InfluxDB and replicate the data to the cloud Influxdb?

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I've done buffering at the PLC level.
Or node red MQTT.

And used a timeacale DB

What is the PLC. How much data do you want to buffer?

Author: .perguntas
Content: You may need to consider the amount of data that you need to store locally but I faced this situation before. You can try using the Coreflux Edge MQTT broker to collect the data from your PLC's and retain it locally with a SQL solution.

Author: scrapper7161
Content:
Carefull with the PLC question... üòÖ Don't store data on the edge (PLC) , otherwise we keep having those locally handled integration. 

@HugoFelgueiras 
I also recommend using  would recommend a broker like coreflux , free , and usually focus a multi-thread solution and runaway from mosquito. Since no thread gets "caught" in the CPU processing something while a bunch of topics are arriving, for better performance Coreflux and Emqx.
I used a similar approach with Maria DB with stored procedures to store and then pull from above, not push. Worked well but crazy handling of data. Then started to use Kafka.

Definitely when it comes to store data for cache in a specific way , then the list of standards start to increase and it is wild wild west. So usually c# , python and now Go give me the solution to work on.
If you need a good and fast implementation in c# I can help

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
If the data is in the PLC, and you want to guard against loss of comms to the PLC, you need to store on the PLC. But I'd call that buffering not storing as such.

Once the data is off the PLC I would ask what tools are on site and familiar to the user

Author: .perguntas
Content: @Mark O'Donovan I don't want to get into "philosophical" arguments but I always defended that the PLCs were built to control processes and not to store data. As an automation engineer my role was always to improve the efficiency of the equipment/machine, and if you add more layers of process to the PLC, like buffering, then you are consuming resources and spending time that you can use to focus on improvement. Today it's not difficult to maintain or implement an edge device that collects the data from multiple shop floor devices or PLCs, handle the data and publishing it into the cloud.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I used both.
the great thing about the IT8000E is you can customer program so much.
The supplier did it for us, but I designed the screen, with the progress bar, ( I love a progress bar)
The Plant had a box packing line, and at the time the checkweigher didn't have this as the checkweigher, but it has been swapped out.
WE put about 30 of them into the plant, and at the same time we were putting them into the another 8 plants.

The D70ES you will probably get up and running much faster. but I think you would enjoy the IT8000E, and probabably get a lot out of  
***"Free programmability***

*Standard programs can be adapted to the requirements of specific applications. New programs can be designed and tested in a very simple way on a PC with the RTC program development environment.
**Simple integration**

The Linux based operating system with the integrated web server provides the ideal functionality for the integration of the IT8000E into local area networks. WLAN communication and remote access via internet are also possible"*

but I cannot find any details on how to program or what you can program

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I just googled, looks like someone got to Systec and they are integrating MQTT
"*All freely programmable SysTec devices can connect to a MQTT broker. This requires current firmware, which our partners can find in the software download section of our website. There is a simple command set in RTC that can be used to establish and terminate the connection, subscribe to topics and send messages.

Special case: IT9: With the new IT9 weighing terminal it will also be possible to configure an own MQTT broker - no gateway is needed!*"

https://www.systecnet.com/en/products/software/mqtt.html

Author: war3n_
Content: Hi guys, I am currently trying to retrieve data from my proface HMI to perform OEE. Can anyone help me, I plan on using OPC UA server for that. Does anyone here have any tips for me. Ps. I am new here

Author: trentc
Content: Well, let‚Äôs first determine if the HMI is the best source for the information that you‚Äôre looking for. Does the HMI display counts like total and rejects? What about machine states like running, stopped and any explanation of the stops? Where does the HMI get this information from? Is there a PLC that it‚Äôs communicating with? Maybe the PLC is a better source. Then comes the question of how to extract the data, how would we communicate with the HMI? What communication methods and protocols can we leverage?

Author: war3n_
Content:
So the HMI actually displays any operation being taken in place, from the level of solution in a tank to the amount of starch being used. It also provides whether the machine is properly working or if there is any failure.
The PLC that it is connected to does not have an adequate comminication port for data transfer while the HMI have a Ethernet port and an RS 485, com port

Author: trentc
Content: What model of proface and PLC are we working with?

Author: war3n_
Content: It's GP-4501TW HMI and an Omron sysmac CP1H

Author: war3n_
Content: The Omron is the PLC being used

Author: trentc
Content: Full Disclosure, I‚Äôm an engineer for Omron. So I‚Äôm familiar‚Ä¶ üòú

Author: war3n_
Content: Ohh that's great then, can you help me?

Author: trentc
Content: I‚Äôll help where i can. I‚Äôm looking at the proface to see our data extraction options‚Ä¶ Do you have the CP1H and proface programs for your system? That would be very helpful.

Author: trentc
Content: Maybe we can do this through dm and we can update the message thread later with our results.

Author: vatsalshah
Content: Hyperconverged infra is here to stay. The control planes (k8s or native) in the cloud are far superior than whatever we build at the edge. If cloud and edge both are under the same control plane, it will reduce friction to migrate workload/data/AI to cloud.

Author: brianpribe
Content: Any new hardware that manages containers will need to have this control plane.

Author: vatsalshah
Content: yepp - the interesting part is that it's not easy to compete with 3 cloud companies (and Redhat). Their control planes (like Google Anthos / Azure IoT Operations / openshift)  are already doing non-industrial edge apps so enabling industrial apps will get easier over time. Most capable edge will become hyperconverged sooner or later.

Author: bachan1868_11442
Content: Not sure if this belongs in #questions or here in edge.   There isn't an "edge wannabe" section.   I've got gauges connected to a keyboard wedge (RS-232)  the data feeds into an app that allows the operator to make decisions to the inspection gauge data and send it to a database.  Sometimes the connection (or maybe the app) is not solid and data is lost.  Not sure if it because of buffer issue or app timeout.  I'm new here and about to design something to replace the app.  I've heard comments, " And we're hoping that fixes the missing data issue."  I'm not sure I agree with statement because I've not heard that the timeout assumption has been proved or a possible  buffer issue has been ruled out.  Network communication not my forte.  Wondering what the community might think of this:  suggesting that they replace the keyboard wedge device with a serial to ethernet converter like a Moxa box.  Would that be a more reliable way to get gauge inspection data to a network database?  Might this better way clear up the missing data issue? (albeit an issue that may not have been properly sniffed out).  Just asking to see what the thoughts are.  It would move them closer to "ethernet connected" and if I could get them to replace rabbitMQ running AMPQ to rabbitMQ with an MQTT SparkplugB plugin we would be closer to being able install a UNS.  What do y'all think about rabbitMQ and MQTT plugin--does this improve rabbitMQ?  What might be a better suggestion?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
There are two ways approach this. The one is I'll call the "wedge" approach and the second the "automation" approach.

It sounds like you started on the wedge approach already. There is data acquisition solved with a keyboard wedge or serial interface. They either collect data continously or with a trigger (e.g., foot switch, button). The major gauge vendors (e.g., Mitutoyo, Mahr, Starett) will have their own and there are vendor solutions like ASDQMS. These solve the data acquisition problem, but not the transaction problem. They don't account for state, metadata, human error, intent, etc. They just blindly capture data. These need some front end or application to facilitate a transaction. This will decouple acquiring data vs logging the data as transaction. Some QMS or SPC apps will have some functionality for logging inspection results. It will often consist of a form with the inspection content or even instructions. The data can collected into that form, verified it was collected correctly (and any other business logic), and then submitted to be logged. Alternatively, you could build something like this in a platform like Tulip or Mendix. So, by having an app, this solve the transactional problem and will enforce data quality.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
The other approach would be to use formal software or automation. The software part varies by industry and what you're seeking to measure. Sometimes it's called gage, testing, or lab software. Since you appear to be doing metrology, something like Orbit Gauge Software (fka GageSoft) would probably work. DataMyte, Marposs, National Instruments, etc have solutions as well. These apps will have a front end to facilitate the transaction but also will have drivers for measurement instrumentation (e.g., LVDT probes, transducers). They also have the capable of performing calculations (e.g., runout, flatness, least squares) for more sophisticated readings. They have their own backend database and reporting. They also can produce text files or will have some communication protocols support to interface with other systems. Sometimes the software is used as standalone testing solution and other times it is used apart of a broader automated inspection solution with PLCs. Other use cases may be less demanding from a metrology/math standpoint and can be a PLC without the software. The probes will be connected to the PLC‚Äôs fieldbus or analog inputs. These are typically used in custom built fixtures and gages. A metrology lab or gage manufacturing shop can produce turn key systems.

The key takeaway should be that blindly collecting data will lead to problems. There needs to be some amount of intelligence on the edge whether that is a software, PLC, or a front end interface to enforce the business process and ‚Äúgatekeep‚Äù the noise.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I would also raise concerns over using MQTT/SpB for this type of application. This takes a ‚Äúfire and forget‚Äù approach to data collection which is generally not desirable for inspection transactions. Unless the destination system is like enforcing a FMEA / Control Plan and is expecting inspection results (on an event or time interval basis), it‚Äôs leaving a lot to chance. Having error handling and a process to guarantee the data was read in and logged correctly is really important.

Links:
https://www.solartronmetrology.com/products/orbit-software/spc-software-gauge-software-orbit-network
https://www.solartronmetrology.com/products/orbit-network/orbit-digital-measurement-network
https://www.spcanywhere.com/

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
CMMs, if programmed right, can minimize the dependence on a "frontend" in your integration strategy. A good CMM program will have prompts for operator to choose options to determine the metadata about what's being inspected. These might be read in through a script or fixed values in the program. In the past, I've built simple console applications to process the resulting text files and publish the data to an API endpoint. Usually, CMM's text files had enough data to create a "healthy" transaction.

With gaging, if it's manual or semi-automated process, humans can be a major factor. Thsi is often overlooked. Having a front end is pretty important. A well-programmed automated solution will typically have states (e.g., production mode, debug mode, calibration mode) that help filter "noise". 

CMMs are more precise, can measure more sophisticated features, can calculate measurements for sophisticated GD&T callouts (e.g., concentricity), and generally used to "certify" more low-volume, bespoke products (e.g., tooling, gage, aerospace component). CMMs are generally in a metrology lab.

Gages are generally less precise, but far lower cost and can generally inspect in greater volume. They're commonly used as "relative" feedback about a process and where to target it. Gages can be in a metrology lab and/or used apart of the production process.

Sometimes CMMs can be used as a additional inspection layer for gages. They function as a secondary check ensure there is correlation.

Author: alexanderrodionov.
Content: Hello, I am currently thinking about architecture for an Edge Platform for company logistic centers where we would run IoT apps that connect to machinery (almost all machines have OPC UA server). Unlike (perhaps) typical Edge environments, this platform will act more like a data center, offering sufficient resources and stable network. It seems impossible to implement such architecture without a container orchestration platform, and I am looking at Kubernetes. The idea is to run our workloads in containers, spinning up VMs in Kubevirt if needed. In case we need to connect to machinery that does not support TCP/IP stack, we are going to use Hardware Gateways. Can you guess any use cases that **cannot **be fulfilled by workloads running on k8s? I presume any modern software like Node-red or Ignition can be run in a container, wondering about any constraints or potential obstacles. Dev experience? Ancient software that cannot live in containers?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It depends on what you're trying to accomplish - high availability? scalability? interoperability?  In each case, the underlying software in the containers/pods needs to be specifically designed to support those scenarios.  There is an industry standards group working on this for manufacturing/industrial use cases as well - the Margo initiative.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Here's an invite to the Margo Discord server:  https://discord.gg/CzfqTX6r

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
The - terminal is linked to the earth/ground terminal and probably the case of the unit.

I would say the cabinet supplying is the same. I've seen it loads of times. 

That said the earth cable is not connected either

Author: mparris
Content: Shields on Display cables and USB cables aren't designed to be current carrying...

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
100 % but they close the loop for the potential difference and will turn on LED's

I've seen cases where the fan kicks in and because the not neutral conductor is such a high resistance the device then turns off.

If enough current returns you'll melt shields.

I've seen the steel gland plate for 6kV switchgear melt because 3 x240mm2 multicore SWA was specified and some decided to run 3 Single core 240 AWA cables instead to save money.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Crank the voltage high enough and anything can be a ground.. including your maintenance techs..

Author: mparris
Content: To be clear...the PCs are fully running in this configuration...not just turning on LEDs

Author: sparkylarks
Content: Your shields are enough so for the current

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Interesting that the sheilds are connected on both ends.. normally that's not great practice..

Author: mparris
Content:
Your question is bringing up a different point...whether the connector shields are connected to chassis ground at both ends.

This situation are PCs connecting 24RTN to shield even when there is a separate power connection for GND...

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
It can also lead to cable melting, IIRC around 200m the induced circulating current can cause things to get hot. 

But at about 400? The induced voltage between the source and destination gets over 60V and you have to start cross connecting shield.s

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
If you open up almost any commercial 24VDC device I would wager 90% have a straight connection between N and Ground.

Some will have a jumper cable to disconnect.

I've seen that twice I think.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Yup.. and many won't have different ground planes on their board for different types of signal..   so if you're wondering why your analogs are really noisy.. probably because they're on the same plane as the power...

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
That is why to do things properly you need an electric Earth, a clean Instrument earth, and another for I.S. instruments.

I had one job where I had an instrument earth with it's own earth rod , and the Rod near the earth grid the lightning rod was connected.

Lightning hits chimney 3 or 4 IO cards blow. Fun calcs on that one. Typical voltage of lightning strikes and average soil resistivity.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Yup.. but many folks (including electrical engineers and board designers) don't understand that until they've had to learn the lesson the hard way.

Author: mparris
Content:
I'm reaching out to Phoenix Contact to explain how this is okay...

If the device has its return circuit connected to chassis, and the power supply has its return leg connected to Earth Ground, then the device's current will split when leaving the device: some current on the normal power circuit return path and some current on the earth ground circuit.  This scenario is the exact definition of a Ground Fault, where if I installed a device to monitor for Ground faults, this PC would be getting trippped all the time.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Can you let us know what they say.

I'll have to look up to see what best practice is. 

I used to know but it's been a while so don't want to say.

But there is often loads of current flowing in earth conductors, shields and armour.

3 phase motors( any imbalance flows through the earth cable or the armour)

But I think some of the issue is if you dont tie the negative to earth you can have a floating voltage where the voltage from L+ to L- is 24 V but L- to E is 2000V and dangerous.

But IT equipment and VFD's can be notorious for tripping ground Fault Devices 

But It does also come back to best practice not being connecting a shields at both ends. And not connecting L- to Ground at both ends.

Author: du5tins
Content:
@here I am looking for some edge devices that meet the following specs:
- Class 1 Div 2 / Class 1 Zone 2 Hazardous area rated
- Extended operating temperature and voltage range (-40C to 70C and 11V to 30V, power system might be 12VDC or 24VDC solar)
- Decent compute specs (8G RAM minimum, 16G storage or micro SD based so we can upgrade it, ARM or x86)
- Linux OS w/ support for a somewhat modern version of docker

Use case is for connecting geographically distributed sites. We don't have the edge software sorted yet either but we want control and ability to store/forward so leaning to Ignition Edge w/ Sp-B at this juncture. Looking closer at HiveMQ Edge and Litmus Edge and others but these appear to be read only for the OT protocols we need. 

Any suggestions or tips?

Author: sim_sam3
Content:
Kepware here! The 32 bit single registers will create incompatibility with our Modbus TCP driver. You can however use the Modbus Serial driver, enable Ethernet Encapsulation, enable Modbus TCP frames, and put the driver‚Äôs model into Omni mode. This will allow support for 1 x 32 bit registers, but you‚Äôll have a limited address range.

Enron Modbus is really the right tool but maybe your addresses are within range of our simpler Modbus Serial driver‚Äôs Omni model support.

Shoot me a note as needed! selsner@ptc.com

Author: sim_sam3
Content: For future readers - don‚Äôt enable Modbus TCP frames unless you know your Enron interface expects them.

Author: tyler092335
Content: What is everyone using for safety controls at the edge? I am used to the Rockwell point IO with safety cards that communicate back to a safety control logix. When I look at groove and plc next for the native iiot protocols they don‚Äôt have support for a safety distributed system.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Buy automation to automate well. A good machine with a native communication protocol is better than a bad machine with an IIoT protocol. Use integrated safety and motion wherever possible. Use mainstream control platforms your org is familiar with, can hire/train for, can source equipment with, etc. Northbound connectivity should be secondary criteria to this. It's not hard to add gateways later. It's much harder to fix automation shortcomings later.

Suppose there are two choices. The first is a Groov EPIC with Ignition Edge running on it, but there is a separate safety relay and motors are controlled with discrete i/o. The second is a Compact GuardLogix with CIP Motion and CIP Safety peripherals implemented. I'll take the second option every time. The alternative, if lucky, is connecting to and managing data silos across 3+ controllers. If not lucky, the data is vague or missing all together. This is not to say the Groov EPIC is bad by any means. I think it's a great solution. Personally, I'd rather compromise on out-of-box IIoT support than automation. Having a proper fieldbus and a holistic approach to control and alarming makes all the difference. Downstream, the data will be so much easier to use and create value with.

"Door 4 opened during cycle" is better than "MCR_FAULT"
"Conveyor 3 VFD at 7.6A load and 50 RPM" is better than "CONVEYOR_ON"
"Braking transistor/chopper circuit failure" is better than "MOTOR_FAULT"
"Encoder overspeed at position x = 900.3" is better than "SERVO_FAULT"

It's hard to do useful analysis or predictions on vague booleans.

Related thread:
https://discord.com/channels/738470295056416930/1095026951804170291/1227061234877071480

Author: mparris
Content:
While it is convenient to have safety and non-safety registers all in the same (dare I say....) namespace, be aware that modification of non-safety items (such as ip address) will modify the GuardLogix safety signature. If a safety event occurs in the factory where you need to prove that your safety system has not changed, you may be SOL.

With their GuardLogix design, Rockwell has clearly favored Integrators over end users, as the likelihood of the safety signature changing for a non-safety reason is high, thus all but eliminating any liability from system integrators. 

A better architecture is to separate safety and process, such as adding a Pilz or Sick safety controller connected to the PLC using a fieldbus of your choice. These devices are better at managing the safety signature, even sometimes having safety signatures for different modules in the code. 

 It's more effort up front to not have it all in one device, but if you are ever deposed by lawyers you'll be glad you have safety signatures you can depend on.

Author: yololo8163
Content:
Does the Enron driver (or any other ‚Äúmodbus‚Äù flavor) allow polling both 4,5 and 6 digit modbus addresses on the same Kepware device?   (Omni *driver* and official Enron  *protocol* only support 4, Dynamic Fluid Meter *driver* supports 5)

Is that what you‚Äôre referring to as ‚Äúlimited address space‚Äù?

Author: sim_sam3
Content:
In short yes,

In long - the Enron driver has a customizable address range table where register sizes, data types and function codes can be assigned to given register ranges. The available range is 0 thru 65535. You can mix types and function codes and sizes as long as your assigned ranges don‚Äôt overlap.

This may be more info than you need, but some additional context: A classic Modbus driver from Kepware with a ‚Äúgeneric‚Äù model selected actually supports 1/2/3/4/5 digit Modbus addresses from 0 to 65535 with the additional digit - for us at least - always a leading digit and just a means to convey the Modbus memory type, like 465535 where 4 indicates Holding Register memory. The Enron driver‚Äôs flexibility comes in because 1) the classic Modbus drivers‚Äô generic model register sizes are fixed at 16 bits rather than Enron/Daniels native of 32 bits, and 2) because the classic Modbus drivers‚Äô sub models like Daniels, while they support 32 bit single registers, have small fixed address ranges well below 65535. These are ranges typical in early Daniel devices and once we added the Enron driver and built it out with features, it put downward pressure on us to greatly enhance these sub models for the other Modbus drivers.

Author: yololo8163
Content:
Thanks so much for this helpful extra info!  Definitely not more than I need.  Thanks to your help I‚Äôve successfully configured kepware to read variable-length 4x registers and 7x registers by using two ‚Äúdevices‚Äù pointing at the same node ID.  It works, but we‚Äôre wondering how we can consolidate into one device.  

Though I‚Äôve been told the nodes are dynamic flow computers, that driver doesn‚Äôt seem to read the 7x 32-bit float registers like Omni/Enron does (returns 1.234 E+25 for example)

And initial attempts at getting Enron driver to read 5-digit 4x words (and individual bits) have failed.  Seems I can‚Äôt create a ‚Äúword‚Äù address range (but it won‚Äôt even read as floats - returns bad status)

We built a visual TWX mapping system in Kepware early after acquisition but decisions were made to source model from TWX instead, which was probably a fine move at the time.

That mapping option with ThingModel in Kep may ride again in a more generally applied way once we make progress with Edge.

Lots of talk about how to advance TWX ingest, Kepware and otherwise.

Author: du5tins
Content: @Sam.E Is there a reason why Kepware EFM exporter was punted out and rebranded under Top Server for licensing?

Author: sim_sam3
Content:
Thanks for asking Dustin! We still sell EFM directly from Kepware. However, we limit ourselves to selling 200 device or fewer EFM setups and kick anything higher than that over to SWTB. We found that we were spending far more money designing and supporting large EFM installs than we were making on licensing, and as remediation we decided to more closely involve SWTB as a partner for our EFM biz. SWTB has made most of their business in O and G and has a diff internal cost structures and can make money just fine on very large installs. 

We are very glad to sell and support everyone directly for 200 or less device counts; anything more, we‚Äôll white glove you to SWTB.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
In this case I do not have an EFM. 

This is the Setup,

I pull data from a windfarm using a PLC to PLC connection. (The windfarm has S7 PLC's connected to Modbus TCP Power meters and Modbus Serial Protection realys)
and that turn the Beacon on an off to indicate that cheap power is available
There is also a Intessis OCPP to Modbus converter to pull data from the Charging Station.

There are then three different routes done for testing 
1- the CC716 can pull data via Modbus, S7 or OPCUA and make it available on an OPCUA server or publishing to a MQTT Broker( I would have to check the Sparkplug capabilities(no Modbus RTU)
2. The Wago PLC can communicate to the  three Devices Via Modbus 
3, the IIoT 2050 can pull the data directly from the three devices two.( Support Modbus RTU as well 

the CC716 provides really great segregation between the Device Layer and the "Cloud Layer"( Here the Cloud layer is VLAN 2) If I was connecting from site to the Cloud directly that would be my choice, especially as I deal with a lot of siemens, but no onsite compute of visualisation. And it is a bit pricey

the WAGO is nice and light for situations where I need some IO and some Modbus comms, it's a nice solution. If I was better with Codesys, it could be really great. I would love to get this working a bit better

But the IOT 2050 is the winner for this use case as I need to provide the Dashboards locally on site, and I have all the data being logged to Timescale

We plan to look up an API to get the live power data.

and the Client can subscribe to the Broker to log any data to their PI system

Going forward the plan is to get the telemetry data from the Vessel( a high speed electric ferry) that the Charger is powering.

If we look at additional site, it will probably be just the IOT2050,

For example, I did not see that ‚Äúavailibility‚Äù was misspelled, even after zooming in and looking at each UI element individually, but ChatGPT easily pointed it out.

Author: mikolaj_37790
Content:
Hi all,

I'm working in the company that is slowly implementing UNS in one of our customers. I'm currently on IIot Pro. I watched the Edge Workshop from Trent Christoper but I still got some puzzles missing.

I still have some (probably stupid) questions.

We have following setup: 
- EMQX broker in the main company server room
- one instance of Ignition in the main server room for dataops and hosting MES system

We want to connect to the legacy equipment and send data to broker.

Initially I wanted to go with following setup:
- one industrial PC per line (MOXA DRP-C100) with installed Ignition Edge. This will talk to all PLC's on line and send data to broker via SparkplugB.

But than comes KEPServerEX...

Is only difference between KEPServerEX and Ignition Edge list of drivers? I can see that KEPServerEX has Telemecanique Uni-Telway driver while Ignition don't.

Is it good idea to use one KepserverEX per line to collect data from devices and then fetch it using OpcUA by Ignition Edge and send it to broker? Maybe one KepserverEX per multiple lines? Or initial setup is fine and Telemecanique Uni-Telway can be handeled in different way.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Kepware has better Drivers,  on Windows Certainly. Not all their drivers are available for Linux
Ignition Edge allow you do other things

Why not use the Ignition in your Server room to connect to the PLC's

Lots of different ways, but I would think that one Kepware per machine is very excessive and expensive. of course that depends on what a Machine is in you situation. The Large Hadron Collider is a single machine üòâ

Author: brianpribe
Content: Second @Mark O'Donovan remarks. KepwareEX should connect to multiple production machines, and allow for an OPC server to act as a gateway. This leaves you with plenty of options to get data.

Author: andybmac
Content: As I'm from large scale pharmacy i struggle with the use of the term "machine".   A line for us could be 20k+ tags, a mix of instruments (temp, pressure probes) and devices (valves, pumps, agitators).  So kepserver per line makes perfect sense to me... there's not a "machine" in sight.  We probably need a magic decoder ring for terms here between the discrete and process industries...

Author: brianpribe
Content: S88 a "machine" can be 4 different things

Author: mikolaj_37790
Content:
@Mark O'Donovan@Brian Pribe Thanks for your replies! 

I'm not sure, if I'll use KepwareEX  to poll data (like 5k tags) from 3 lines isn't it bad architecture in terms of constantly polling lots of data? I thought that local gateway (eg Ignition Edge collecting 2k tags) + sending data to broker is desired approach. Than Ignition on Server room for MES apps and DataOps. Ignition from server room talking straight to PLC isn't non scalable and simply bad idea in terms of security? I thought that one of biggest advantages of MQTT is that connection is created from the edge to broker not opposite way so we can enforce stricter network rules.

Author: brianpribe
Content: First off, you gotta get the data. If KepwareEX is the only means, then you kinda have to use it in your architecture. You could have multiple KepwareEX instances to help with the load, though a server with enough resources should manage. You just don't want KepwareEX (polling) to be your hub where you build off of it. You can then have KepwareEX go MQTT out to your hub.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Are you sure you have a S7-300 and not a s7-1500.
The S7-300 is an older PLC model. It would not typically have OPC-UA( not sure if it can at  all)
The S7-1500 has can run  WinCC Unified View of things as a Web based HMI.  and you would access that from any webclient .
Are your HMI Panels , siemens Panels, or are they just tablets essentially?

If you are running WinCC Unified View of Things, on a PLC then you have a S7-1500 so I  would set up an OPC-UA server if that is waht you want.
There is a S7-1500 MQTT block that is not really fit for your purpose

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
The desired approach depends on lots of things.
I tend to favour the concept of a Production Network ,which includes the PLCS et but also the servers that host the MES etc. good governance at a network level in relation to Segmentation and VLAN in in particular, as well as managing open ports, but really I am more concerned about managing the security to keep the outside world away from the production. so using MQTT from Production out to the Corporate or Cloud network . then I see that security advantage come into play. massively.

I am not sure the securing the Edge to Server connection in a Plant where I am responsible for both is a massive security risk.  I am much more concerned in managing how data connects to the Production Network. Also if I want to connect form the Edge to the Cloud I would favour MQTT( with TLS).

Opening Port 102 from your Server to the PLC, Is that really a material risk. You will probably want to open it to allow access to program the PLC or Screens for changes anyway.

As for scalability, if your machines at the edge are all homogenous then having a edge device that you can use as a pattern an add to each machine is great. so if you have a fleet management solutions that works, If you need to map all the S7 Datablocks to OPC anyway, I don't thing there is that much of a scalability issue to be honest.

Author: andybmac
Content: this must be some difference between "English English" and "American English" !  Seriously though: Units, EMs and CMs - i can sort of see as a machine - in the S88 physical model (I struggle with a process cell being a machine - but i can let that slide) but its not good semantics.  A temperature probe is not really a machine - its an instrument that has no functionality to be called (generally) but it is a CM as opposed to a pump which has state and functions to be called.  The procedural model items as a machine - that takes a lot more mind games.  They dont "exist" as a physical entity - they are transitory.  I can call functions but again - its not a machine as such.  I guess this is all semantics - just making sure I understand base lines.  1 press "machine" connected to a kepware server I cant visualise a tag count; 1 vial filling line connected to kepware - 10k tags in my world, 1 biotech line connected to a kepware server - 25k tags in my world

Author: trentc
Content:
I will echo what the other guys said that kepware has a larger library of drivers than ignition edge but the mqtt capability of ignition edge is far superior and you can run ignition on Linux but kepware is mostly windows. You can also do far more with ignition edge, so my suggestion is to use ignition edge either on every asset or every few assets depending on how many tags you‚Äôll be transacting.

While you could use ignition in your server room for PLC‚Äôs. I do not suggest it because typically the server room is a large network distance from the asset and you don‚Äôt want to be using cyclic communications with legacy type technologies across large networks. Unless you want to run into scaling issues rather quickly.

As far as what do you do when you don‚Äôt have the drivers needed in ignition, you can always supplement it by adding kepware or some other device that offers an OPCUA server then you can connect it to ignition edge or your ignition in the server room.

Author: brianpribe
Content: There are so many mind games that you almost have to take a course to understand it.

Author: trentc
Content:
This is an actual application I'm working on, I'm curious what approaches people in the community would take....

Omron CJ2 PLCs, FINS or Ethernet/IP would be acceptable.

Cyclic reading of a trigger ....when it changes....capture a data block.

Data block is variable length, read from plc, with max of 14700 words of data, 16 bit integers representing 0.01 resolution

It needs to be collected, transformed, and scaled, along with the part serial number (7 WORDs are ascii), coming from a different PLC, then stored to a database.

We have to do this before the part leaves typically 18s....but as short as 10s.

Author: jdingus
Content: Been a while since I followed benthos did they ever get an AB connector?

Author: brianpribe
Content: Oh yeah üòà

Author: mparris
Content:
My first thought is an aggregation PLC that can natively speak Ethernet/IP in the most efficient manner, such as COS / Event-Driven Messaging.

Then have a trigger in the aggregation PLC for some data collector to grab it all when ready.

Author: trentc
Content:
I love PLCs, it‚Äôs been a significant part of my career for 22yr, and this is not a bad idea. 

Ive done exactly this many times using an Omron NX102 that has a built in SQL client, and it does this task without flinching ‚Ä¶. 

But I see this as a technological crutch. 

‚ÄúJust throw in another PLC, you already have 3, what‚Äôs another!?‚Äù

I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs the way we SHOULD be doing things. I try to find more accessible, scaleable and manageable tools that most likely have a better cost benefit for tasks such as this. 

Paying big money for a PLC as a data aggregator, but then i still have to manage it individually with proprietary software, as long as I can ‚Äúping it‚Äù‚Ä¶.is just not desirable.

Author: _dyland
Content:
I've done close to this a few times, the difference was in the array size and where the variable length was handled... Depending on the controller, the application, the other tags communicating, and possibly the scan ti.e requirements 14,700 words may or may not be a heavy load. That said, when I did it, it was PLC logic to package everything into a clean data structure (usually in an AB Control or Compact Logix - into an Array of  UDTs nested into another UDT that had the handler tags) with a Boolean Trigger set by the PLC and Reset by the Data Gateway. Later versions added some more tags for troubleshooting like string representations of timestamps and such.

Over different projects and requirements, the data gateway was Ignition, Node-Red, and Factory Talk View SE. 

Having the data split between multiple PLCs puts a bit of a wrench, but depending on more specifics, I could see that being PLC to PLC or both PLCs to Data Gateway.... Likely both as you have drawn but I try to limit the number of different connections to PLCs when possible.

Also depends on how linked things are and if timestamps could be reconciled later or not... If we have shared IDs between PLCs or not and things like that. 

But, the ones I have done didn't quite meet the requirements you laid out because they read the full array and determined the length before dumping to SQL, rather than only reading to the variable length in the first place.

I am very curious to how you get that requirement met.

Author: trentc
Content:
Imagine doing this on Logix500, this is closer to Omron CJ2/CX-One..... where everything is in memory addressing. So I'm not building a UDTs and strings like you can in 5000. 

The only real identifier for the data is the serial number....which comes from a different PLC than the data, of course you could use time....but then you have to assume a time stamp window to pair the data together.

We discussed just using the existing Ethernet/IP link to bring all of the data together into one plc....passing the SN over, for a single source device.  However, in many real world applications, we may not have access to modify these links and add more code. Also noting that the effort that is required is a barrier to accomplishing the goal and moving quickly....because these types of things are secondary to production....and once you edit code, you own the whole thing....are reasons that engineers resist taking on these changes.

Also in your example, you assumed that you have the ability to identify the length of data to be moved to the DB based on the data block, looking for the first 0 perhaps.....but in my application there is an allocated "stack" of 14700 words that never gets cleared...only overwritten....and the only way to identify the size for certain, is to read the qty from the PLC managing the "stack" of data.

The diagram I provided is how I solved it, without the details.
1. Read trigger, when changed move to step 2.
2. Read Serial Number
3. Read Stack Size
4. Break data reads into max 500 word blocks up to the data end, and reassemble.
5. Generate event data, including serial number, insert to DB, returning event ID
6. Generate batch insert for data block, including eventID, insert to DB.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I had something similar before.
AB and Aveva but.

I had to bring all the data into one PLC, and use a trigger to populate a buffer.

And then a handshake between PLC and System Platform to say a new record was ready, have it read, confirm the read and clear the buffer.

I might have 2 or  records in the buffer.

Doing a read to the SCADA always resulted in time mismatches and data associated with the wrong entry

Author: _dyland
Content:
500 wouldn't be too bad, id make a few tables of the max size and go from there. Some things, specifically getting creative with memory addressing, were easier in 500 than 5000... I really lose people when I get into why we had to use bit overlays in 5000...

Never did get into Omron PLCs at all myself yet. 

And yeah, that serial number being in a PLC, especially a separate PLC complicates things for sure.

In my examples, we built in the ways to identify when we buffered the data in the PLC.  Sometimes 0s sometimes incremental integer IDs (that rolled over), sometimes clearing between batches. Etc.

We always added code when it got this complex, but it was always separate and on top of the existing production code in a way that ensured it was read only not write, the concern was really about affecting scan times for processes that were already pretty tight. A lot of the times it was code I, or someone on my team, wrote anyways - so we could plan ahead. 

My real answer is I couldn't tell you how I "Would do it" without way more information. Just that I have done similar. Always a unique challenge!

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content:
Maybe is a naive answer but it could help trigger a good idea
Your Data Block stage (step 4) is your bottleneck, so dont make it wait, read ciclicaly (assuming the 14700 Words are a pile and not generated all at once) at a rate that doesnt stress it and you see usefull, and add it incrementally on a buffer, that way you wont have duplicated data. When your trigger rise, transfer all this buffer to another (this will depend on your hardware power) and clean the first one. 
This way you will have access to your data for processing on the second buffer when the trigger rise.

Author: trentc
Content: That is a good idea. IN this case though, over 10k words is being filled in 8s.....each word is 1 task cycle of the PLC which is 0.8-0.9ms

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content: which is the limit of that FINS comunication? you could get the last 2000 tags every second (the average is more than a 1000 a second, so you will have some safety overlap). This way, and with a logic that only append the new task avoiding duplicates, you can have that conector running all the time on a managable amount of load so it is no longer your bottleneck

Author: trentc
Content:
You are suggesting that I countinuously "scan" the block....and when I get the trigger...take the "snapshot" from my previously read blocks of data? This isn't a bad idea....it would reduce "spikes" in the communication load....but I would have to ensure my timing of the trigger doesn't happen in the middle of a "scan"....
I found that I would sometimes get errors reading large blocks of data....so I broke them into 500 word blocks...which executes in 10-20ms.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
If you do that .
Would passing the serial number to the other PLC's help you synchronise. ( Or at least debug) Or a sequence number 

If you want to avoid PLC to PLC Comms I understand that too

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content: Yes, countinuosly scan the source on chunks of X (to be define) tag, compare this chunk with the last X tags of buffer 1, append the differences to buffer 1. When the trigger fires transfer buffer 1 to buffer 2 and clear buffer 1. Work with what you got on buffer 2.

Author: trentc
Content: Yea it helps, but we would have to set up another PLC to PLC link to do this....when I still feel like it's unnecessary.

Author: trentc
Content: Yea this isn't a bad idea...my hesitation is the complication of that logic. I honestly only need to take a snapshot based on a trigger, and I have 10s to capture it....so if I needed to, I would still only read based on a trigger, instead of scanning....just throttle the reads with delays between...which I am already doing....I added a 50ms delay between block reads...

Author: _dyland
Content: For what it's worth, after hearing more of the constraints and requirements, I'm pretty sure I would have settled on almost exactly what you did in that diagram.

Author: _dyland
Content: Also, thanks for sharing, not enough of this stuff gets past the NDAs and into the public.

Author: trentc
Content:
Helps when you are doing complimentary PoCs....and I'm not sharing anything proprietary.
I agree that not enough of these applications gets shared...I hope to change this.

Author: trentc
Content: It needs refinement....but this is how I solved it.

Nice! Honestly, I am glad I cannot share the version of this that I did in View SE in 2019... VBA, ActiveX, all sorts of fun!
It was a mess but it worked...

Author: trentc
Content: If using ignition edge to do your compute and evaluation, then you only need simple inputs at the point of sensing. Take a look at Moxa iologik, simple low cost io that has modbusTCP which ignition edge supports. These devices have a counter mode for the digital inputs so it can sit in your asset and count the number of times an input transition occurs, and you can read it at a lower frequency with ignition edge. It‚Äôs not ‚Äúfancy‚Äù or edge driven at the IO‚Ä¶ but it‚Äôs low cost and effective.

I have an active project where we're going to use Highbyte to consume the flatfiles and push the data into Tulip via its REST API. Of course thel icensing model wouldn't be cost effective for one or a few machines, but this solution will eventually be on 100 PCs in the shop.

Author: jeff.rankinen
Content: Hey All, I'm working on a Modbus RTU (Eagle Research XARTU/1C Electronic Flow Meter) to MQTT Sparkplug project. The port is RS-232. I have a RS-232 to RS-485 converter which connects to a CommFront DVS-485-2 Modbus RTU to Modbus TCP converter. I'm having an issue with time-outs when trying to poll the meter. I'm using the Modbus TCP driver in Ignition and looking at the Status Logs. Likely a baud rate or other serial setting issue. I finally retrieved the serial port configuration and register map. But I also found out this client had some customization done to be compatible with their current SCADA platform. Wondering if any of you have had worked on a similar system and found a solution to something non-standard? Thanks!

Author: jeff.rankinen
Content: Good news! It turns out it was a baud rate issue. Once we had the baud rate and other serial settings and Modbus ID correct, I was able to poll some registers. 115200 was unstable so we dropped the baud rate to 19200.  Now I just need to do some translation in Ignition. This data is in ENRON HEXASCII. For example, the 30,090 value in Register 7025 is actually 308.49 as a Float. Next, some nerd fun with ChatGPT to get the transform script for Ignition.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Glad you got it figured out but my reply would have been use some small edge device and Node Red. Skip the RS-232 to RS-485 conversion.

Author: ravil1

Author: stefan_71208
Content:
Hello all,

we are looking for a scalable modern edge solution that can scale to over a 100 sites .

Our requirements are 

- southwards OPCUA, MQTT, Modbus TCP, Siemens stack, Beckhoff ADS 
- transform messages to certain structure
- northwards publish via MQTT to a central Broker
- mangaged centrally (RBAC, Config..)
- already somewhat proven in industrial setups


Deployment architecture should be modern ‚Äì either bare metal and containerized setups (linux).

The challenge is that we dont have a lot of datapoints per plant (average 100 but will grow in future ) and to get proper pricing to start can be very difficult. 

We are currently looking at 2 different products  : 

- Litmus (looks best) but pricing is very high as we can not seem to find the right pricing structure for us
- Kepware incl Kepware+ -> still in middleage with its architecture / but is promising linux availabality for most of our drivers next year / pricing is good

We also looked at other stuff like  OPCRouter, Siemens Edge, Edgecentral (EdgexFoundry), German Edge, Node Red (Flowfuse), hivemqedge but all of them were not satisfying

Does anyone have any other suggestions of products that we might have missed?

Thanks, Cheers

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Aveva Edge? Ignition Edge?

Author: _dyland
Content:
Please do not select products based on promised features. 

What I would add to that list depends on the problems you are trying to solve. What's the use case?
With that I would generally say I would look into Ignition, Fuuz, Solace, Highbyte. Based exclusively on your listed requirements I would say Ignition (Not Edge)

Author: _dyland
Content:
Without more understanding on the use case and the intended feature set - I would rarely reccomend Ignition Edge on it's own. A lot of it's features really require a full gateway (Which can still be reasonable cheap, like less that 5 or 6k USD headless, you don't need every module).
One is that it only includes the cirrus link Transmission Module not the engine (Missing the Southbound MQTT requirement listed) and no SQL Conectivity to edge (Without some workarounds like an API layer - PostgREST is fun for this).

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Forgot to ask the most important question.

Why do you want to donthis.
What problems are you solving?

What will subscribe to the broker.


Do you need visualisation? Historisation? Integration into ERP etc???

Author: ravil1
Content:
Hi Stefan,
Prosys OPC UA Forge conforms to all your requirements: https://prosysopc.com/products/opc-ua-forge/ .
I am assuming that RBAC is Role Based Access Control. Forge supports built-in users or integration with LDAP.  Then address space and Read/Write can be configured for access depending on what user is connected.  In terms of configuration, web-based GUI can be accessed remotely. Configuration can be done also via REST API. So hopefully can conform to this requirement too.

It has flexible licensing: perpetual or subscription based. 
You can stack instances of it in layers - install on eash site, and an aggreator instance in the cloud for central access to all sites.
There is a use case with one of the setups: https://prosysopc.com/cases/from-mtconnect-to-opc-ua-cnc-data-collection-with-forge/
My company is Prosys OPC partner in North America. 
We can also help with hardware/software to install and infrastructure to manage/control all 100 sites remotely.
DM me for details or live demo.

Author: exception06lizzybusy_48596
Content:
Stefan:

I suggest you look at what ErgoTech has to offer for this.

Author: exception06lizzybusy_48596
Content:
MIStudio was built exactly for this type of scalable edge-to-enterprise deployment.

    Drivers southbound: native support for OPC UA, MQTT, Modbus TCP, Siemens, Beckhoff ADS, SECS/GEM, etc.

    Transformation: no/low-code data modeling and message mapping to enforce consistent structures.

    Northbound publishing: out-of-the-box MQTT broker integration (central or distributed) also to OPC, REST, AMQP, etc. etc..

    Central management: role-based access, configuration sync, and containerized deployment (Linux, bare metal, or Kubernetes/K3s).

    Proven in fabs & industrial sites: deployed in production with automation/data source integrations. 

Deploy your way MIStudio supports modern containerized architecture or bare-metal deployment on Linux and Windos (and BSD) with pricing that scales with your application, making it practical for plants that start small and grow over time.

Happy to share more details or a quick demo if useful.  Some videos here:  https://www.youtube.com/@ergotechsystems596

Author: stefan_71208
Content:
thanks everyone for the input ... 

there are currently 2 main usecases  for consumers of our broker

-  SAP MII -> MES - following stream back to shopfloor for Dashboarding and MES on line
-  data lake (Azure Synaps) ->  Azure Databricks - Power BI Reporting, various data science cases in pipeline (SAS)

Those are mostly already running and implemented as we already have connected around 50 sites but as said we are looking for a better / more stable / more scalable solution on the shopfloor that gives us the possibility to scale faster and connect remaining 100+ sites

Author: stefan_71208
Content:
Agree, we‚Äôre quite hesitant to work with PTC/Kepware.
Progress and development on their end has been relatively slow over the past few years, and we've noticed a significant number of people leaving, which doesn't give much confidence.

That said, they‚Äôre still strong on the connectivity side. But considering Kepware's position as a market leader, it's surprising how many essential features are still missing. We'd have expected more maturity in the platform by now.

there are currently 2 main usecases  for consumers of our broker

- SAP MII -> MES - following stream back to shopfloor for Dashboarding and MES on line
- data lake (Azure Synaps) ->  Azure Databricks - Power BI Reporting, various data science cases in pipeline (SAS)

Author: chrismisztur_43648
Content: What do the data structures look like hitting the MQTT broker?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Why not use PCO?

Author: stefan_71208
Content:
Basically its a variation of predefined message schemas .. for example 

Sensor Schema
Payload fields include:
description: A brief explanation of the sensor or data
value: The measured value
unit: The unit of measurement (e.g., ¬∞C, %, m/s)
timestamp: The time the data was recorded

Schemas can also be more complex and consist of several datapoints
